college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Leerdoelen In this course you will learn more about the different aspects and the tools to use for the communication of your research.
.
Description of the modules All participants are asked to have a look at all modules, but to choose 3 from the 5 modules to deliver the assignment.
  1. Summarize (how to summarize your research (or research proposal), both for an academic and a non-academic audience).
  2. Presentation (how to give a presentation and how to make an infographic or poster to visualize your research (question).
  3. Publication strategy This module will discuss how to choose journals or book publishers, how to assess their quality and how to make a good strategy for successful publication. After this module, you will be able to create your own publication plan.
  4. Your audience and how to reach it At the end of this module you will be aware of your different audiences, you will know more about societal relevance and impact, and you will have learned how to make your research visible for your audience by using several tools.
  5. Personal branding In today’s world of social media, it is more important than ever to ensure that you have an online presence, a ‘personal brand’, that looks professional and can be used for networking purposes.
After completing this module, you will know how to ‘brand’ yourself through LinkedIn, what the most important elements of an optimized LinkedIn profile of an academic are, and how to promote your research to a specific audience.

Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud

As the world’s urban population grows, the living conditions in cities differ drastically. Socio-economic divides, disabilities, and differences linked to gender, race and ethnicity have important consequences for people’s everyday experiences in/with the city and for their sense of belonging.

This course focuses on the key role of communication in sustaining and challenging these inequalities. The starting point is the acknowledgement that (economic) equality and social (e.g., cultural, racial, ethnic, gender) difference can go hand in hand. This means that socio-economic justice is not about everyone being the same, but about gender, ethnic, racial and other differences being properly recognized and represented. Recognition and representation are communication rights: They enable social groups to have a fair say in society and in the distribution of its resources.


Take Rotterdam as an example. Consider how the city is drawn and labeled in tourist maps and business brochures; how diverse city inhabitants and neighborhoods are portrayed in the media. Consider what corporate and municipal actors mean when they call the city “smart” and who benefits from that smartness. Consider the efforts of citizens who –wanting to be recognized as such— creatively claim spaces and visibility. Overall, consider which ways of being Rotterdammer and perspectives on the city prevail and why.
 
In dealing with these issues—not only in relation to Rotterdam, but to cities around the world—the course strongly relies on students’ own background and experiences. It pays attention to both the local and the cross-national from an interdisciplinary and critical perspective.

Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • Critical and interdisciplinary theoretical perspectives on social inequality.
  • Basic communicational dimensions of social inequality.
  • Communicative practices related to specific inequalities and efforts to contest them in contemporary urban spaces.
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Critically reflect upon, compare and articulate the strengths and weaknesses of different perspectives on the topic.
  • Take and defend theoretical positions.
  • Independently apply academic concepts and theories covered in the course to contemporary case studies and their own work.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. AFM Krijnen', 'dr. AG Fokkema', 'dr. CS Ritter', 'dr. DC Ramos Antunes da Silva', 'dr. J Kneer', 'dr. M Scalvini', 'dr. PS Cameron-Gardos', 'dr. WK McCarthy', 'JR van Keulen, MA', 'P Mashigo, MA', 'prof.dr. MPA Bouman', 'Q Huang']
text:
Inhoud Students will have a general understanding of 'ethics' for the media professional. They will be introduced to different perspectives in (social) philosophy with an emphasis on different modes of ethical reasoning. This understanding will enable the students to evaluate how well or how poorly standards in the field (e.g., professional ethics in journalism or public relations), are constructed and formulated. Students will not only be able to identify the ethical perspectives underlying these standards, but also to identify the different ethical argumentations implied within these. Through readings and class discussions connected to real life cases, students will be trained in ethical reasoning and form personal ethical underpinnings for their future careers.

Note: The lectures of this course are mandatory. Leerdoelen Students have advanced their knowledge, understanding and awareness of:
  • ethical thinking in general;
  • the cultural and historical diversity of ethical principles;
  • ethical principles guiding professional ethical standards in the field of media and communication.
Students have developed the skills to:
  • critically examine and evaluate ethical principles guiding professional ethical standards in the field of media and communication;
  • formulate and defend their own ethical principles and reflect on their own intercultural competencies.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['DE Kiss, MA', 'dr. AMM Hermans', 'dr. L Zheng', 'dr. NF Lund', 'dr. Y Wang', 'lic. S Monsalve Fonseca, MPhil', 'prof.dr. M van Selm', 'RS Rocha, MSc', 'S Lambrechts']
text:
Inhoud
T-mobile creates a YouTube viral video by capitalizing on the already viral flashmob videos online. Marc Jacobs gains a loyal following on Twitter through his personable tweets. KLM, designs a media campaign encouraging people to ‘stewardess’ themselves, gaining significant attention with well over 55,000 new fans on Facebook in just 7 days. Whether it is electronics, fashion non-profits, all companies and organizations seem challenged by new communications possibilities in the social media era. However, most are still experimenting with their communications and some are hesitant to adapt.

This course provides an overview and application of how companies and organizations are using social media. The course examines key patterns and ongoing challenges in social media marketing based on recent empirical findings, particularly in relation to social media and reputational risk, as well as social customer relationship management. In teams, students will focus on a particular theme and choose a particular company or organization. Then, applying their academic knowledge, they will conduct a practical consulting project. The course cumulates in a pitch to the company (in class) and a final written proposal using insights gained throughout the term. This workshop will be of interest to students keen on entering the private sector as consultants and communication specialists.
Leerdoelen Students have gained knowledge and an understanding of:
  • The management of social media communication and marketing within (international) companies and organizations
  • The needs of a particular company or organization  and their concerns regarding social media
  • Innovations and challenges in adopting social media strategies and campaigns
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Critically reflect upon international case studies and real-world social media management scenarios
  • Apply theoretical notions to practical consulting project
  • Develop a professional relationship with a company or organization
  • Implement diverse methods of collecting and analyzing customer data
  • Design and pitch a professional proposal for companies or organizations on their social media practices
  • Effectively work in internationally diverse teams and identify key patterns and ongoing challenges in social media campaigns

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['CC Spall', 'dr. DC Ramos Antunes da Silva', 'dr. IM Derda', 'dr. M Slot', 'M Fried, MSC MA', 'MC Eickhoff, MA', 'N Maru', 'Q Huang', 'RS Rocha, MSc', 'TTV Nguyen, MSc', 'V Balan, MSc', 'Y Leder, MA']
text:
Inhoud The introduction and use of new communication technologies in society can never be told in just one story. It is a process of mutual shaping; society and technology influence each other, with   various outcomes, opportunities and impacts for different groups of people in various contexts. In   this course, we will look at the interplay between communication technologies and society. The course is both historical and thematic in nature and offers a critical exploration of (a selection of) cultural, social, political and economic impacts of various communication technologies on our society. Teaching methods involve a combination of lectures and tutorials. The lectures provide a guide to the subject matter and set out foundations on which students can build, while the tutorials stress active participation by the students and provide the opportunity for in-class assignments and discussion of key issues and optional topics. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • The historical development of media and communication technologies in international perspective;
  • Themes central to the study of new media and communication technologies;
  • Social, political, cultural and economic impacts of new media and communication technologies and the forces shaping their development and use in different times and places.
Students have developed the ability and/or propensity to:
  • Critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues related to societal aspects of new media and communication technologies;
  • Formulate their own viewpoints and research questions, using relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. DC Ramos Antunes da Silva', 'dr. T De La Hera']
text:
Inhoud The introduction and role of new communication technologies in society can never be told in just one story. It is a  process  of mutual shaping; society and technology influence  each other, with various outcomes, opportunities and impacts for  different groups  of people  in various  contexts. In this course, we will critically reflect upon the interplay between communication technologies and society. The course is both historical and thematic in nature. Students  will be  trained to  critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues related to societal aspects of new media and communication technologies, and to formulate their own viewpoints, using relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings.  Leerdoelen Students have  nowledge and understanding of:
  • The  historical development of media  and  communication technologies;
  • Theoretical perspectives and approaches utilized in the study of new media and communication technologies;
  • Social, political, cultural and economic impacts of new media and communication technologies and the  forces  shaping their  development and use  in different times  and places.
Students have the ability and/or propensity to:
  • Critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues related to societal aspects of new media and communication  technologies;
  • To formulate their own viewpoints and research questions, using relevant theoretical insights, concepts  and  research findings.

course_title: Communication and Media Labour Market Orientation
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Graduates of the IBCoM program can take on specialized communication jobs in a variety of fields, including marketing, management, sales, corporate communications, public relations, internal communications, government, public affairs, education, journalism, the media and entertainment industries, and the art world.

This course will help IBCoM students orient on the opportunities in these professional fields, in preparation for their internships (required in the second year of the program), and for the job market after they have graduated from the program. During the lectures, guest speakers from a variety of relevant fields will present their views on the labor market in communication and media and discuss the issues that they consider key to acquiring and fulfilling particular positions or internships in their field. In the meetings students will train and develop their skills to find and prepare for an internship or job relevant to their career goals.

Note: This course is only open to IBCoM students. 

Students should have completed the course Communication and Media Labour Market Orientation (CM2008) before they may start with the internship (CM3041) in BA-2. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding and awareness of:
  • Labor market prospects and career opportunities for graduates in communication and media
  • Internships opportunities for students in communication and media in the Netherlands and abroad
  • Expectations and requirements of potential employers and internship providers in a variety of relevant fields
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Define their own career goals and learning objectives
  • Orientate themselves on the (international) job and internship market
  • Search for relevant job opportunities and internships in the Netherlands and abroad
  • Apply for an (international) internship position
  • Develop an internship plan and otherwise prepare for their internship

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. A van Prooijen', 'dr. FGR De Keyzer', 'dr. R Mittal', 'dr. S Nguyen', 'dr. Y Wang', 'PH Le, MSC MA', 'PM Edwards', 'S Lambrechts', 'S Pieters', 'TAP Oomen, MSc', 'TTV Nguyen, MSc', 'Y Leder, MA']
text:
Inhoud In this course, we will examine communication as it relates to organizations and organizing. The course will focus on the history, major theories, and contemporary issues and dilemmas of organizations in an international and globalizing environment. Topics covered are communication processes and structure, organizational culture, leadership, branding and identity, power, teamwork, and gender in organizations. Critiques of organizational communication systems, structures and theories are also presented. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • The main theoretical approaches, perspectives and issues in the field of organizational communication;
  • The role of communication in the functioning and performance of organizations;
  • Processes of organizational communication in a multicultural and global environment.
Students have the ability and/or propensity to:
  • Systematically analyse and critically reflect on fundamental and practical issues in the field of organizational communication
  • To communicate their viewpoints clearly and constructively, both orally and in writing;
  • Reflect on and improve their own competence in communicating in diverse organizational settings.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['A van Lienden, MA', 'BG Zerebecki, MSc', 'C Modugno, MSc', 'CC Spall', 'dr. DC Ramos Antunes da Silva', 'dr. SMR Driessen', 'JK Herkommer', 'M Fried, MSC MA', 'P Mashigo, MA', 'V Balan, MSc']
text:
Inhoud This course presents an overview of state-of-the art approaches to understanding media and communication as social forces. The first part of the course considers how media and communication feature in processes of major social change(s). It does so through the concept of mediatization, which approaches social, cultural, political and economic practices as increasingly organized around the workings and logic of the media. Case studies will illustrate how different fields and institutions are greatly affected by such media logic.
The second part of the course focuses on the different ways in which we can understand media and communication as technologies in governing the behavior of citizens in contemporary society. The course emphasizes current developments in media and communications in an international perspective to provide context and comparison. Course activities include in-depth discussion of key issues and questions, in-class assignments, presentations and discussions of student assignments and coursework. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding  of:
  • The main theoretical perspectives and approaches to the study of the societal aspects and impacts of mediated communication;
  • The  historical development of mediated communication;
  • The social, political, cultural and economic impacts of media and the forces shaping their development and use in different times and places.
Students are able to:
  • Reflect on fundamental and practical issues related to societal aspects of mediated communication, drawing on relevant theoretical insights, concepts and research findings;
  • Formulate their own viewpoints and research.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['mr.dr. E Boomsluiter', 'prof.mr.dr. JH Even', 'prof.mr.dr. MA Verbrugh']

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud The idea underlying this course is to present constitutional law from a comparative perspective, in order to improve the knowledge of the student's national constitutional system. For that reason, not only constitutional texts will be compared and analysed, but also specific features of constitutional systems, such as the separation of powers, judicial review (or the absence of judicial review), federalism and the protection of human rights. Leerdoelen Constitutional law has become increasingly important not only in the context of national legal systems, but also in an international context, as part of attempts to rebuild states that are in crisis or have become ‘failed states’ where stability and security are jeopardized, peaceful means of solving conflicts are under pressure and the rights of private citizens are not guaranteed. This course aims at increasing the familiarity of students with basic notions of constitutional law in various constitutional systems. Focus will be on a substantive theme and on method. Recent literature will be read with the students and discussed during class.

Students are expected to give a group presentation in which they link themes that are present in the literature to constitutional questions that have arisen in their home country.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. SPF van Haperen', 'ES Graler', 'K Parmaksiz', 'OS van der Woerd, MSc', 'prof.dr. HM van de Bovenkamp', 'prof.dr. RA Bal']
text:
Inhoud

How can we find out why countries that are similar in many ways sometimes have very different healthcare policies? Or, the other way around, why countries that at first sight appear to be very different, turn out to have rather similar policies? The aim of this course is to provide you with theoretical perspectives and methodological tools to answer the question of how to perform a comparative health policy analysis to explain cross-country differences and similarities.
We use an institutional theory framework. Institutional theory looks at the ‘building blocks’ of society. The relationships between state, market and community differ between countries. For instance, the relative dominance of the state in country A versus the market in country B can explain differences between their healthcare policies. Institutional theory also looks at how these building blocks or the relationships between them change overtime and what the role of past decisions and human action is in causing (or blocking) change.

We use a case-oriented research design to find out what is inside the ‘black box’ of healthcare policies across countries. This is a qualitative approach, in which we are not so much interested in finding correlations or testing hypotheses, but rather in learning more about the stories behind the policies. Concepts from institutional theory will help to structure the search for information and to interpret the findings.

Grading
The group paper assignment will determine 60% of the final course grade; the individual assignment will make up the other 40%.  The minimal grade for each assignment is a 4.0, which can be compensated with the other grade in order to complete the course.

Leerdoelen

At the end of this course, you will be able to execute a comparative health policy analysis and to judge the possibilities for cross-country learning.

college: Erasmus School of Law
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Benchmarking and lesson drawing by comparing public policies are important strategies for policy innovation. At various policy levels, policy actors are looking at each other to study to find out what policies have been developed, what the assumptions behind these policies were, how they have been implemented, to what extent these policies were either more or less effective and how policy change was organized. Another strategy has been to compare policy domains, examining for instance why some issues rise on the agenda more easily or are implemented very differently across policy domains. Yet, comparing public policies comes with many difficulties. To overcome these hurdles, this course adopts a theory-driven design for comparing public policies. More precisely we will look at public policies from four angles, i.e. the:
  • rationalistic mode: evidence-based;
  • political mode: value-driven;
  • institutional mode: policy feedback;
  • social-constructivist mode: policy network.
The course is directed to the explanation of public policies: what mode of public policy provides the best explanation for the design, implementation and effectiveness of public policies? Taking the policy cycle and its various stages [agenda setting, policy formulation, policy implementation, policy evaluation and policy change as a point of departure, students have to carry-out a comparative policy analysis on a policy issue of their own choice. The design should be presented in the form of a poster. The findings have to be reported in a research paper paying due attention to the course literature.

In addition, this course will discuss strategies for policy learning based on comparative analyses. How to design a comparative analysis in such a way that the findings will lead to policy learning, and what to do when research findings are available to ensure that policy change takes place? The course will be completed with a cross-national comparison in terms of policy convergence (or divergence) in policy settings such as the European Union (OMC, exchange of best-practices)? Leerdoelen By the end of this course, students
  • will have developed a better understanding of methods of comparative policy analysis;
  • will be able to develop theory-driven designs for comparative policy analysis;
  • will be able to operationalize and apply the most relevant theories and concepts related to the different stages of the policy cycle;
  • will be able to recognize and design strategies for policy learning based on comparative policy analyses.
Belangrijk om te weten Please note that this course a part of Master International Public Management and Public Policy and of the Governance of Migration and Diversity track of the Master in Public Administration. Elective students from Master Public Administration tend to experience it as challenging. Furthermore, papers can be submitted only in English.

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud Competition policy (also called "antitrust policy") is a term used broadly to describe intervention by public authorities to ensure competition in markets for goods and services. This course aims at making students familiar with the application of economic arguments in European competition law. Comparisons with U.S. antitrust law are included where appropriate for a better understanding of cases and the implications of legislation and court rulings on economic efficiency.
This course is open for EMLE students only.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. AF Roos', 'dr. RGM Kemp', 'dr.ir. RCMH Douven', 'prof.dr. M Varkevisser']
text:
Inhoud Following years of controls, rationing and expenditure caps, many countries introduce market-based health care reforms. Competitive interactions between health care providers and payers create incentives that affect market players’ behavior and the price, quality and quality of health care services. This is especially true in the United States, where the majority of total health expenditures are privately financed and prices, quantities and qualities for health care services are determined by market interactions. But competitive forces also shape strategic interactions in other health care systems (for example, the Netherlands), including those which are mostly publicly financed and where prices are regulated (for example, the British NHS).

In this multidisciplinary course, students are introduced to (i) determinants of market structure, prices, quality, provider networks and competition in health insurance and provider markets as well as (ii) the basic principles of competition law. Unique attributes in health care not only affect the functioning of market-based health care systems, but also complicate competition enforcement. Therefore, competition (or: antitrust) enforcement in the health care sector is also extensively discussed.

The central aim of this course is to study:
  • the functioning and performance of competitive health care systems
  • the use and adequacy of competition enforcement in health care
  • the challenges related to competition (enforcement) in health care.
To that end, the course introduces students to state-of-the-art concepts and literature in the field of industrial organization of health care markets and antitrust enforcement in health care.

Course structure
The course consists of pre-recorded video lectures and interactive live meetings for questions & answers and in-depth discussion of practical examples.

Some classes will be taught by guest teachers. Leerdoelen The central aim of this course is to study:
  • the functioning and performance of competitive health care markets
  • the role of EU competition law and its national counterparts in health care
  • what theoretical and empirical challenges policymakers and antitrust agencies face, when introducing competition and applying competition law in health care
By the end of this course the student is able to:
  • Evaluate the functioning and performance of competitive health care markets
  • Assess the use and adequacy of the enforcement of main competition instruments in health care from both an economic and legal perspective:
    • the cartel prohibition
    • the prohibition on abuse of dominance
    • merger control
Understand the theoretical & empirical challenges related to competition and the enforcement of competition policy in health care.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus MC Academie
Erasmus MC Academie
Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. M.J. Negrello', 'E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen']

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud Most students are comfortable using commercially available software, like Excel or Adobe Photoshop. However, the power of being able to use computers expands dramatically when one learns how to think like a software engineer and how to design and even write one’s own computer programs. Programming, or “coding”, is an essential skill for a large number of academic and commercial activities. This course is an introduction to programming simple algorithms that can be extremely useful throughout anyone’s career. This course aims to provide students with an understanding of the role computation can play in solving problems. It also aims to help students, regardless of their future direction, to feel justifiably confident of their ability to write programs that allow them to accomplish useful goals. The course uses the Matlab (M) programming language, as it is easy to learn and useful in many scientific fields, and the acquired coding skills and the programmer’s mindset will be easily transferred to other programming languages.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives:

• Illustrate the value of computing and computer programming 
• Become familiar with programming and the programming environment of MATLAB 
• Apply the use of programming to a set of problems
• Learn how to continue learning how to program

college: Erasmus University College
text: Inhoud Coding is an essential skill for a large number of academic and commercial activities. This course introduces students to the programming language Python 3 (P). This language is widely used in academia, is open and free, and allows one to use a programming language used by a large worldwide community, as well as companies like Google, Facebook, Instagram, Spotify, Quora, Netflix, Dropbox & Reddit. Python 3 is well-supported and well-documented and allows for a number of things that other packages, e.g Matlab, do not. For example, like picking one’s own Integrated Development Environment. The course Computer Science M is not a prerequisite, but can be helpful because the way of thinking like a programmer is also taught in that course. Students will be offered lectures alongside tutorials during which they will work on exercises and assignments. Leerdoelen At the end of the course, the students will acquire sufficient knowledge in order to apply techniques from informatics, computer science and programming to their own research.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

The course starts by introducing various Computer Science topics relevant for Business Analytics. After that, in order to be able to query relational databases, the SQL query language will be studied. As means to process Big Data we will look at parallel computing models, focusing on the Map-Reduce parallel computing style.

Also, with the purpose of reducing the number of computations for finding similar items (a fundamental data mining problem), we will describe Locality-Sensitive Hashing.

In order to better assimilate the topics covered during lectures, the students will work in teams on several assignments on the discussed topics. The students will also write a report describing the proposed solutions. In addition a larger individual assignment that involves programming will result in a short paper.

Leerdoelen
  • Have an overview of Computer Science topics (e.g., Machine Learning, Data Mining, Query Languages, Parallel Algorithms, etc.) relevant for Business Analytics.
  • Know Computer Science techniques (e.g., Locality-Sensitive Hashing, SQL, Map-Reduce, etc.) applicable for Business Analytics.
  • Exploit Computer Science techniques for building Business Analytics solutions.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The course content is made more homogeneous and the final exam is based on an individual assignment.

college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud The course focuses upon certain concrete legal problems that are connected with the use of information technology in society. Examples are: downloading music and movies from the internet; the legal protection of computer software, databases and data; ecommerce and electronic markets; privacy protection and computer crime; legal questions of ‘Social media’ and the liability of intermediary service providers. Students will learn to analyse these problems and examine possible solutions within the context of their own national legal system and of EU legislation. The problems of integrating technological developments in areas that have always been paper-based, and the role and use of 'electronic signatures' in these areas will also be examined. In addition to these practical aspects, the impact of technology on the development of legal principles will be discussed.
 
Furthermore, information technology has given rise to new possibilities for legal practice as well as for performing (empirical) legal research. A term that is sometimes used for this is ‘LegalTech’. Several practical applications connected with this will be discussed during the course. Among these are new ways to increase legal knowledge, as well as to manage this knowledge and to apply it.

By working on two practical assignments, students will have the opportunity to apply parts of the subject matter of this course in practice. For one of the assignments, they will have the opportunity to perform ‘jurimetrical research’ into judicial decision making. By analysing case reports, a prediction model featuring the most important decision factors can be built.
  Leerdoelen
The aim of this course is twofold:
•    to familiarize students with the social changes brought about by the 'Information Society', and to place these within a legal context;
•    to assess the impact of IT developments for the legal profession (sometimes referred to as ‘LegalTech’) and to gain insight in new tools and methodologies (for instance, for performing legal research) that are (or will be) available to lawyers.
 
After the course, students will be able to
•    understand and describe the way in which technology is developing;
•    formulate legal questions and problems relevant to our current ‘Information Society’;
•    provide solutions to these questions and problems;
•    discern the essential characteristics of the internet, as far as these are legally relevant;
•    assess the impact of IT on legal practice;
•    perform empirical research, as a group member, with respect to (data relating to) legal decision making;
•    explain the importance of proper knowledge management for legal organizations, and the role information systems can play for that.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Categories and concepts make up the knowledge people have about things and people in the world. Being able to make a connection between our earlier experiences and new interactions with the environment ensure that we can recognise and understand new things and people. For most people this is a fairly simple process which runs largely automatically, but understanding it from a psychological viewpoint is highly complicated. Four broad topics will be covered during this course: Learning categories and the formation of prototypes and stereotypes, and the consequences for categorizing things and people. The effect of brain damage or abnormalities on categorisation and concept representations, with a special focus on deficits that result in the inability to recognize particular categories of things such as animals or human faces. Embodied cognition, which will address the question whether bodily sensations or actions are involved in the representations of categories. The grounding of concepts in the brain, addressing the question where and how conceptual knowledge is represented by the brain, and which methods can be used to investigate this question. Leerdoelen Students learn the most important theories and empirical data on the way people represent their knowledge and the influence this has on behaviour. Attention will also be devoted to research methods both in theory and practice. At the end of the course, students should be able to understand, describe, and critically compare theories of categorization and concept representations. They should be able to understand, describe, and critically evaluate studies that test such theories.
  Belangrijk om te weten English serves as the language of instruction for all tutorials and lectures.

course_title: Concepts and Methods of Law and Economics
college: Erasmus School of Law
text: Inhoud This course offers an introduction to the basic concepts and methods of law and economics. It illustrates the broad utility of these tools by way of applications to the analysis of various core areas of law. This course does not aim to develop practical skills or new insights, but rather to show the broad utility of economic analysis of law. By combining examples from various areas of law, students will learn that the economic approach to law provides a unified vision of the law, tying together diverse areas of the law into a common theoretical structure.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This course takes a global perspective in exploring the theoretical social context of cultural policy with examples from European cultural strategy, though policy in the United States and other parts of the world are also examined. Classes are grounded in sociological theory and knowledge will be extended and enhanced through empirical research.  Emphasis is on the various dilemmas facing those who create, study, and work with cultural policy. Topics covered include how culture is defined, what is considered legitimate and consequently worthy of state support; art’s growing position in the marketplace; how globalization may affect local and national culture; the organizational needs of managers versus the creative needs of artists; how consumption practices influence policy and policy’s effect on cultural participation and education. We end the course considering how cultural policy has shifted to match changing cultural and social values.
 
The course is for advanced students interested in academic or applied careers in arts, culture, and public policy. In exploring various forms of culture and cultural research, the course cuts across disciplines, including economics, humanities, and social-psychology, though is grounded primarily in sociological theory and methodology. This course is a seminar and, consequently, the class work is a combination of lecture, discussion, class exercises and student presentation. Students will contribute to the content of the course through discussion and presentation of case studies that serve as exemplars. In this way, the class is research intensive, relying on student interests to direct the exploration of the course's main themes. The class is conducted entirely in English and students are required to discuss and report in every class. Leerdoelen Students will learn to distinguish the main policy concerns debated by academics and those involved in cultural policy creation and research. Students will be able to address these concerns through a foundation of cultural and organizational sociological theory and empirical research. Finally, students will be able to link concepts considered in class to the broader social context and current courses of action.

course_title: Conflict Analysis and Transformation: A Governance Perspective
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud In today's world, war between states has become a rarity, whereas violent conflict within national boundaries is of growing concern. The causes and dynamics of civil wars, and other types of intra-state conflicts, require a different understanding than classical wars. Conflicts are increasingly complex, featuring multiple parties, transnational dynamics, and strategies to resolve them.
 
The course focuses on contemporary conflicts and is structured around three parts: (I) how conflicts arise, (II) how they can be managed, and (III) how they can be transformed and resolved. Borrowing from fields such as International Relations, Political Science, Sociology, Psychology, history, anthropology, Law, this course has a distinctly interdisciplinary outlook.
 
A variety of violent conflicts are featured ranging from ethnic, electoral, ethnic, resource-based and secessionist. By adopting a case study-approach, we will attempt to understand the causes of conflict as well as techniques and interventions developed to end and resolve them such as peacekeeping, mediation, and transitional justice. Finally, you will gain tools to understand and analyse conflict, and gain practical experience in negotiating a resolution to a conflict by means of a simulation game. Leerdoelen
After completing this course, you will:
  • have basic knowledge of various types of conflict in the contemporary world;
  • be familiar with different conflict models and able to apply these models, concepts and theories to a range of conflicts;
  • have acquired an understanding of the main methods and tools used in conflict resolution;
  • have acquired basic skills in conflict analysis, problem-solving and negotiation

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud The objective of this course is for all students to get acquainted with the complexity of (un)sustainability by observing, researching, experiencing, analyzing, and reflecting on a contested concept. To enhance learning about contested concepts, the concept of ‘waste’ will be the leading example throughout this course. This course serves as a starting point for the specialization and therefore focusses on student’s positionality towards the concept of waste and on empowering students to foster an experimental mindset and take a design-oriented approach. The main pillars of the specialization: thinking, doing, relating will all be featured. The course will partly take place outside the academy.
  Leerdoelen 1. Contested Concepts
  • Students are able to understand how concepts can be contested and what this means for sustainability.
  • Students are able to rethink contested concepts of sustainability based on the ability of taking new perspectives on the concept.
2. Critical Reflection
  • Students are able to critically reflect on one's own assumptions of the understanding of sustainability.
  • Students can reflect on the boundaries and gaps in one's own knowledge.
  • Students can reflect on the role in collaborative group processes.
3. Communication and Experimentation
  • Students are able to communicate the rethought concept.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. AR van der Eijk', 'dr. BAS Koene', 'dr. RL Olie', 'drs. RJM Vogels', 'ir. JPH van Term, MBA', 'NE Constantinescu', 'prof.dr. E Waarts']
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
To bring business closer to your academic education and enhance your understanding of the business world in practice the consultancy project is part of the program. In the consultancy project you are challenged to analyse a real-life problem coming from a business-client and understand the specific needs in and of a client organization. In a group of approximately 6 students you will be asked to help a client solving a problem by developing new and sustainable recommendations. This process takes place in a project-like work setting in intensive contact with the client. You are expected to understand the clients’ needs, scope and narrow down the problem into a researchable question, develop and use a suitable theoretical framework, collect data and explore potential solutions and make recommendations. The projects often take place within a context with various stakeholders. Hence, dealing with a variety of different stakeholder is part of the project.

Next to problem-solving skills necessary in this project team cooperation and leadership in and of a team are relevant aspects in this project. To reflect on the team process and improve on your team behaviour various challenge and reflection moments are built into this 4 month process. The project team is invited to assess their members’ behaviour and critically reflect on possible improvements.
 

This course is worth 6 EC and runs from blocks 3 through 4.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • Analytical skills: Dealing with a high amount of information in a short time in an (formerly) unknown domain and gain/maintain an overview
  • Analytical skills: Being able to define, scope, analyse and structure an (formerly) unknown and ill-defined problem
  • Problem-solving skills: Develop consistent, relevant and sustainable recommendations for the client based on high professional standards and understand that there is no right or wrong
  • Managerial skills: Think independently and behave autonomously: working on problems – not following instructions
  • Managerial skills: manage and satisfy the various requirements from stakeholders
  • Managerial skills: Make use of the cross-cultural and disciplinary diversity in a team
  • Leadership skills: experience and reflect on your impact on a team process and think about improvements
  • Getting socialized into the business world

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Inhoud
Veel organisaties lopen tegen vraagstukken aan die zij niet zelf kunnen oplossen. Vaak ontbeert het hen aan de kennis of expertise die nodig is. Op dergelijke momenten kunnen zij een consultant inhuren. Het kennisvoordeel van een consultant kan betrekking hebben op specialistische kennis van een industrie of vakgebied, een specifieke methode of opgebouwde ervaringen.

In dit consultancyproject, dat een belangrijk onderdeel vormt van het pMiM-programma, gaan studenten in groepen van vier studenten intensief aan de slag om een bestaand probleem voor één private of (semi-) publieke organisatie op te lossen. Net als in het echt, komt deze “opdracht” uit het netwerk van de consultant. Dat kan de organisatie zijn waar een van de studenten werkzaam is (met als voordeel dat deze organisatie extra rendement krijgt op hun medewerker die het pMiM-programma doorloopt) maar dat is niet noodzakelijk (al is het wel aanbevelenswaardig om een organisatie te vinden waar men contacten heeft zodat men vlot kan starten). Het is echter uitgesloten dat men een adviesopdracht doet voor zichzelf (want dan is men klant en consultant tegelijkertijd). Samen met de klant (opdrachtgever) wordt er gekeken naar een vraagstuk waar de consultants mee aan de slag gaan.

Dit vraagstuk dient te liggen op het gebied van een of meerdere van de VN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). Zo slaan we meerdere vliegen in één klap. We helpen de organisatie en de samenleving. Niet voor niets wil RSM organisaties stimuleren tot een “force for positive change”. Alle teams werken dan ook vanuit het gezamenlijke adviesbureau “SDG Consultancy”, waarbij studenten de adviesteams vormen en de docent de adviespartner.

Het algemeen doel van het consultancyproject is om op een professionele wijze, met hulp van wetenschappelijke inzichten, een echt, weerbarstig probleem voor een organisatie op te lossen, om te leren samen te werken in multidisciplinaire en/of multiculturele teams, een probleem goed te definiëren, te structuren en af te bakenen en om een consultancyproces van begin tot eind te doorlopen zodat tot handzame aanbevelingen voor de organisatie van de opdrachtgever wordt gekomen. De implementatie van de aanbevelingen hoort niet tot de scope van dit project.  

Dit vak bestaat uit 6 EC en loopt in blok 4 en 5, jaar 1

 
Leerdoelen
Leerdoelen
Na afronding van het vak is de student tot het volgende in staat:
  • Omgaan met grote hoeveelheid informatie in een korte tijd, op een onbekend terrein en in een onbekende setting en hierin het overzicht te krijgen en bewaren.
  • Identificeren, analyseren, vaststellen en structureren van een onbekend probleem.
  • Ontwikkelen van een relevante en bestendige oplossing voor de klant gebaseerd op professionele standaarden en het begrijpen van de managementimplicaties van die oplossing. 
  • Oplossen van een probleem, in plaats van het opvolgen van instructies, door onafhankelijk denken en autonoom handelen. 
  • Managen van en tegemoetkomen aan de verschillende behoeften en verwachtingen van belanghebbenden.
  • Gebruikmaken van de culturele en disciplinaire diversiteit in een team.
  • Reflecteren op de eigen impact op het teamproces. 
  • Bekendraken met de organisatiecontext.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud The course will be taught using a seminar structure.  Each lecture will be divided into two parts. During the first half of the lecture we will focus on discussing assigned readings to both gain an understanding of foundational areas in consumer behavior and to develop critical thinking skills. In the second half of each lecture we will turn our focus to future research. To achieve this, students will submit three short thought papers that propose a new research question, that they will share with the class and which we will discuss and further develop. Throughout the course, insights into writing a consumer behavior paper will be shared including such topics as generating research ideas, motivating and positioning the work, and articulating contributions.

This course is taught by Prof. Jennifer J. Argo (Alberta School of Business). Leerdoelen
  1. Expose students to the main theoretical and substantive research areas conducted in consumer behavior research.
  2. Provide students with a strong foundation for critical thinking in the area of consumer behavior.
  3. Provide insight into how a consumer behavior paper is written.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Consumers are confronted in their daily lives with numerous marketing actions. Companies and manufacturers use media to persuade consumers to buy their products or to use their services. To understand the idea behind these communication messages you will learn in this course different concepts and theories from the behavioral sciences. For example you will learn how consumers make decisions and how they learn and remember information. You will also learn how consumers are persuaded or motivated. Moreover you will learn how consumers form attitudes about products and you will get insight into how all these theories and concepts are used by companies in their media communication and marketing strategies. 
 
Note:
  • This course is not accessible for students who have already completed the CM2062, CM2072 or CM2272 course.
Leerdoelen The purpose of this course is to introduce you to the study of consumer behavior. We will examine many concepts and theories from the behavioral sciences and analyze their usefulness for developing marketing strategies. The goal is to teach you these key concepts and to develop your ability to apply them in analyzing marketing situations and developing appropriate marketing strategies.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud If a company wants to build brand loyalty, it needs to first understand its customer. In this course we examine the connection between understanding a company’s target market and creating brand loyalty.
This course is project- and practice-oriented as we apply theory to a problem situation in a company. Thus, students work on specific companies; they analyse the companies’ brand, target market and brand loyalty strategies and they study how they engage with consumers in physical and online servicescapes. On that basis, students develop a new service for the company that can enhance customer experiences and thus lead to increased brand loyalty.

The course is meant to provide prominent theories on consumer behaviour from a marketing perspective. Students will get a better understanding of various marketing processes within a company as they study how they engage with consumers. They also examine, based on scientific literature, the various aspects of branding and the confluence of factors leading to brand loyalty. The course will stimulate creativity and innovation as students go through a process of analysis and idea development. Also, the students will improve their debating skills as they discuss their proposals and ideas within the context of group presentations. Leerdoelen Students will have knowledge and understanding of:
  • branding and brand loyalty strategies;
  • consumer needs, motivations and behaviour;
  • companies’ servicescapes and marketing efforts;
  • developing new service ideas to strengthen consumer satisfaction and loyalty;
  • applying theory in practice by analysing specific companies.
Students have the ability to:
  • develop their analytical and creative competencies, both individually (through individual assignments) and in teams (during seminar debates, reports and presentations);
  • advance their understanding of consumers’ motivations and behaviour, and how companies interact with consumers in online and offline servicescapes;
  • improve the insights into branding and strategies for building brand loyalty through enhancing customer experiences;
  • practice their debating skills, opinion expression, argument defense, presentation, and pitch abilities.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
​
Understanding consumers is the key to a successful marketing strategy. Unfortunately, however, the mind of the consumer is not always easy to understand. This course provides an overview of theories that best explain how consumers arrive at their judgments and decisions. The course will review relevant theories from economics and psychology that provide a foundation for behavioural marketing. Consumer behaviour varies greatly depending on a range of factors. For instance, consumers’ judgments and decisions are influenced by the market environment (e.g., retail vs. online), the type of consumer (e.g., older vs. younger), and the type of product (e.g., hedonic vs. utilitarian goods), just to name a few. Although it is impossible to fully grasp and predict this behaviour, consumer researchers have created a body of knowledge that allows us to achieve at least a basic understanding of consumer needs, wants, decisions and actions. This course will provide a structured overview of this body of knowledge. In the first part of the course, students will be provided with an introduction to the psychology of perception, information processing, emotions and decision-making. The second part of the course will elaborate on the influences of the social environment, culture and situational factors on consumer behaviour. Additionally, the second part of this course will apply these theories and principles to real-world marketing problems.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives

1.    Provide you with a foundation in the theories, models, and other tools used by academic and industry marketers for understanding the determinants of consumer behavior.
2.    Provide you with general ideas about how to influence consumers, and about how you as a consumer are influenced by others (including marketers).
3.    Prepare you to write a master thesis on the topic of consumer behavior.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

This course uses a multi-dimension perspective to explain and apply the consumers’ behavioural elements. Ultimately therefore, the benefit of this course is that students (future marketeers) will be able to identify and analyse how consumer behaviour works in practice, offering students the tools to apply this knowledge to their own future marketing practice.
This course starts with the historical context of consumption, it assesses how this process works for individual consumers and it identifies and discusses the consumers’ decision-making processes, very much touching several behavioural study areas in psychology as well.
For marketeers, it is critically important to appraise how both current and future buyers respond to the products and services that are offered to them and to use this insight to successfully offer products and services to buyers and consumers. We will assess the past, current and future trends in consumer behaviour.
Obviously, it is necessary that marketeers learn how to study the behaviour of their (potential) buyers before they can apply their findings and insights to help optimize the design of their products and services and thus generate the necessary profit for their firms.

Leerdoelen

After this consumer behaviour course, you will be able:

  • To evaluate past, current and future trends as well as consumer behaviour developments.
  • To identify how behavioural insight thinking impacts on consumer behaviour.
  • To identify the decision-making process stages of consumer shopping behaviour.
  • To explain how behavioural, cognitive and social learning impacts on consumer behaviour.
  • To explain the perceptual process, from exposure to stimuli to consumer response.
  • To assess what attitude theory is and how this theory is used in consumer marketing.
  • To analyse how personality, self and psychographics explain the consumer’s behaviour.
  • To explain the role of group influence mechanisms on consumer behaviour.
  • To appraise how buyer behaviour relates to segments, differentiation and distinctiveness.
  • To assess and compare individual (age/knowledge/income) and external (socio-cultural /geographic/demographic/technological) factors that influence consumer behaviour.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar There are no changes of this course module in academic year 2021 - 2022.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The goal of this course is to provide students with a proper understanding of consumption from the academic perspectives of the homo economicus, homo sociologicus, and homo aestheticus. Using this multi-disciplinary perspective, consumption will be addressed as a socially embedded practice where aspects of freedom and individual choice are to be considered in the light of the opportunities for consumption offered by a socio-historically specific context. This implies that students develop an understanding of the causes and consequences of consumption (both material and cultural) at both the micro-level (e.g., identity, routines, meaning-making) and the macro-level (e.g., sustainability, politics, citizenship). Having been offered a solid theoretical foundation on consumption, students will apply theoretical insights to actual consumption practices by conducting interviews on informants’ consumption practices. In addition, they will keep and present a one-week diary of their consumption and explore to what extent the theories offered apply to themselves, explicitly linking micro- and macro-levels of analysis so as to grasp the complex links between consumer behaviour on the one hand and its causes and consequences at the level of society.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of: 
  • The main theories and concepts, including a critical appraisal of their historical emergence, regarding consumption and consumer culture
  • The consumer research traditions within economics and the social sciences
  • Various definitions of consumption
Students have developed skills to:
  • Apply theoretical concepts regarding consumption and consumer culture to empirical observations / their own lives
  • Report and reflect on their findings in oral and written form

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
In this course, students will familiarize themselves with the main marketing research approaches for understanding consumer behavior. Students will acquire knowledge on: (1) how to accurately measure and analyze consumers’ preferences, attitudes and choices, and (2) how marketing variables (such as product benefits, assortments, advertisements and retail environments) affect consumer behavior. The course introduces the main methods for analyzing consumer behavior (e.g. experiments and survey research), and focuses on the design and analysis of experiments and surveys.  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
  • Understand the main research methods used to study consumer behavior
  • Analyze consumer research data, collected in experiments and in surveys
  • Interpret and make recommendations based on the results of the consumer research

course_title: Consumer Perceptions of Corporate Social Responsibility
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud A growing number of companies have started to recognize the value of sustainable business practices, and have adopted a pro-active search for opportunities to improve their societal and environmental impacts. These socially responsible practices can lead to a range of shared benefits for the company and for society. Despite these mutual benefits, it can be challenging for companies to promote their CSR activities. On the one hand, it is important for companies to communicate about their CSR performance in order to acquire potential reputational benefits. Moreover, consumers increasingly demand transparency from companies about their business conduct. On the other hand, consumers do not always respond positively to CSR information of companies. Consumers can be sceptical about the credibility of corporate claims about their involvement in CSR. Thus, even though companies might have sincere motives for their sustainability initiatives, the promotion of these initiatives can backfire due to suspicions of corporate greenwashing. Topics that are discussed in this course include the drivers of consumers’ preference for socially responsible companies, how CSR communication is evaluated by consumers, perceptions of sincerity of corporate motives to invest in CSR, and the role of new media in CSR communication. 
  Leerdoelen Students will gain knowledge and understanding of:
  • Theoretical approaches, concepts and perspectives in the field of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR) communication;
  • The challenges of communicating CSR initiatives; 
  • Consumer attitudes, motives and intentions regarding CSR.
 
Students will develop the skills to:
  • Systematically analyse and critically reflect on theoretical and practical issues in CSR communication;
  • Apply theoretical knowledge to and construct arguments about CSR-related communication strategies and issues.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In modern society, identity is increasingly shaped and defined by what we buy, brands we wear, products we use, and consumer loyalties we claim. Perhaps as a consequence, in the past several decades consumer studies have grown in importance for sociological research. Accordingly, this course examines the connection between consumption and identity.  We begin by exploring contemporary theories of consumption, including ideas on rationalization and taste distinctions.  We then turn to consumption’s role in mediating the modern tension between establishing individual identity and community membership. We next address the possible dangers of using commodities of the culture industry to help shape our societies and ourselves. To what degree does the culture industry determine consumption practices and understandings? To address this question, we first examine the other side of consumption, supply, and how cultural producers and gatekeepers determine what products to offer. Once consumers attain these products, are they active or passive—i.e., how do they use, change, or reject commercial goods? Finally, we end the course by examining consumption’s role in social mobilization, including protest, to effect change.

  Leerdoelen Students will be able to identify the major issues within consumption studies and address those issues through a foundation of sociological theory and empirical research. Students will also be able to link concepts considered in class and the literature to the broader social context and their own social realities and consumption practices.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. LE Braden', 'dr. MJ Berghman', 'GA Giolo Rego, MSc']
text:
Inhoud In recent decades, cultural sociology has been one of the fastest growing areas of sociological study. Some have even argued that contemporary sociology has been witnessing a ‘cultural turn’ – making culture (‘meaning-making’) a central aspect of sociological inquiry in many different areas such as politics, economy, the state, etc. This course addresses major themes and theories in cultural sociology by discerning three ideal typical approaches:
 
  1. culture as cognitive structure approach, which studies the way in which cultural codes, schemas, narratives and texts constrain and enable the possible range and arrangement of meanings;
  2. culture in action approach, which focuses on the practical ways in which culture is reflexively used and set to work to solve everyday problems;
  3. production of culture approach, which focuses on how the content of culture (in the more restricted sense) is affected by its production, distribution and consumption.
 
We will study exemplary works from all three contemporary approaches in cultural sociology, and, furthermore, focus on work that integrates key ideas from these different approaches into the study of making meaning in various cultural genres such as music, literature, fashion and sports. Finally, we will zoom in on how gender, race/ethnicity and nationality affect meaning-making, and how each of the three abovementioned approaches has studied such questions differently. In this course students will develop and expand their knowledge of the sociological perspective on the arts and culture in the broad sense. They will be able to distinguish three contemporary theoretical approaches in cultural sociology (culture as cognitive structure, culture in action and production of culture) and identify these approaches in recent sociological research.

course_title: Contemporary Capitalism and Governance : Neo Liberalism and Beyond
