college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud According to deliberative democrats, proper democracy requires that citizens engage in an open debate, rather than merely voting on referenda or electing representatives. The ideal of deliberative democracy is more than just intuitive: it has been defended by a wide range of political philosophers, including Habermas and Rawls.

But how does deliberation actually work in practice? Does it always nicely lead to consensus, and where does that leave us with pluralism? Will it ultimately lead to more insight and/or better decisions, objectively speaking – or does discussion in groups only lead to an increased polarization within society? Is there a clash between social choice’s aggregation methods, and deliberation? Can we get any mathematical grip on deliberation? How do contemporary political scientists look at the classical ideal?

In this interactive and interdisciplinary course, students will tackle questions such as these, drawing on work of various sorts: empirical, philosophical, and formal. They will read and discuss both classical and recent papers on them and develop their own positions in light of these.

This course naturally follows Stefan Wintein’s course “Social Choice and Political Representation” It is more advanced in terms of teaching methods (students are supposed to be relatively independent in reading and presenting papers) and focuses less on technical (formal) results and more on political philosophy issues. However, students who did not follow Stefan’s course are still allowed to take this one. Leerdoelen Upon succesful completion of this course, students can:
  1. Summarize the viewpoints defended by various “schools of thought” on deliberative democracy, and their historical development.
  2. Distinguish and explain key criticisms of deliberative democracy.
  3. Apply central concepts and distinctions in the literature on deliberative democracy: adaptive preferences; meta-agreement vs. single-peakedness; polarization; external vs. internal legitimation of democratic systems; (self)-silencing, informational cascades.
  4. Perform joint research on the subject of deliberative democracy (broadly conceived), integrating insights from psychology, political science, computer science, philosophy, and political theory.
  5. Present the results of said research to their peers.
  6. Write a short position paper on a subject in the philosophy of democracy, integrating insights gained from said teamwork and from in-class presentations and discussions.
  7. Give constructive feedback to their peers on a short position paper, both in oral and in written form.

course_title: Denken in het donker: Filosofie en Film
college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
lecturers: ['dr. B Leeuwenburgh', 'prof.dr. FA Muller', 'T Heijmeskamp, MA']
text:
Inhoud

De cursus is uitsluitend bedoeld voor de voltijdstudenten. Aanwezigheid en participatie zijn verplicht.
Afronding van de cursus is alleen mogelijk wanneer er wordt deelgenomen aan de cursus.


In de ‘filosofie en film’-cursus staat een urgent filosofisch probleem centraal waarrond een aantal films wordt geselecteerd en vertoond. Verschillende docenten verzorgen colleges over het thema en de gekozen films. Van de studenten wordt verwacht dat zij essays schrijven, elkaars essays beoordelen, en presenteren en discussiëren over de films en het thema. De nadere invulling van de cursus wordt via Canvas bekend gemaakt.


De colleges worden niet opgenomen.

Leerdoelen

Inzicht krijgen in de academische beoefening van filosofie en het vermogen ontwikkelen om in korte opdrachten de filosofische thematiek en importantie van verschillende films onder woorden te brengen.

Het opdoen van de basisvaardigheden van het schrijven van een filosofisch artikel.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Over the last decades, companies and investors have been increasingly challenged by risks due to unpredictable movements in stock prices, commodity prices, exchange rates, and interest rates. Financial markets have responded to this increase in volatility by developing a wide range of financial instruments known as derivatives, as well as strategies combining these products with traditional financial securities like stocks and bonds. As a result, derivatives markets have rapidly increased in volume and size and have become one of the most exciting areas in finance. However, the global financial crisis in 2007-2008 has made clear that derivatives can also create new risks when their design and limitations are poorly understood by market participants.  

This goal of this course is to help students navigating the complex and esoteric world of derivatives. It covers the essentials of key derivatives instruments, such as forwards, futures, swaps, and options. You will learn how these products work, how they are used for hedging and speculation, how they are priced using fundamental no-arbitrage principles, and how to exploit any mispricing using arbitrage strategies. You will apply this theoretical knowledge to solve practical assignments and case studies. The course fosters a deep analytical and conceptual understanding of derivatives and enhances your problem-solving skills. 

 
Entry requirements or required background knowledge
This course is intended for students with strong analytical skills and an interest in quantitative finance. Given the mathematical nature and advanced level of the course, students are strongly advised to enroll in this course only if they have passed all BSc courses in mathematics and the MSc F&I core courses Investments and Financial Modeling with a grade of at least 7.5.  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
At the end of this course, students should understand the structure of key derivatives instruments and should know how to price these products. They should also understand the use of derivatives for trading strategies, financial engineering, and hedging.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud Attending Turorial seminars is not compulsary, but making the assignments is. For this reason, attending Tutorial seminars is highly recommended. 

The lectures will be recorded.

Towards the end of the sixteenth century, the Aristotelian conception of the sciences seemed to have passed its expiry date. Many novatores in philosophy were inspired to develop methodological innovations in order to find new ways of coming to know more about nature, yet it was only in the work of René Descartes (1596-1650) that the “new philosophy” developed into a real alternative for the complete body of Aristotelian thought. Descartes’ mechanistic view of nature would prove fruitful in the field of natural philosophy and would inspire him to formulate a new metaphysical conception of man. In the hands of Benedictus de Spinoza (1632-1677), Descartes’ mechanistic approach came to affect questions of ethics and politics as well, leading to drastic changes in the interpretation of human mental life and human freedom.
Besides discussing Descartes and Spinoza, this course will sketch the broader historical context in which their work emerged, by focussing on humanist alternatives in ethics and politics, such as that of Hugo Grotius (1583-1645); alternative mechanistic philosophies, such as those of Galileo Galilei (1564-1642) and Thomas Hobbes (1588-1679); alternative metaphysics, such as those of Platonists and Occasionalists; and alternative methodologies, such as those of Isaac Newton (1643-1727) and Blaise Pascal (1623-1662). Leerdoelen At the end of the course, students will be able to specify the main differences between the metaphysical, natural philosophical, epistemological, anthropological and moral philosophical ideas dividing Descartes and Spinoza; to know how these compare to alternative seventeenth-century approaches in political philosophy, natural philosophy, metaphysics and scientific methodology; and to understand how Descartes’ and Spinoza’s positions relate to contemporary issues in philosophy.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
lecturers: ['dr. JJFM Bos', 'dr. P Rossini', 'prof.dr. JA van Ruler']
text:
Inhoud This course is part of cluster 3. Subjectivity and Response-Ability

Despite the persistence of major distortions and even caricatures of his standpoints in schoolbook representations as well as in the scholarly literature, Descartes’ philosophical views are still of great relevance for thinking about ourselves as social animals with conscious experience. In this course, we will engage in a fundamental revision and even a rehabilitation of Descartes’ views by interpreting them from the perspective of the seventeenth-century parting of ways between science and philosophy. Reviewing Descartes’ standpoints in their historical context, we shall be able to reassess their immediate social and cultural impact, as well as their long-term after-effects and their relevance for present-day science and philosophy. Besides contrasting the Cartesian concept of the self and its passions to the older, moral concept of reason, we shall deal with such diverse subjects as ealry-modern feminism and present-day cognitive science and neurology, in order to explain why the Cartesian turn was not about ‘metaphysical dualism’, nor about the ‘subject’, but about making room for real-life problem-solving away from metaphysics.

Attendance at lectures and seminars is mandatory. Missing more than one session without notice on legitimate grounds will involve an extra assignment to be made for every class missed. Leerdoelen At the end of this course, the student will be able to explain how Descartes’ method in philosophy may be explained as a break with the metaphysical past, to link this transformation in philosophy to the emergence of emancipatory views on human beings and their social behaviour, to explain the misconceptions surrounding Cartesianism in both analytical and continental traditions in philosophy as historical contingencies and to formulate a reasoned position on the ongoing significance of Descartes’ naturalist project for theories of consciousness in neuroscience and philosophy today.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description 
People often prepare long and detailed business plans when they want to implement new ideas. This takes a lot of time and resources and since customer preferences can change pretty quickly, a business plan might be obsolete by the time it is done. How can you approach innovation in a more flexible and agile way and develop innovations that are truly customer-centric? 

During this course, you will learn how to shift your mindset and embrace a different approach to developing new products, services and processes. Using design thinking to develop innovations will help you to see the value of an offering from a customer’s perspective. This structured approach means empathizing with the user to match their real needs, and stimulates creativity and innovation. You will learn to define, interpret, and reframe problems, and how to involve others in your project. You will focus on iterative solutions to get to a final product through prototyping and trial and error.  

Leerdoelen

Learning Objectives 
After this course, you will be able to: 

  • understand design thinking principles 
  • apply tools and techniques to empathize with customers and gain insights into their unmet needs and desires 
  • analyze a customer problem and, if necessary, reframe it 
  • understand various methods to generate ideas and select solutions 
  • create prototypes to gain rapid feedback and iterate your ideas 
  • understand how to facilitate a design thinking process in your team or organization

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['C Villegas Mejia, MA', 'dr. M Boffo', 'T Laure, MSc']
text:
Inhoud This course introduces the world of e-Health by describing what it is and how it can be used to promote healthy behaviors and improve health and wellbeing in several different areas, with a specific focus on digital behavior change interventions (DBCI). Through the presentation of case studies and examples of DBCI applications, the course will focus both theoretically and through practical work on the process of designing and implementing a DBCI. Spanning different contexts of application (e.g., primary prevention, lifestyle or mental health care interventions) and target user groups, the course will present a range of DBCI functionalities, such as online platforms, smartphone applications, or serious games, and showcase a set of design principles and frameworks that are crucial for the development of evidence-based and engaging digital interventions.
By reviewing synoptic and methodological articles on methods for developing and evaluating DBCIs, and reviews and empirical articles on design and application of DBCIs across different areas of health psychology and behavior change (such as, but not exclusively HIV and sex, addiction, obesity, stress, etc.), the students are stimulated to learn and practice all phases involved in the design of a DBCI, with a narrow focus on their role as (future) behavioral scientists working in digital behavior change.
Questions like “how can you align the design of a DBCI to the needs and skills of the target users?” and “how can you achieve sufficient levels of adoption and engagement with the DBCI?” are addressed. This course combines theoretical knowledge with practice. Building upon the knowledge on an established e-health design framework, students will start developing first-hand experience during workshops guided by professional designers and behavioral scientists, and unsupervised group work. As professionals in the world of digital behavior change, students will very often work in teams, therefore they need to be able to collaborate and work efficiently with others. Divided in groups, students will elaborate the concept design of their first low-fidelity (i.e., paper version) mini-DBCI addressing a specific behavior or problem for a target group of users. Leerdoelen

At the end of this course you will be able to...

  • Design a low-fidelity prototype of a mini-DBCI by making use of Behavior Change Techniques (BCTs), a user-centered design approach, and persuasive design elements:
    • Perform a problem and contextual analysis in order to identify the goal of the mini-DBCI, define the target group, propose appropriate BCTs and/or therapeutic principles to be included in the mini-DBCI.
    • Apply user-centered design techniques (e.g., create personas, use case scenarios or requirements) to match the intervention goals and technology of choice.
    • Sketch the concept design (e.g., low-fi prototype) of the mini-DBCI, including the proposed mechanics wrapping the chosen BCTs and/or therapeutic principles and the end-to-end user journey
    • Evaluate the user acceptance and feasibility of the concept design of your mini-DBCI with formative evaluation methods
  • Critically discuss decisions made in terms of content and design choices during the design process of the mini-DBCI
  • Present the concept design and the design process of the mini-DBCI as if you were presenting it to the relevant stakeholders
  • Critically evaluate the process and outcomes of the implementation of specific BCTs and/or therapeutic principles underlying the mini-DBCI
  • Discuss key aspects to consider in the potential implementation / evaluation plan of the mini-DBCI in its specific context
  • Critically evaluate the working process, communication skills and overall performance while working in a team

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['A Mehrdar, MSc', 'dr. AAM Abdelwahed, MBA', 'dr. T Kucukyilmaz', 'dr. Y Ghiassi-Farrokhfal']
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
This course and the accompanying reading materials aim to provide you with the knowledge and skills required for building information systems that drive business success. You will learn about the process of building modern information systems and about the requirements engineering, analysis, and design activities of software engineering. You will learn to identify stakeholders and requirements, to define the structure of an information system, to evaluate competing solutions for a business problem, and you will start to “speak business and IT”. You will gain insight into how important these activities are in creating information systems that are truly aligned with business needs. Throughout the course, you will also learn about selected topics in IT strategy and IT software project management. In your team project, you will develop the idea, the business justification, and the requirements for a novel business application.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
 
Objective 1: Software Development Processes
  • Remember what a system, a socio-technical system, and emergent system properties are
  • Explain the principal activities involved in systems engineering: requirements engineering, (problem) analysis, modeling, (solution) design, implementation, quality assurance, operation, maintenance, and related management activities
  • Explain the special nature of software-based systems in contrast to other technical systems
  • Produce a software business case for a self-selected software development effort
  • Understand the purpose of software development processes
  • Able to clarify under which circumstances the Waterfall model, the V model, the Spiral model, the Unified Process, the Incremental Model, or Prototyping, is most appropriate
 
Objective 2: Software Requirements
  • Explain the importance of requirements engineering within software engineering
  • Explain key challenges in and techniques for requirements discovery, development, analysis, communication, and validation
  • Apply the following techniques for requirements discovery: interviewing, scenario analysis, and use cases
  • Produce specifications of stakeholder requirements and system requirements, functional requirements, non-functional / performance requirements, and constraints using the most appropriate of the following representations: natural language, structured language, graphical specifications, mathematical specifications.
 
Objective 3: Software Design
  • Describe the purpose of requirements traceability and the tools used for establishing it
  • Describe the role of modeling in software engineering
  • Explain the notions of (object) classes, attributes, operations, cardinality / multiplicity, association, composition, and generalization and use them correctly in modeling stylized scenarios
  • Draw and critique structural models of a simple problem domain using Unified Modeling Language (UML) class diagrams
  • Draw and critique behavioral models of a simple problem domain using UML activity, state, use case and sequence diagrams
  • Analyze the unstructured description of a software development effort to distinguish between requirements and design ideas
  • Explain key concepts in good software design: abstraction, architecture, separation of concerns, modularity, refinement, refactoring, and low coupling / high cohesion
  • Explain the connection between design, requirements, and business value
  • Use Impact Estimation to calculate value-maximizing design decisions in a principled fashion
 
Objective 4: Value Based Software Engineering
  • Describe common problems in value creation through software projects, and the sources of these problems
  • Identify such problems in an unstructured description of a stylized development effort
  • Explain the roles of iterative approaches, of continuous learning and refinement, and of quantified performance requirements in value creation
  • Explain the characteristics of a good plan for a software development effort: putting planning before the plan, planning iteratively, continuous refinement, embracing change, and maintaining the connection with the business case
  • Apply fundamental estimation techniques for size and effort to the unstructured description of a software development effort: counting, calibration, and historical data, expert judgements
  • Explain the role of uncertainty in estimates for size and effort: the cone of uncertainty.
 
Objective 5: Agile Software Development Methods
  • Explain which software engineering methodology works best in which situation and what are the advantages and disadvantages of each method.
  • Understand the fundamentals of Agile software engineering and methods
  • Understand the basics of Scrum and Xtreme Programming, two commonly used Agile methods
  • Understand the differences between various Agile methods and evaluate the merits of each for a given software project.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Behaviour of participants involved in problem solving or service delivery is shaped and constrained by institutions: formal and informal rules, procedures, organization structures, shared outlooks and language. These institutions create a specific choice architecture, providing actors with mindsets and incentives that encourage certain behaviors and discourage other behavior. Given the conflicting perceptions and interests of actors, supportive institutional arrangement is crucial for successful collaboration.  Nobel prize laureate Oliver Williamson distinguishes 4 levels of institutions: culture, formal rules, interorganizational and organizational arrangements. Wicked problems and governance strategies to deal with them are transboundary: they cut across the existing demarcations between organizations, networks, administrative levels and territorial jurisdictions like municipalities, regions and countries. As a consequence, participants are confronted with institutional complexity: not only do they have to deal with legislation, procedures and organizational traditions that hinder collaboration, but other participates may be guided by other rules, outlooks and incentives, resulting in incompatibilities in strategies and suggested solutions. Dealing with wicked problems therefore requires reflection, analysis and anticipation of existing institutional choice architectures, and often institutional redesign. This course will present economic, historical, and sociological approaches to institutions and institutional design, thus providing a theoretical foundation for understanding the nature of institutions and institutional change, their influences on behavior and the implications for governance strategies trying to anticipate and influence the evolving choice architecture.  Also a conceptual framework for institutional analysis will be presented, building especially on the work of Elinor Ostrom on institutional rules and processes and principles of institutional design. In addition the normative implications and risks of institutional design will be discussed, acknowledging the importance of institutions as forms of social capital, the specific values that are at stake in institutional design and the limited governability of institutions and institutional reform. Leerdoelen Providing students with
  • insights in the role of institutions as choice architecture influencing problem solving, policy making and public service delivery in governance networks
  • knowledge on types of  institutions and institutional theories
  • an understanding of the principles, normative issues and risks underlying the functioning of institutions,  institutional design and institutional design processes

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. A Pisarevskaya', 'dr. FK Seiger', 'dr. W Belabas']
text:
Inhoud The thesis trajectory consists of two parts: ‘designing migration policy research’ and ‘thesis research’. During this course [designing migration policy research] the students learn about the design, methods and methodology of research on the border of public administration and migration students. Furthermore the students will develop their own research proposal and will learn to reflect and assess the formulation of a problem definition and research question; operationalisation of concepts into reliable and valid indicators; the selection of the appropriate methods of data collection and analysis and the formulation of a research design.
At the start of block 3, students will be matched with a supervisor, most likely one of the lecturers that taught the mandatory courses of the master program. This is coordinated by the GMD program directors and depends on the expertise and thesis-load of potential supervisors.
Students are only allowed to start with their actual thesis-research when their thesis proposal has been considered satisfactory by their supervisor. Once their proposal has been approved, students are allowed to conduct the research as detailed in their proposal, and report the findings of this research in their master thesis.
  Leerdoelen In the process of writing the thesis proposal the student learns:
  • to independently provide an overview of the existent literature on the chosen research field;
  • to independently apply public administration and migration theory to deduce hypotheses from, or to base qualitative expectations on, that will form the basis of the theoretical framework;
  • to independently develop a clearly defined theoretical framework;
  • to independently formulate and assess a theoretically and socially relevant problem definition and research question;
  • to individually operationalize and assess concepts into reliable and valid indicators;
  • to independently choose and assess the appropriate methods of data collection and analysis for the research design;
  • to independently develop and assess a theoretically and methodologically profound and feasible research design for the research question formulated;
  • to independently structure and reference a research proposal.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud In the course Designing Social Research, we identify and discuss various philosophical and methodological approaches to research: (1) large-n, quantitative, positivist approaches, (2) small-n, qualitative constructivist/interpretivist approaches, and (3) critical-theory approaches. Within each of these foundational approaches, we focus on the formulation of research questions, the role of ‘theory’, and the most important data gathering techniques like experiments, surveys, field studies, and unobtrusive methods. Furthermore, we address the issues of validity and reliability in research, and describe possible types of impacts of research on society.
  Leerdoelen After having successfully completed this course, students are able to:
  • Describe philosophical roots and manifestations of (1) large-n, quantitative, positivist approaches, (2) small-n, qualitative, constructivist/interpretivist approaches, and (3) critical-theory approaches to social science research endeavors;
  • Describe different study designs implied by various social science research approaches such as time series designs, (quasi-)experiments, surveys, field research, case studies, and unobtrusive designs;
  • Explain procedures for measurement, including the idea of validity and reliability;
  • Describe several modes for data analysis, including the elaboration paradigm;
  • Critically evaluate the quality of existing studies with respect to research approach, study design, data gathering and data analysis; 
  • Identify various ways in which academic research can have impact on society, and reflect on the ethical stance of researchers.
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Theory and theory development are seen as crucial to making meaningful academic contributions to bodies of knowledge in management and organizational research. Despite its prominence, the processes through which we theorize are often left implicit, and not typically discussed or taught in doctoral training programs. The course tries to address this very point; participants will through a series of exercises, practical assignments and readings be trained in ‘reading’ theory in journal articles, and will also develop skills in the development of theory as part of their own research.

(It is generally advised to take this course in your second year, so that you can learn optimally from this course.) Leerdoelen 1. To have a basic understanding of management and organizational theory; what theory is, and what its core components are.
2. To develop reflective skills in theory development; including basic argumentation and the formulation of propositions, construct clarity and persuasive writing.
3. To develop creative skills in developing theory through specific forms of reasoning such as conceptual blending and counter-factual reasoning.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
lecturers: ['dr. D. Jaarsma', 'E. Buitenhuis - Linssen', 'L.M.R. Nijs - de Langen']

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructors: Dr W. Janssens (VU), Prof. M. Pradhan (VU), Dr. Wouter Zant (VU)
 
Course content:
The course provides an advanced treatment of a number of core topics in Development Economics. In this course the following topics are covered:
  1. Global poverty and inequality trends and prospects
  2. Model-based imputation in welfare analysis
  3. Manufacturing as a development strategy
  4. Gender and development
  5. Productivity in agriculture
  6. Trade and transaction costs
  7. Technological fixes to development problems
Leerdoelen By the end of the course, students have gained knowledge and understanding of the economic principles underlying the core issues; have developed a good understanding of available empirical strategies to analyze these issues in practice and to have the ability to derive the policy implications from the theoretical and empirical analyses.

course_title: Development Policies and Practice: Interests, Conflicts and Cooperation
