college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)

course_title: Developmental Challenges and Deviations in early childhood
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
Wanneer een kind van 1 jaar begint te huilen wanneer zijn moeder uit zicht is, wordt dit bestempeld als normaal, leeftijdsadequaat gedrag. Wanneer een 5-jarig kind weigert naar school te gaan en alleen bij zijn ouders in bed wil slapen om maar zo dicht mogelijk bij zijn moeder te zijn, wordt het een heel ander verhaal… Wanneer maakt gedrag deel uit van ‘normale ontwikkeling’ en wanneer spreken we van ‘abnormaal gedrag’? Deze vraag is heel relevant voor psychologen in het werkveld van de klinische kinder- en jeugdpsychologie. In het tweede blok van de Master Klinische Kinder- en Jeugdpsychologie, zullen stoornissen die zich voordoen in de vroege kindertijd worden benaderd vanuit een ontwikkelingspsychologisch perspectief. Vanuit normale ontwikkeling en de ‘taken’ of uitdagingen die het kind daarbij tegenkomt, wordt gekeken naar deviaties in gedrag of emoties die op kunnen treden wanneer een kind deze ontwikkelingstaken niet goed doorloopt.
 
Het blok is een onderdeel van de eisen voor het behalen van de Basisaantekening Psychodiagnostiek van het Nederlands Instituut van Psychologen (NIP).
Leerdoelen Er is in dit blok veel aandacht voor ontwikkelingsprocessen en psychopathologie in voornamelijk de vroege kindertijd. Naast kennis over ontwikkelingstaken en daaraan gerelateerde stoornissen, vindt verdieping plaats t.a.v. specifieke populaties (bv. hechtingsproblemen bij kinderen van moeders met ernstige post-partum problematiek), omgevingsfactoren (bv. ouder-kind interactie bij peuters met een regulatiestoornis), of behandelingen (bv. gedragsmodificatie bij vroege voedingsproblemen).

course_title: Developmental Psychology: Challenges in Education and Development
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
Blok 2.7 gaat nader in belangrijke thema’s binnen de Ontwikkelings- & Onderwijspsychologie zoals nature versus nurture, continuïteit versus eindigheid en natuurlijke rijping versus actieve sturing. De verschillende facetten en fasen van de normale ontwikkeling van de kindertijd naar de (late) volwassenheid zullen worden bestudeerd. Immers, de ontwikkelingspsychologie beslaat niet alleen de vroegkinderlijke ontwikkeling maar ook de ontwikkeling van kind naar puber/adolescent en volwassene en zelfs de ontwikkelingen van de oudere mens. Ook de interactie tussen biologische determinanten van ontwikkeling en omgevingsdeterminanten zal worden belicht tijdens bijvoorbeeld de vroegkinderlijke ontwikkeling en de late volwassenheid. Aan de hand van problemen die in de onderwijsgroepen besproken worden en verdiepingscolleges zal inzicht verkregen worden in de wetenschappelijke stand van zaken betreffende fundamenteel en toegepast onderzoek en (empirische evidentie voor) theorieën binnen deze subdiscipline. Up to date kennis van dit vakgebied is tenslotte ook belangrijk om een geïnformeerde mening te vormen in maatschappelijke kwesties die vandaag de dag spelen zoals de effecten van kinderopvang op ontwikkeling, problemen tijdens de puberteit, ouders met een verstandelijke beperking etc.
Leerdoelen Kennis van Ontwikkelings - & Onderwijspsychologie is belangrijk voor al die sociaal wetenschappelijke professionals die beroepshalve te maken krijgen met kinderen en jeugdigen (in gezinnen, op school etc.) en een gedegen bijdrage willen leveren aan leer -en opvoedingspraktijken, zoals het begeleiden van (moeilijk) lerende kinderen en het uitbrengen van advies aan hun ouders en leerkrachten of om ernstig probleemgedrag te analyseren en een plan op te stellen voor een mogelijke, ethisch-verantwoorde interventie. Het doel van Blok 2.7 is het bieden van een verdere verdieping in de kinder- en jeugdpsychologie plus het geven van een algemene oriëntatie in de adolescentiepsychologie en de ontwikkeling naar volwassenheid en ouderdom. Specifiek wordt er van studenten verwacht dat ze na afloop van het blok: 1) een duidelijke beschrijving kunnen geven van de belangrijkste biologische, sociale en psychologische ontwikkelingen tijdens de kindertijd, adolescentie, volwassenheid en ouderdom; 2) een goed beeld hebben van biologische en omgevingsfactoren, en de interactie daartussen, die de ontwikkeling kunnen beïnvloeden; en 3) theorie, onderzoek en toepassingen kunnen evalueren op hun sterke en minder sterke punten. Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

course_title: Developmental Psychology: Global Challenges for the Developing Child
college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud Although development is an ongoing process throughout life, the focus of this course will be on the development of children. In this course, the main developmental theories (cognitive, emotional, social, moral) will be introduced.
You will also be confronted with different challenges that children all over the world experience while growing up. What role do media and technology play in the child’s development? What is the importance of cultural empowerment in explaining children’s development? What is the effect of child labour on children’s health and well-being?
The developmental theories and challenges will be debated in the context of three major themes in developmental psychology: nature vs. nurture, continuity vs. discontinuity, and universality vs. sociocultural context.

course_title: Deviantie en Criminaliteit in de Stad
college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud
Pedagogen kunnen in hun latere werkveld op verschillende wijzen te maken krijgen met jeugdcriminaliteit. In dit blok wordt daarom aandacht besteed aan probleemgedrag en criminaliteit onder jongeren in een multiculturele stedelijke context. Er wordt ingegaan op een scala aan verklaringen voor probleemgedrag en criminaliteit (van sociaalpsychologisch tot sociologisch en criminologisch), strafrechtelijke reacties van de overheid op criminaliteit, het integrale veiligheidsbeleid en op thema’s waar jongeren in een multiculturele stedelijke context mee in aanraking kunnen komen zoals geweld, drugs, migratie en integratieproblematiek.
Leerdoelen
Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:
  • de uiteenlopende verschijningsvormen van probleemgedrag en jeugdcriminaliteit in een multiculturele stedelijke context in relatie tot politieke, maatschappelijke en culturele ontwikkelingen te benoemen;
  • op basis van uiteenlopende sociaalwetenschappelijke theorieën het ontstaan en het voortduren van probleemgedrag en criminaliteit van jongeren te verklaren;
  • deze sociaalwetenschappelijke theorieën op een zinvolle wijze op actuele vraagstukken van jeugdcriminaliteit en probleemgedrag toe te passen;
  • mogelijkheden voor preventie, screening en interventies (en de effectiviteit) van het integraal veiligheidsbeleid ten aanzien van jeugdcriminaliteit te beschrijven en te begrijpen onder welke omstandigheden voor specifieke vormen van interventie wordt gekozen.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['B van Gent, MSc', 'dr. AP Ringoot', 'dr. R Kok']
text:
Inhoud
In dit blok wordt de complexe werkelijkheid van het diagnostisch proces geïllustreerd aan de hand van casuïstiek, waarin verschillende typen ontwikkelingsproblemen aan bod komen en er aandacht is voor de context waarin de problemen zijn ontstaan en waarin de diagnostiek moet plaatsvinden. Gecombineerd met het practicum waarin verschillende diagnostische instrumenten worden behandeld wordt het diagnostisch traject voor verschillende casussen doorlopen. Omdat de ontwikkeling van elk kind anders verloopt, dus ook bij kinderen met een ontwikkelingsprobleem, wordt van je verwacht dat je de vergaarde kennis van de afgelopen jaren, gecombineerd met de kennis die je in dit blok opdoet gedurende de werkgroepen, het practicum en de colleges, kunt combineren om zo tot onderkennende, verklarende en/of indicerende hypothesen te komen voor de specifieke kinderen. Het is namelijk van belang dat er geleerd wordt hoe een diagnose/hypothese tot stand komt zodat je na deze studie zelf in staat bent het volledige diagnostisch proces te doorlopen bij kinderen met ontwikkelingsproblematiek. Je moet daarom leren hoe je problematiek bij het kind in het kader van omgevingsinvloeden, culturele invloeden, genderverschillen en leeftijdskenmerken moet bezien en tot een afgewogen diagnose kan komen die kan leiden tot handelingsgerichte adviezen.
Leerdoelen
Aan het eind van dit blok:
  • heb je kennis van  het proces van diagnostiek van kinderen, al dan niet met een verstandelijke beperking; het beloop van (lage) intelligentie door de jaren heen, comorbiditeit van gedragsproblemen, invloed van ouders en culturele diversiteit
    (intended learning outcomes 1, 2, 3 en 4)
  • heb je kennis van effecten van gender- en cultuurverschillen en kun je de diagnostiek en daarmee samenhangende opvoeding en problematiek van het betreffende kind benaderen vanuit de zienswijze van de ouder met bijbehorende culturele gedachten gangen
    (intended learning outcomes 1, 2, 3 en 4)
  • heb je kennis van het proces van diagnostiek bij jonge kinderen waarbij sprake is van psychopathologie; het belang van ontwikkelingsleeftijd, stabiliteit van diagnoses, meetinstrumenten, dynamisch testen en het kind in zijn (culturele) context
    (intended learning outcomes 1, 2, 3 en 4)
  • heb je kennis van de invloed van ouders met psychische problemen op het ontstaan van gedragsproblemen bij kinderen; op welke wijze kan dit in kaart worden gebracht en hoe kijken verschillende culturen tegen psychopathologie aan
    (intended learning outcomes 1, 2, 3 en 4)
  • kun je de verschillende fasen van de diagnostische cyclus in de praktijk doorlopen en keuzes die hierbij gemaakt worden kritisch beschouwen
    (intended learning outcomes 3, 7-14)
  • heb je kennis van ethische dilemma’s bij diagnostiek en leer je op basis van kennis en ethiek welke beslissingen juist (kunnen) zijn
    (intended learning outcomes 2 en 3)

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. NK Schoemaker', 'drs. S de Goeij - van Bedijk']
text:
Inhoud
Dit practicum bouwt voort op eerdere Testvaardigheden (1.4, 1.5, 3.4) en Gespreksvaardigheden (1.6, 2.1) practica, waarin studenten basisvaardigheden hebben opgedaan met betrekking tot de afname, rapportage en terugkoppeling van een psychodiagnostisch onderzoek. In dit practicum maken studenten kennis met het diagnostische proces in de praktijk en zal er voortgebouwd worden op de reeds verworven vaardigheden.
 
Leerdoelen
Na afronding van dit practicum hebben studenten:
  • Kennis van en inzicht in het doorlopen van de verschillende stappen (intake tot en met advies) van de diagnostische cyclus (eindterm 3);
  • Vaardigheden ontwikkeld voor het opstellen en toetsen van diagnostische hypothesen en het kunnen nemen van beslissingen ten aanzien van de te nemen stappen in een diagnostische procedure, rekening houdend met de verschillen tussen cliënten (i.e. gender, leeftijd, culturele diversiteit) (eindtermen 8, 9 en 10);
  • Vaardigheden opgedaan om diagnostische middelen (observatie, interview) en instrumenten (tests, vragenlijsten) te herkennen, te selecteren, te scoren en te interpreteren (eindterm 9 en 13);
  • Vaardigheden opgedaan om onderdelen van de diagnostische cyclus (klachtanalyse, probleemanalyse, diagnostisch perspectief, toetsing en diagnostische conclusie) te doorlopen en schriftelijk vast te leggen volgens de richtlijnen die gelden voor de NVO Basisaantekening Diagnostiek (eindtermen 7, 9 en 12);
  • De student is in staat om kritisch te reflecteren op het eigen handelen en professioneel om te gaan met collega's, cliënten en hun systeem (eindtermen 7 en 14);
  • De student is zich bewust van de ethische dilemma’s en het belang van een beroepscode tijdens het diagnostisch proces (eindtermen 7 en 12);
  • De student leert hoe het is om te werken in een team (eindterm 11).
 
De student is in staat om zonder instructie en met enige begeleiding (onderdeel schrijfonderwijs):
  • Een professionele schrijfstijl toe te passen en deze af te stemmen op een specifieke doelgroep (e.g. kinderen, ouders, leerkrachten en andere professionals);
  • Een (gedeeltelijke) casusbeschrijving conform NVO-richtlijnen betreffende de Basisaantekening Diagnostiek te schrijven;
  • Toetsbare hypothesen op te stellen en deze wetenschappelijk te onderbouwen.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud

What if our current mode of existence stems from a world populated not with things but with forces, not with subjects but with powers, not with bodies but

with functions? In other words, while humans have been good at tracing metric and measurable properties such as lengths, heights, and depths, can they become equally capable of mapping intensive relations? The purpose of this module is to get attuned to the relational space of perception, memory and attention. The exercise will comprise a cartography of tendencies that are probed, discovered and scrutinised in movement, as an entanglement of action and perception. The output (a compilation of GIFs) aims to prove that relations can be directly perceived, thus pointing to a new way of diagramming (architectural) reality. The students will work in groups of max. 3 and will be asked to produce a compilation of 3 different GIFs according to their statement in 2 regarding the relation between action and perception. In addition, they should prepare a caption for each GIF, as well as a short text where they express their statement and the logics behind it. The students are asked to present their GIFs and other material in the end of the workshop in 10 min. presentations, which include peer feedback.
Day 1: photographing/site visits
Day 2: production
Day 3: presentation

Leerdoelen

Upon completion of the three modules, the students will have:

o Acquired the academic skills for thinking, reading, presenting, and collaborating in an inclusive and transdisciplinary manner, in particular a sensibility for problems at the interface of architecture and philosophy;

o Acquired a conceptual toolbox for thinking in terms of relations and speculative-interactive design;

o Learned to apply contemporary ideas and debates in a dynamic urban setting in engaged, responsible, and non-reactive ways; Acquired or developed basic (technical) design skills while contributing to ecological literacy.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['AM Kloc, MSc', 'dr. A Priante', 'dr. D Tsekouras', 'prof.dr. T Li']
text:
Inhoud

Course overview 

Digital transformation is affecting all organizations. Some are well ahead in going digital, many just got started or were forced to do so. Such a digital disruption has created three large challenges: (1) understanding what technologies are relevant, which ones will be developed and how to leverage their value, (b) changing the way of thinking in terms of strategic decisions, as there is a difference between being digitized and being digital, and (c) having access to all the available data, but also being able to convert them to meaningful information which can lead to impactful decisions. At the same time, consumers are becoming increasingly knowledgeable and demanding, and interact with firms in many ways. These consumers require the formation of tailored value creation systems to better match their needs. Therefore, digital strategies are shifting from traditional product-centric to a customer-centric approach. Many industries struggle to adapt to these changes, with their business models being disrupted by new, agile competitors with innovative business models. 

In this course, we focus on Digital Business and discuss the differences between digitizing business operations, and truly becoming a digital business. We analyze different digital business models and strategies to leverage value across various channels (online, offline, mobile). We also investigate how digital businesses use the information they can receive from customers across the different stages of the customer journeys. Further, we explore various digital governance models and discuss the importance of IT security and privacy in the context of digital business. Last, we focus on the future opportunities and challenges of digital business, in terms of technology, business models, and management practices. 

The course is offered by the Business Information Management group of RSM’s Department of Technology and Operations Management. 

Leerdoelen

Learning Goals 

The first goal of the course is to provide students with a better understanding of how firms, consumers and employees are impacted by the evolution of digital technologies and how understanding their impact can be leveraged to their advantage. For instance, how companies can use the digital technologies to interact with the consumers in order to provide a greater value for both sides. Emerging channels and IT-enabled systems that can be used for these different interactions receive special attention. The second goal of the course is to learn about the opportunities and challenges that the digital reality presents and to understand how they require different governance and planning.  


After successful completion of this course, students will reach the following objectives: 

  • Discuss the evolution of digital technologies and current technological trends. 
  • Understand and analyze the challenges that digitization brings to organizations. 
  • Analyze digital business models and identify their strengths and weaknesses. 
  • Understand how firms can acquire, target and engage with digital consumers. 
  • Evaluate how technologies can be used to create societal and business impact. 
  • Recognize the future challenges of digital business. 


At the end of this course, students will also acquire or improve their skills in the following areas: 

  • Analytical and critical thinking. 
  • Problem identification and problem solving. 
  • Working in groups, teamwork, and group dynamics.

course_title: Digital Citizens and Communities - Applied user-baed topics
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. A Paz Alencar', 'dr. D Trottier', 'dr. JF Ferreira Goncalves', 'dr. M Tulin', 'Q Huang']
text:
Inhoud

Digital media continue to shape how individuals and communities perform specific activities, and fulfill social roles. Proponents claim that new platforms help us become informed, stay safe, and even get employed. Yet users also experience a range of frustrations, vulnerabilities and harms as a result of our dependence on mobile devices, social platforms and algorithms that manage our lives. This course focuses on user-led practices in a range of personal and professional contexts. Case studies will be attuned to the types of positions students may seek on the job market, as well as the kinds of political causes that may inform their advocacy. Students will engage with academic and practical perspectives in a variety of fields that involve user-led forms of digital practice, such as citizen science, whistleblowing, digital activism and open-source coding initiatives.

Leerdoelen

Students have knowledge and understanding of

  • The cultural and institutional contexts in which user-led digital technologies are adopted by individuals
  • Theoretical concepts that help explain and make sense of user-led practices
  • How public discourse shapes the perceived acceptability and desirability of emerging practices

Students have developed the skills to:

  • Apply concepts related to digital media, citizenship and communities to specific case studies;
  • Critically evaluate citizen driven uses of digital technologies;
  • Create original research ideas related to current challenges in digital components of civic engagement and communities.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. IM Derda', 'dr. SMR Driessen', 'P Mashigo, MA', 'RS Rocha, MSc', 'S Lambrechts']
text:
Inhoud For most of us, digital content is omnipresent in our lives: we consume it daily, but also produce it regularly. Posting a photo on Instagram, writing a review on Amazon, watching a video on YouTube, listening to a podcast, or reading the course description online: these are some everyday forms through which we engage with, consume, and produce digital content.
 
In this course, we take a look behind the scenes of digital content. Students will analyse how and what role digital content plays in the field of media and communication. In eight weeks, students will explore and reflect upon strategies and practices like digital storytelling, and various aspects of digital marketing. This theoretical foundation equips students to apply their knowledge to analyse various case studies. Moreover, students will put these theoretical insights to the test by working on a case of digital content creation themselves.

 
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • ·The key developments and trends in and of digital content as a communication practice
  • ·Critical perspectives and theories on digital content, media ethics and media literacy
  • ·The relevance of digital content in the field of media and communication
  • ·The various strategies and roles digital content can take within the field of media and communication

Students have developed skills to:
  • ·Apply relevant theoretical insights to analyse digital content
  • ·Critically reflect on existing digital content, in both verbal and written form
  • ·Design and create digital content for a particular audience or stakeholder(s)
  • ·Work in international and intercultural teams to evaluate and ameliorate a digital content case

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Many choices are made in digital environments, however, not only the sheer number of choices but also their presentation may influence our decisions and distort us, because we have only limited cognitive capacities to cope with lots of choices. In this course, we will focus on digital decisions, made in digital environments such as websites or apps, with emphasis on how these decisions deviate from rational and/or ethical standards. Understanding how digital environments influence our choices can help to improve our decision-making. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
As part of this course, students will learn how websites influence our choices and how we can improve digital decision-making. Through practical, hands-on assignments, we will discuss:
  • Heuristics in digital decision-making
  • Biases in digital decision-making
  • Emotions in digital decision-making
  • Designing choices in digital environments
  • Digital experimentation
  • Digital A/B testing

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Consumers use various technologies in their everyday life, such as mobile applications, internet browsers, social networks, and wearables. In doing so, consumers leave a digital footprint - a stream of data that describes their online activities. Sometimes, they explicitly share content with other people (e.g. social networks, forums) or have direct communication with a company (e.g. online customer service). Data that consumers intentionally submit online is defined as active digital footprint. At the same time, consumers also leave a passive digital footprint: their search history, the news they read online, the location and time when they use a device. Both active and passive digital footprints can reveal consumer attitudes, interests, and preferences. This brings numerous opportunities and challenges for companies, consumers, and public policy makers. 

This course discusses the benefits and risks associated with the use of digital footprints for marketeers, consumers, and policy makers. Brand managers can use detailed consumer level data to gain better insights about their target group and to adapt their communication and branding strategies accordingly. At the same time, consumers and policy makers are becoming more concerned about how digital footprints are collected and used. This course will help you develop an in-depth understanding of ethical issues related to digital footprints and measures that can mitigate such risks (e.g., the EU General Data Protection Regulation). 

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
Students who actively participate in all sessions and successfully complete their assignments will be able to: 
  • Understand and explain the importance of digital footprints for consumers, policy, and businesses. 
  • Identify strengths and weaknesses in how companies handle consumer data. 
  • Recognize potential ethical issues related to digital footprints. 
  • Understand and explain implications of the GDPR for the EU marketplace. 
  • Provide managerial and policy recommendations.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['E Demir, LL.M', 'mr. KP Prifti', 'mr. MR Remmerswaal', 'prof.dr. EF Stamhuis, LLM', 'prof.dr. K Heine']
text:
Inhoud Digitalisering krijgt een nieuwe, soms disruptieve impuls met de opkomst van kunstmatige intelligentie en big data. De vraag naar een goede inbedding in de samenleving met behulp van het recht is opnieuw actueel en op allerhande terreinen aan de orde. Het keuzevak Digital Governance behandelt enkele van de belangrijkste juridisch-politieke thema's. Gedacht wordt aan
  1. actorschap en autonome machines,
  2. eigendom,
  3. privacy,
  4. industrie en technologiereuzen,
  5. democratie.
In het leerproces worden de studenten uitgedaagd om in interactie met elkaar de vragen te concretiseren en oplossingen te ontwerpen. Voor materiaalproductie en presentaties zal worden samengewerkt met het Jean Monnet Centre of Excellence Digital Governance. De voertaal is Nederlands, maar van de studenten wordt verwacht dat zij gastcolleges in het Engels kunnen volgen en dan kunnen deelnemen aan een gedachtewisseling in het Engels. Leerdoelen Na voltooiing van deze cursus:
  • Heeft de student een middenniveau van kennis van de fenomenen AI en Big Data en de (potentieel disruptieve) maatschappelijke gevolgen daarvan.
  • Heeft de student inzicht in een aantal juridisch-politiek centrale thema’s voor digitalisering, in het bijzonder onder invloed van AI  en Big Data en de stand van de regulering.
  • Heeft de student inzicht in de doctrinair juridische en rechtseconomische afwegingen bij de relevante reguleringsvraagstukken.
  • Kan een student in haar/zijn eigen discipline een beperkt onderzoek uitvoeren op een van de thema’s en daarvan mondeling en schriftelijk verslag doen.
  • Kan de student een verbinding maken tussen zijn reeds voltooide studieonderdelen en governance van digitalisering.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The launch of social media platforms and smartphones in the mid-2000s have dramatically changed how marketers engage with their customers. Businesses have undergone a paradigm shift in which consumers play a much more active role in the communication and branding of a product/service. Consumers are no longer passive receivers of information; they are empowered initiators and co-creators of marketing communication and campaigns. They can strengthen brand equity by being brand ambassadors spreading the word about products across global social media networks. However, they also have the power to undermine and destroy a brand if it goes against their values. In this new volatile market environment, companies must continually rethink and adapt their strategies and tactics, working closely with consumers and other stakeholders in communicating their brand and value proposition.

This digital age also affords a lot of opportunities for businesses. Consumers are now closely interacting with social media platforms, streaming services, and apps for several hours a day, and business have an opportunity to study each individual consumer’s behaviour and decision-making processes. They can therefore personalise their services, so they meet the exact needs of the consumer, who are also customising their customer experiences to their specific preferences. The digital age has thus facilitated a very close and intimate relationship between consumer and businesses.

This course takes a multidisciplinary approach to the topic of digital marketing and is thus for students who are interested in subjects such as marketing, branding, social media, strategy, consumer behaviour, storytelling, co-creation, apps and online shopping. The course provides valuable insights which helps students prepare for a career in business and marketing.

In this course, we will examine the challenges, opportunities, and trends of digital marketing with the help of case studies, videos and guest speakers. We are looking closely into the behaviour of the digitally savvy consumers who are actively co-creating with brands across various social media platforms, apps, online shops and streaming services and we are exploring the strategies of marketers in engaging with these consumers, for instance, through storytelling and influencer marketing. Leerdoelen Students gain knowledge and understanding of:
  • The digital marketing strategies and tactics of businesses
  • Consumer behaviour in the digital age through marketing research
  • Branding and co-creation in social media
  • The digital servicescape and online shopping

Students have developed the skills to:
  • Demonstrate an understanding of the impacts of digital marketing and social media in creating value propositions for customers.
  • Recognise and appreciate the role of consumers as co-marketers and co-producers in digital marketing.
  • Develop skills in using and integrating new media and digital technologies in creating and implementing marketing strategies.
  • Critically assess marketing campaigns and strategies across digital platforms.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

The emergence of internet has drastically changed various aspects of a firm's operations. Some traditional marketing strategies are now outdated or deeply transformed, and firms increasingly rely on new media to acquire customers. In light of this, in this course we will discuss digital marketing strategy, implementation, and practice.

Leerdoelen
  • Explain the role and importance of digital marketing in a rapidly changing business envrionment
  • Discuss the key elements of a digital marketing strategy
  • Illustrate how the effectiveness of a digital marketing campaign can be measured
  • Demonstrate practical skills in common digital marketing tools such as

SEO, SEM, Social media, and Google Analytics.

Extra There will be 3 assignments that count for 30, 30 and 40%; one of the assignments is a group assignment; two assignments are individual
The first assignment is a group assignment in which you have to build your own webshop
The second assignment involves creating a strategy for a brand to become less dependent on Google and Facebook
The third assignment will be announced during the course

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
The development of practice and research in marketing is always accompanied by advancement in technologies. From 1921 when Queensboro Corporation paid for the first radio commercial to 2015 when Oreo used “#RedVelvetOreo” to promote its new cookie flavor on Twitter, technologies have exerted profound influence on how marketers connect with consumers. The technological advancements bring forth new opportunities while posing unprecedented challenges for marketers. This course balances the strategy and tactic side of digital marketing by not only examining how to develop digital marketing strategies to increase shareholder value and sustain competitive advantage but also creating hands-on experiences with different digital marketing tools. With a systematic approach, we will explore various managerial problems such as how to design a website and drive traffic, how to optimize search engine efforts, how to purchase inventory for online display advertising, and how to allocate budget to different online communication channels. With these discussions, this course aims to shape your perspective as a digital marketing leader. 
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
  • Understand how digital marketing strategies fit with overall marketing and/or media strategy;
  • Learn to formulate and implement a digital marketing strategy, calculate digital marketing effort and ROI;
  • Understand the major digital marketing tools: web development and analytics, search engine marketing, mobile marketing and email marketing;
  • Learn how to perform web analytics, carry out keywords bidding, and purchase inventory for online display advertising.  
  • Understand digital marketing landscape and marketing in ever-evolving digital age.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Digital media affects many tasks in organizational life. The communication with both clients and colleagues is dominated by e-mail communication either handled from a personal computer or on the move by using mobile devices. This not only affects the work domain, but also the home domain since many employees stay connected (24/7 availability) to their work even during leisure time. 
Virtual teams support international collaborations with the direct consequence that expert input in projects has become time and place independent. The globalization has encouraged this development, in that new media have made the access to talent and knowledge more attainable and financially affordable. This also demands for new leadership styles that are adapted to the increased physical distance and mediated communication between leader and followers.
Finally, when an employee decides it is time to make a next move on the labor market the chances that a webcam test is part of the selection procedure is significant. Companies try to make their selections methods more objective by using serious games as a selection tool as well. Online assessments have become part of the selection procedure and the chances that you really make a first impression during your job interview have decreased dramatically.
In other words, the impact of digital media on organizational life is evident and goes beyond simply facilitating our work. The new innovations in technology have really changed the way we work. Leerdoelen

At the end of this course, the student…

1.  has profound knowledge in the domains of how communication technology changed our work-home interface;
2. has profound knowledge in the domain of mediated collaboration in virtual teams;
3. has profound knowledge on the impact of social media and personnel selection and gamification in online assessments;
4. realizes the importance of empirical evidence for effectiveness of all constructs that are common practice in the work field;
5. has developed a meta-cognitive view on the topics included in this course and is able to critically read and integrate the literature;
6. is able to apply the theoretical concepts discussed in this course to issues in the workplace. This can result in a theoretically funded advise for organizations;
7. knows how to evaluate claims made in popular press and realizes that empirically sound is not the same as valuable in practice and vice versa.

Belangrijk om te weten Both lectures and tutorial meetings are in English.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. JS Lee', 'dr. L Zheng', 'dr. M Tulin']
text:
Inhoud It is often rightly noted that people have more and easier access to information than ever before, and that there is more media created today (often by media users and audiences) than at any point
in history. This vast and diverse media content offers an incredible opportunity, but also challenge, to media analysts. Some of the most difficult questions facing media research concern not only how to properly identify critically important media texts, but also how to collect and make sense of patterns that can be observed within and across media. Here, students will be provided scientific and industry-leading methodological tools in order to carry out these tasks, particularly in social media environments.
The human and computer-assisted approaches for digital media analysis blend qualitative and quantitative techniques. In conjunction with real-world and practical modules, this course opens doors for students to apply innovative and groundbreaking analytic techniques that can contribute to shaping the future directions of media research. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding  of:
  • Digital media analysis and their applicability in the field of media and communication.
  • Research designs and measuring instruments for the analysis media.
  • Practical considerations necessary for digital media analysis, for example the concepts and issues surrounding the collection of online data and their management.
Students have the ability to:
  • Propose appropriate methods to meet particular research needs.
  • Collect and analyze data from social media (Twitter, Facebook, YouTube), and news (LexisNexis) on topics of their choice.
  • Present digital research in clear, novel and engaging ways, orally and in writing.
  • Perform basic text analysis, topic modeling, sentiment analysis, and network analysis.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In today’s increasingly competitive attention economy it is of vital importance for digital media organisations to connect with their consumers to constantly adjust and improve their content, services, and business models. In order to successfully build and maintain relationships with their target groups, organisations first need to understand the contemporary consumer (e.g. motivations behind decision-making processes). For instance, what makes the consumer come back for more? What relationships emerge between an organisation and the consumer, but also between consumers (e.g. communities, collective intelligence)? When do her preferences change and why? How can we understand the underlying dynamics and contributing factors?
 
In this course, we will approach consumer culture from a cognitive science and sociology perspective and explore definitions and theories that deepen our understanding of the phenomenon. This also includes a critical look at the role of data-driven technologies in this context (e.g. how data inform organisations about their target groups).
 
This course focuses on relevant case studies from the news media industry. This sector experiences profound transformations triggered by the disruptive impact of digital technologies on journalistic practices and news consumption behaviour(s). Daily operations in newsrooms are shaped by digital technology: how they create, curate, and distribute their “content”, how they build their business models, as well as how they engage with the news audience.
 
The course aims to bridge the macro-level approach to digital transformation with the micro-level approach to user experience, participation and engagement. At the end of this course, students are expected to combine academic knowledge with creative thinking in an advice to a news media organisation. Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding  of:
  • What the digital transformation is and how it changes media organisations;
  • Consumer participation and the trends that shape it;
  • The relationship between media organisations and their consumers.
 
Students have developed skills to:
  • Critically assess organisational change in the media sector;
  • Apply scientific and empirical approaches to analyse the selected case studies;
  • Formulate evidence-based advice to media organisations.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Digital media are increasingly present in people’s everyday life. The proliferation of smartphones and Internet connections results in social interactions often based on digital communication, which modify and – sometimes – replace face-to-face discussions. This has an impact on how individuals and communities frame and express their cultural identities. Therefore, identity becomes a frequently discussed topic on social media and other Internet venues, involving characteristics such as gender, sexuality, religion, political affiliation, (dis)ability, ethnicity and race. Digital spaces can both help people to affirm and diffuse cultural identities within mainstream culture, and become tools for discrimination and hate speech against certain identity groups. By exploring different digital media platforms –such as Twitter, Facebook, blogs, You Tube –this class will discuss how cultural identities change, evolve, and are negotiated on the Internet. Students will analyze international case studies connected to digital media and cultural identities, such as the #MeToo and #BlackLivesMatter campaigns, the diffusion of online Islamophobia and Anti-Semitism, and Internet narratives about LGBTQ+ rights and same-sex unions.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • How the articulation of cultural identities affects and impacts digital media use in contemporary societies
  • How the current proliferation of digital media offers new venues for both affirming and marginalizing identity groups
  • How current academic perspectives on digital media allow exploring people' online self‐representations
 
Students are able to:
  • Critically reflect upon the role of media in relation to cultural identities, analyzing both positive and negative representations
  • Independently relate the academic concepts covered in the course to novel examples within today’s digital media landscape
  • Apply academic theories to case studies that illustrate the development and negotiation of cultural identities online

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud As digital media become ubiquitous, they affect how we circulate information about health. The changes are multi-folded: (1) organisations are now more connected to their clients and, then, have to provide accessible venues for communication; (2) patients are not only connected to organisations, but also to each other, circulating information and creating narratives without the need of a mediator; and (3) the hyperconnected society provides different social constructions that shape health communication. These digital practices concern citizens and researchers interested in the health arena, as well as professionals in the field of communication who aspire to work for healthcare industries. Those in the field have now to understand the impacts of digital media on how they will posit themselves and produce discourse, mainly by adapting to a society that is actively exchanging health information online.
  Leerdoelen Students have gained knowledge and understanding of:
  • Main theories connected to health communication and their adaptation to online environments
  • The flows of information about health online
  • The different actors and possibilities concerning online health communication
  • How organisations can adapt to this scenario and what is the role of a professional in the media and communication sector
  • The benefits and drawbacks related to online health communication

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['D Kourelis', 'dr. D Trottier', 'dr. HJCJ Hitters', 'dr. I Awad Cherit', 'dr. JF Ferreira Goncalves', 'dr. JS Lee', 'dr. V Chaudhri']
text:
Inhoud This is a course that requires basic familiarity with qualitative and quantitative social sciences research methods. Technical proficiency in any particular digital analysis method or tool is not a prerequisite. However, a willingness to experiment with digital technologies that, due to their novelty, will not always work as expected is necessary to succeed in the course. Most business research happens in teams, so this course will include a group research project in addition to individual work. After completion of this course, students will be able to gather and analyze digital data for future projects using appropriate methodologies and tools.

The course provides an introduction into the different aspects of researching the digital. It is not exhaustive; comprehensive coverage of the material would require multiple courses. Instead, students will acquire a feel for methods and tools of research as well as where to look for them in the digital world. This is crucial within the program of media and communication, where in other courses as well as in the thesis, students have to be able to choose and use different tools and methods in their own research.

Via lectures and interactive hands-on workshops, students will become acquainted with theoretical concepts and scholarly debates surrounding digital research methods combined with a hands-on approach of dealing with data. Bringing in topics such as information visualization and design also sheds light on other important aspects of research: how and in what form to communicate outcomes?

  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • Digital research methods and their applicability in the field of media and communication.
  • Research designs and measuring instruments for social media analysis.
  • Practical considerations necessary for social media analysis, for example the concepts and issues surrounding the collection of online data and their management.
Students have the ability to:                                                     
  • Propose appropriate methods to meet particular research needs.
  • Collect and analyze data from social media (Twitter, Facebook, YouTube) and news (LexisNexis) on topics of their choice.
  • Present digital research in clear, novel and engaging ways, orally and in writing.
  • Perform basic text analysis, topic modeling, sentiment analysis, and network analysis.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
In the last decades, the unprecedent growth of digital technologies has led to a rapid decline in the cost of storage, computation, and transmission of data. It deeply impacted firm internal business processes and external interactions with other businesses, consumers, policy makers. The aim of this course is to learn how digital transformation reshapes key strategic domains of firms, including internal processes, competition, value creation and innovation. One of the areas disrupted by digital transformation is supply chain management. The new operating model for purchasing and supply management, known as Procurement 4.0 will be thoroughly addressed as well as the new role of purchaser in the organization. 

In this course, we will discuss the core changes brought by digital transformation and the new approaches actively adopted by firms to stay competitive, such as artificial intelligence and data-driven decision making. We will address the following questions: How do new business models emerge as a consequence of digitalization? How do traditional businesses adapt to the markets disrupted by digital entrants? What is the impact of this transformation on supply chains and what are the resulting challenges in sourcing, inventory management, distribution and product returns? How can businesses leverage the power of data for enabling new ways of addressing customer needs and operational efficiency and competing their rivals?

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
In this course, we will learn how digital transformation affects business strategies of firms and their supply chains and how it can lead to emergence of the new business models, such as online platforms and omnichannel. We will discuss what digital transformation entails in terms of data and analytics and how business strategies and supply chain benefit and change as a result of this. After this course, students will: 
  • Understand how businesses are affected by digital transformation 
  • Use the main concepts of digital transformation literature to analyze digital strategies of firms 
  • Understand the challenges of digital transformation on the organization of supply chains and how to cope with them in practice  
  • Analyze the data from large digital businesses and propose solutions to their business problems

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Digital technologies are implicated in emerging developments, but also reflecting longstanding practices and patterns in social organising. This course addresses theoretical and conceptual matters in relation to the uptake and social impact of digital media technologies. It encompasses an exploration into theoretical understandings of new forms of information and communication technologies (ICTs) and how these theoretical understandings shape responses and perspectives. To engage with how digitalisation mutually shapes social practice and is shaped by them, the course focuses attention on particular artefacts and examples to increase understanding and applicability. As such, students learn to apply key theoretical framings and concepts pertaining to study of digital media studies, with an eye to particular social and political contexts in which these are manifest. This accounts for key conceptual frameworks that provide occasionally divergent accounts of digital media in society.

The course focuses on providing a toolbox approach to the circumstances surrounding contemporary digitalisation processes, equipping students with the critical skills necessary to assess current technological change and anticipate (responses to) forthcoming transitions. Within the course, the first half will focus on building the understandings of various theoretical perspectives and how these approaches shape our understandings and direct our responses. After this this, the latter half of the course will add more specific theoretical perspectives and add a focus on key digitalisation contexts (work, media, marketing) and more specific artefacts of digitalisation (social media apps, mobile phones, IoT devices, environmental sensors). Leerdoelen

Students have knowledge and understanding of:

  • How digitalisation processes have amplified and accelerated both beneficial and detrimental social practices;
  • Theoretical perspectives related to understanding information and communication technologies and their implications within contemporary life.

Students have developed the skills to

  • Contextualise digitalisation within various social, economic, and political circumstances;
  • Articulate theoretical approaches and the focus such approaches create and conceal in relation to understandings of digitalisation practices and developments;
  • Effectively apply theoretical understandings to empirical contexts or artefacts related to technology and digitisation.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. F Grommé', 'prof.dr. CL ter Hoeven', 'prof.dr. F Koster']
text:
Inhoud

Digitalisation is often accompanied by claims about a ‘new industrial revolution’. Yet, we also know that technologies often perpetuate existing patterns of organisation and associated inequalities. In this course we will have closer look at how digitalisation affects work, organisation and governance.

Each week, we will discuss the dynamics of digitalisation on a different level of analysis, including surveillance on the workfloor, online activism, the changing nature of corporations and the historical continuities behind labour casualisation. You will be invited to compare and contrast theories and empirical insights from organisational sociology, public administration, digital sociology and science and technology studies. Running through the course are the questions of how we shape technologies and their effects, and how we can imagine and accomplish change.

We will start from the idea that technologies such as data analytics, sensors and algorithms can shape organisations and organisational processes. But how digital technologies are applied also is an outcome of institutional arrangements, politics, cultures and identities. Our focus will be on developing analytical and methodological skills needed to understand and assess the different dynamics associated with digitalisation.

Such analytical skills are increasingly relevant for policy, corporate and activist practitioners confronted with developments such as automated decision making or the disruptive effects of platforms. But digitalisation also means we need to develop and adjust our own practices and methods. How to do research on organisations and events that (partly) take place online? What are the possibilities and ethics of doing this type of research? We will find this out by conducting a method experiment.

Leerdoelen
  1. Compare theories about technology and society from (digital) sociology, public administration and science and technology studies.
  2. Develop theoretically informed standpoints on the social and political implications of previous and future technological transformations of work and organisation, based on the course literature and independent literature research.
  3. Evaluate propositions for policy or organisational change using theories about technology and society from the course literature.
  4. Develop basic digital methods attuned to researching the digitalisation of organisations and organisational processes.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['mr. GT Terpstra', 'mr. W Scherpenisse', 'prof.dr. EF Stamhuis, LLM']
text:
Inhoud “Videobeelden campus EUR verkocht aan commerciële partner”. Stel dat je dit bericht in je newsfeed leest. Of: “Proctoring data toegankelijk voor overheidsdiensten”. Zou dat niet meteen je belangstelling wekken (en misschien ook je haren rechtop doen staan)? Met deze headlines zitten we volop in het veld van dataprotectie en privacy.

Vandaag de dag wordt de positie van de individuele burger of een bedrijf niet alleen bepaald door het handelen of beslissen van overheden. Het beleid, de acties en de beslissingen van private en hybride actoren hebben evenzeer grote invloed op de levens van mensen. Dit brengt ons bij de vraag in welke mate de rechtsnormen en beginselen variëren. Met de ontwikkeling van regels en beginselen die voor zowel publieke als private actoren gelden, is getracht te voorzien in een passend normenkader. Daarmee wordt de klassieke scheiding tussen publiekrecht en privaatrecht gerelativeerd. Wetten en beginselen die de scheiding tussen publiek en privaat overstijgen, waren al te zien voordat de digitalisering inzette (denk aan de horizontale werking van grondrechten), maar in deze ontwikkeling krijgen ze extra gewicht. Digitalisering kan nieuwe mogelijkheden bieden om de waarden in het recht te bevorderen, maar brengt ook behoorlijke risico’s met zich mee, onverschillig of dat in het publieke of private domein valt. Daarom is het recht inzake dataprotectie een zeer geschikt onderwerp om de overstijging van rechtsdomeinen te bestuderen.

In deze cursus brengen we je in contact met een set van normen en beginselen, waarin het onderscheid tussen publiek en privaat naar de achtergrond gedrongen is: de regulering van data-gedreven, algoritme-gestuurd handelen en beslissen in publieke en private organisaties. Aan dit belangrijke onderwerp is tot nu toe in de Bachelor Rechtsgeleerdheid en de Master Staats- en bestuursrecht nagenoeg geen aandacht besteed. Deze regulering heeft echter grote gevolgen voor de manier waarop een bedrijf, ziekenhuis of universiteit gerund wordt en lokale en nationale gemeenschappen worden bestuurd. De centrale regeling in de Algemene Verordening Gegevensbescherming zal veel aandacht krijgen, evenals het risico van discriminatie in, of door geautomatiseerde besluitvorming. Ook de praktijk van toezicht en handhaving komt aan de orde.

Er zijn onderwijsbijeenkomsten met docenten met bijzondere expertise voorzien, met aandacht voor praktijksituaties (clinics). Het onderwijs in dit vak wordt deels in het Nederlands en deels in het Engels aangeboden. Dat geldt ook voor de literatuur. Voor de toetsing is gekozen voor een eindtoets met open vragen.


  Leerdoelen Studenten beschikken na afloop van deze cursus over:
 
  • Kennis van het relevante normenkader rond vraagstukken van privacy, gegevensbescherming en data-gestuurd handelen.
  • Inzicht in stand van zaken en ontwikkelingen rond het gebruik van data-gedreven en/of algoritme-gestuurd handelen en beslissen door publieke en private organisaties.
  • Inzicht in regulerings- en handhavingsvraagstukken met betrekking tot data-gedreven en/of algoritme-gestuurd handelen en beslissen door publieke en private organisaties; i.h.b. het risico van systeem bias en discriminatie.
  • Vaardigheid in het toepassen van relevante juridische normenkaders op praktijkvraagstukken rond privacy en gegevensbescherming en non-discriminatie, met toepassing van de verschillende perspectieven in de praktijk: data verwerker, individu, toezichthouder.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['D de Kleer, MA', 'dr. BCM Kester', 'dr. PC Ruigrok', 'dr. RA Harder']
text:
Inhoud Het mediagebruik van Nederlanders is aan het veranderen en dit betekent ook dat ze op andere manieren nieuws tot zich nemen. Dit heeft grote gevolgen voor de journalistiek. Processen van commercialisering en popularisering, maar ook nieuwe technieken, e-technologie en de permanente mogelijkheid via ‘mobile devices’ media-uitingen te volgen en daar interactief aan deel te nemen, hebben de (politieke) informatievoorziening – en daarmee ook de opiniestructuur – drastisch gewijzigd. Door sociale media loopt de interactie tussen mensen online en offline steeds meer door elkaar heen en begint die grens te vervagen. Die veranderingen gaan niet bij iedereen even snel. Er is duidelijk sprake van voorlopers en volgers en de vraag is hoe die verschillen te verklaren zijn en wat de gevolgen zijn van verschillen in digitale vaardigheden en online levensstijlen. Wat verandert er in de levens van burgers ten aanzien van onder meer sociale contacten, vrijetijdsbesteding en cultuurparticipatie? In het seminar wordt veel empirisch onderzoek dat inzicht geeft in de Nederlandse situatie behandeld. 
  Leerdoelen Je maakt kennis met veel nieuwe concepten en als sommige concepten je al bekend zijn uit vorige cursussen dan leer je je daar verder in te verdiepen, ze met elkaar te verbinden en bij complexere vragen toe te passen en eventueel te operationaliseren voor onderzoek.

Je ontwikkelt kennis van en inzicht in:
  • de belangrijkste theorieën rondom digital journalism en een netwerksamenleving;
  • de relatie tussen theoretische (journalistieke) concepten en de dagelijkse nieuwspraktijk
  • wetenschappelijk onderzoek over (aspecten van) digital journalism en de netwerksamenleving.
  • Je leert (mondeling en schriftelijk) te reflecteren en een visie te ontwikkelen op de huidige ontwikkelingen binnen de journalistiek en de toekomst van de journalistiek.
  • Je leert werken met (veel) data en dat om te zetten tot een interessant artikel voor een medium.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Many scholars identify a shift from government to governance. Governments find themselves in situations where they need to govern in horizontal relations and are more dependent on a wide array of non-profit and for-profit organizations to achieve their aims. Problem-solving takes place in complex networks of for- profit, non-profit and governmental organizations.

In this course we extensively look at what governance actually means and what the consequences are of this shift from government to governance. The course especially focuses on a number dilemmas related to the shift toward governance when governments try to solve complex social problems:

1.         Effective governance; How to achieve effective actions in complex governance networks. Effective governance networks require connectedness between actors, issues and arenas but it is not so easy to achieve as  confirmed by the now vast literature on governance. Governance processes are characterized by complexity and this makes it hard to achieve good results. It requires extensive network management and linking of various interests and values of the actors and thus good connective skills of managers.

2.         Democratic governance; Networks do have a strong horizontal character in which societal actors receive influence on important decisions. This character sometimes sharply conflicts with the classical representational institutions. How to deal with the tensions between representative democracy and elements of participative democracy in networks is an important governance dilemma. The course will address questions of democratic decision-making, in particular how it relates to governance networks;

3.            Accountable governance; how to handle the fact that in governance networks many actors are responsible and thus accountable. Is it true as some authors claim that networks blur existing accountability and not only ‘no one is in charge’ but also no ‘one is responsible’. And if not what accountability mechanisms are at place in networks? Leerdoelen Providing students with
  • Knowledge of modern theories of governance that have emerged the last 15 years

  • Ability to recognize assumptions and theoretical arguments in these theories and relate them to (wicked) policy problems

  • Ability to critically reflect on the assumptions of governance theories

  • Capability to analyze governance processes and wicked policy problems with these theories

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud Bij Direct Tax Assurance and Technology gaat het om het herkennen, begeleiden en beheersen van fiscale processen en risico’s als onderdeel van de totale bedrijfsvoering en bedrijfsstrategie en om de inzet van nieuwe technologieën daarbij.
Van een incident-gedreven en fiscaaltechnische aanpak naar een (nog) meer procesmatige en risicogerichte benadering om te bereiken dat de organisatie (zoveel mogelijk) in control is met betrekking tot de fiscale positie en inzicht heeft in alle mogelijke fiscale risico's betreffende de bedrijfsvoering. Leerdoelen Na het volgen van dit vak is de student:
  • op de hoogte van de ontwikkelingen en laatste stand van zaken omtrent tax assurance & technology
  • in staat om fiscale processen omtrent directe belastingen en de fiscale risico’s die daarmee gepaard gaan, in kaart te brengen
  • bekend met de systematiek van de digitale technologie die kan worden gebruikt bij de fiscale risicoselectie en risicobeheersing ten aanzien van directe belastingen en in staat in praktijkgerichte cases te beoordelen welke technologie ingezet kan worden
  • op de hoogte van ethische leerstukken en hoe die in de fiscaliteit toepassing kunnen vinden en hoe deze de fiscale werksfeer kunnen beïnvloeden. Tevens is de student in staat om daarin zelfstandig een positie te bepalen.

college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
lecturers: ['dr. F Mukhtarov', 'dr. HM Hintjens', 'dr. S Heumann', 'prof.dr. D Gasper']

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Great challenges, of economic, environmental and technical nature, are posed on companies in producing and delivering goods on demand, on the spot, right when and where customers demand them. Since production systems usually cannot follow the demand fluctuations instantaneously, distribution systems are required to bridge temporal and geographical gaps, and the gap in scale between production and consumption. The activities and decisions to be managed in such distribution systems are manifold and include distribution network design, the planning and managing of inventories deployed throughout the networks, linking sources and destinations through transportation, achieving coordination in channels. The rise of online retail and increasing urbanization poses new challenges in the last-mile and city logistics.    

This course focuses on the analysis, planning, and organization of these activities. The analysis, planning, and organization of decisions and activities in distribution is a daunting task in its own right. The task is compounded by the dynamics in the business context such as globalization and the rapid proliferation of applications of information and communication technology. Contributions from several fields have shaped today’s vision on how to master the challenges of fulfilment of customer demand. This course takes an analytical perspective on how to organize for performance of distribution networks. It captures key factors in quantitative models, which it then analyzes, thereby uncovering important trade-offs and performance drivers in distribution networks. 

Leerdoelen

Learning Objectives
Upon finishing this course a student is able to 

  • Name and motivate the key decisions, drivers of performance, and trade-offs in the design of distribution networks. 
  • Translate practical problems related to the design and operation of distribution networks into quantitative models. 
  • Select and apply the most appropriate quantitative methods and software tools to help analyze and design distribution networks. 
  • Formulate clear recommendations and conclusions based on the modeling and analysis of distribution networks. 
  • Students can generate relevant insights based on quantitative models that use incomplete, inaccurate or uncertain input data.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

A force driving change in our society is diversity. Marketingwise, segmentation has become a struggle due the never ending diversity in target markets. Culture, gender, income, LHTB, religion, …. But also due to age.
The demographic earthquake called aging has created the biggest market segment ever. This requires all organisations to reconsider their current strategies. Many more mature consumers with different needs than younger consumers or similar needs but a different way of converting these into wants.
The course discusses the changes in emotion and cognition that occur due to aging, and which lead to the Seven Soft Spots of Aging. To identify these Soft Spots, we have to know the customer’s life story. We have to understand the fall and winter seasons of life and how life in these stages differs from the lives of younger people, living in the spring and summer seasons. Insights in academic studies on aging will be synthesised and applied to real life to create, spread and realise the right value proposition for the mature consumer.
Part of the course is a team assignment about hospitality in elderlycare. Besides mature marketing, you will be getting to know more about hospitality and the experience economy. And the marketingimplicaties for eldely.
This earthquake called aging has an enormous impact on any organisation. So it’s time for a wake-up call! In the course, be inspired about this huge market segment and by looking into the heart and mind of these consumers. And what this implies marketing wise. And you might realise after the course that “Beautiful young people are an accident nature, beautiful old people a work of art

Leerdoelen

To learn about the relevance of diversity of marketing and how to develop a Grey Ocean / agewise marketing strategy

Extra The lessons will be online.

course_title: Diversity and Inclusion in Strategic Communication
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['dr. AC Uribe Sandoval', 'dr. J Hofhuis', 'dr. V Chaudhri']
text:
Inhoud
The management of diversity and inclusion (e.g. how to deal with differences in culture, race, gender, age, sexual orientation) has become one of the major challenges of the modern workplace. Organizations can take different approaches to this issue, and many successful (and less successful) examples exist of how these are represented in strategic communication, such as websites, (job) advertisements, and annual reports. The first section of this course will familiarize students with the state-of-the art literature on this topic.
 
Next, students join forces and design and conduct a quantitative study that examines how diversity and inclusion are represented in organizational communication and how it may affect employees, job candidates or (potential) customers. Data collection will be done collectively, but each student chooses their own specific subtopic.
 
This research workshop enables students to gain hands-on experience with quantitative methods and analyses (e.g. quantitative content analysis, survey or experimental research). Two meetings are SPSS-sessions, which will actively guide students through the data analysis and interpretation phase. Results are presented in class, through group presentations, as well as in the final product, which is a short individual research paper.
 
Note: Working experience with SPSS is desirable, but not compulsory.
 
Leerdoelen  Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • State-of-the-art theory on organizational perspectives regarding diversity and inclusion
  • How these perspectives are communicated by organizations
  • Common research designs and methods to examine these communications
 
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Design and execute a small scale empirical study using quantitative methods
  • Report on their findings in oral and written form
  • Critically reflect on the limitations and the possible societal implications of their research
  • Evaluate their own work and others’ research work

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. BB de Koning', 'dr. D Jansen', 'prof.dr. SE Severiens']
text:
Inhoud This course discusses the situation of teachers and trainers in urban contexts, serving classrooms with students from a large variety of socioeconomic and ethnic/cultural backgrounds. Processes in the diverse classroom and training settings are considered from a social psychological perspective (micro), from a learning and instruction perspective (micro) and from a school improvement perspective (meso). The starting point of the course will be recent patterns of migration, the ever growing diversity (super-diversity) in urban areas related to equity issues.
In project 1 social psychological phenomena during learning such as the role of stereotypes, teacher expectations and intergroup contact theory will be studied. In project 2 the focus will be on instruction in diverse classrooms and training settings and the role of variation and differentiation. In project 3, psychological needs of students according to the self-determination theory and cultural responsive teaching will be studied. Finally, in project 4, innovations in the urban context and the role of teachers in school development will be the main topic.   Leerdoelen At the end of this course you will be able to:
  • Describe, compare and critique the main theories on stereotypes, teacher expectations and intergroup contact in the diverse classroom and training settings.
  • Describe, compare and critique the main theories on variation and differentiation in classrooms and training settings with students from diverse backgrounds.
  • Describe, compare and critique the main theories on psychological needs in education and cultural response teaching and training.
  • Describe and evaluate key factors of organizing schools for improvement in an urban setting.
  • Apply evidence-based coaching techniques and qualitative research methods in a concrete setting
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus School of Law

course_title: Dood en letsel: voorkomen, vergoeden en vergelden
college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['mr. FM Ruitenbeek - Bart', 'mr. LM Stroo', 'mr. M de Groot', 'mr. MR Hebly', 'prof.mr. SD Lindenbergh']
text:
Inhoud
Vanuit veel wetenschappen is het nodige te zeggen over de vraag wanneer dood en letsel voorkomen, vergoed of vergolden moet worden. In deze verbredende minor brengen we deze inzichten bijeen, laten verschillende (gast)docenten hun licht er over schijnen, brengen we studenten aan de praat over de multidisciplinariteit van het onderwerp en confronteren we elkaar met tal van dilemma’s.
Leerdoelen De student kan na afloop van dit vak:
  • De centrale begrippen, de systematiek en de grondslagen van het aansprakelijkheids- en schadevergoedingsrecht grondig beschrijven en analyseren
  • Inzichten vanuit verschillende wetenschappen (rechtswetenschappen, rechtseconomie, rechtspsychologie en gezondheidswetenschappen) over het voorkomen, vergoeden en/of vergelden van dood en letsel beschrijven, analyseren en betrekken in zijn eigen oordeelsvorming over het recht en de verschillende dilemma’s die dood en letsel met zich brengen
  • Inzichten uit de beroepspraktijk over het voorkomen, vergoeden en/of vergelden van dood en letsel beschrijven, analyseren en betrekken in zijn eigen oordeelsvorming over het recht en de verschillende dilemma’s die dood en letsel met zich brengen
  • Wetenschappelijke literatuur, rechtspraak en wetgeving kritisch bestuderen, zich daarover een oordeel vormen en dit kort en bondig onder woorden brengen

college: Erasmus MC Academie
Language and Training Centre (LTC)
text:
Inhoud

Een cursus Nederlands bestaat uit tien wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 2,5 uur. Het afsluitende examen vindt na afloop van de cursus plaats op een vooraf vastgestelde datum (zie onderstaande planning). Aan het einde van de cursus is de stof van één cursusniveau behandeld. 

Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Nederlands A1?

Tijdens deze cursus leer je de basis van de Nederlandse taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, schrijven en spreken in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen
 die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

  • jezelf voorstellen;
  • begroeten en afscheid nemen van mensen;
  • afspraak maken;
  • café, markt, restaurant en kledingzaak;
  • grammatica;
  • vocabulaire;
  • de Nederlandse cultuur.
Leerdoelen Aan het einde van de cursus beschik je over een bescheiden woordenschat zodat je in veelvoorkomende en alledaagse situaties kunt communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is A1 volgens het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR). Belangrijk om te weten
  • Let op: sommige groepen worden online aangeboden en sommige zijn op de campus.
  • Het Language & Training Centre organiseert driemaal per jaar cursussen Nederlands (oktober-december / januari-maart / april-juni). 
  • Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
  • De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Nederlands gesproken.
  • Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 43,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. 
  • In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
  • Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
  • De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 16 deelnemers. Bij online cursussen is het maximum 15 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.
  • Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.
  • De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
  • Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.
  • Lees ook onze voorwaarden.

college: Language and Training Centre (LTC)
text:
Inhoud

Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Nederlands?

Tijdens deze cursus leer je de basis van de Nederlandse taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op luisteren en communicatie in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

  • Jezelf voorstellen en persoonlijke voorkeuren vertellen;
  • Eten bestellen en winkelen;
  • Een afspraak maken en de tijd/kalender lezen;
  • De weg wijzen, uitleggen wat je hebt gedaan.

Door deze praktijkgevallen leer je:

  • Basis grammatica, woordenschat en uitdrukkingen;
  • Mondelinge communicatie en schrijf- en leesvaardigheden in het Nederlands;
  • Nederlandse cultuur en persoonlijke vaardigheden.

Tijdens de lessen word je geacht actief deel te nemen aan de conversatie- en mondelinge opdrachten. Je leert tevens hoe je een korte tekst moet schrijven.

Leerdoelen De cursus Nederlands voor beginners A1+A2.1 is een dubbele cursus: aan het eind van het traject is de stof van twee cursusniveaus behandeld. De cursus bestaat dan ook uit 20 lessen van 2,5 uur. Voordeel is dat je tussendoor geen examen hoeft te doen. Je stroomt dus automatisch door van niveau A1 naar niveau A2.1. Belangrijk om te weten
  • Let op: sommige groepen worden online aangeboden en sommige zijn op de campus.
  • Het Language & Training Centre organiseert driemaal per jaar cursussen Nederlands (oktober-december / januari-maart / april-juni). 
  • Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
  • De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Nederlands gesproken.
  • Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 43,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. 
  • In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
  • Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
  • De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 16 deelnemers. Bij online cursussen is het maximum 15 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.
  • Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.
  • De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
  • Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.
  • Lees ook onze voorwaarden.
Data en tijden

 

Maandagen 17.30-20.00 uur
Data: 17 januari 2022 - 16 juni 2022
Locatie: Online via Zoom
Examendatum: Week 25
