college: Language and Training Centre (LTC)
text:
Inhoud

Wil je graag de Nederlandse taal leren maar heb je gedurende het jaar nooit tijd? Of vind je een 10-weekse cursus te lang? Dan is deze cursus wat voor jou! Tijdens de zomercursus Nederlands voor beginners leer je in 2 weken wat je anders in 10 weken leert.

Deze cursus bestaat uit tien dagelijkse bijeenkomsten van 3 uur. Het afsluitende examen vindt plaats op de laatste dag van de cursus. Aan het einde van de cursus is de stof van één cursusniveau behandeld.

Wat leer je tijdens de online cursus zomercursus Nederlands?

Tijdens deze cursus leer je de basis van de Nederlandse taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, schrijven en spreken in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

  • uitspraak;
  • jezelf voorstellen;
  • begroeten en afscheid nemen van mensen;
  • afspraak maken;
  • praten over je familie;
  • café, markt, restaurant en kledingzaak;
  • grammatica;
  • vocabulaire;
  • de Nederlandse cultuur.
Leerdoelen Aan het einde van de cursus beschik je over een bescheiden woordenschat zodat je in veelvoorkomende en alledaagse situaties kunt communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is A1 volgens het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR). Belangrijk om te weten
  • Deze cursus vindt plaats van maandag 1 t/m vrijdag 12 augustus 2022. (online)
  • Deze cursus is alleen toegankelijk voor studenten van ESSB.
  • Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
  • De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Nederlands gesproken.
  • Het cursusmateriaal is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details. Let op bij de speciale kortingsregeling is het cursusmateriaal (e-book) wel inbegrepen.
  • Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de dagelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per dag aan zelfstudie besteden.
  • De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 10 en maximaal 16 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 10 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.
  • Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.
  • De mondelinge en luistervaardigheden wordt getoetst op vrijdag 12 augustus tussen 10.00 en 12.00 uur. Het afsluitende schriftelijke examen, waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst, vindt plaats op vrijdag 12 augustus van 14.00-15.30. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
  • Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.
  • Lees ook onze voorwaarden.
Data en tijden

Maandag 1 t/m vrijdag 12 augustus 2022 (Online)

  • Tijd: 10.00-13.15 uur (inclusief 15 minuten pauze)
  • Locatie: Online via Zoom
  • Examen: Vrijdag 12 augustus 2022
Let op! Voor Duitstaligen is er een speciale zomercursus Nederlands A1-A2.1

text:

In deze cursus behandel je de leerstof die hoort bij niveau A1 en niveau A2.1. 

Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Nederlands A1& A2.1?

  • Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
  • De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 16 deelnemers. Bij online cursussen is het maximum 15 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.
  • Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.
  • De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
  • Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.
  • Lees ook onze voorwaarden.

college: Language and Training Centre (LTC)
text:
Inhoud

Deze cursus bestaat uit tien wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 2,5 uur. Het afsluitende examen vindt na afloop van de cursus plaats op een vooraf vastgestelde datum (zie onderstaande planning). Aan het einde van de cursus is de stof van één cursusniveau behandeld. 

Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Nederlands A2.1?

Deze cursus is een vervolg op de cursus Nederlands A1. Tijdens deze cursus bouw je verder op de eerder geleerde onderwerpen van de Nederlands taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, schrijven en spreken in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

  • makelaar, huisarts, fietsenmaker, verjaardag;
  • grammatica;
  • vocabulaire;
  • de Nederlandse cultuur.
Leerdoelen Aan het einde van de cursus beschik je over een bescheiden woordenschat zodat je in veelvoorkomende en alledaagse situaties kunt communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is A2.1 volgens het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR). Belangrijk om te weten
  • Let op: sommige groepen worden online aangeboden en sommige zijn op de campus.
  • Het Language & Training Centre organiseert driemaal per jaar cursussen Nederlands (oktober-december / januari-maart / april-juni)
  • Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
  • De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Nederlands gesproken.
  • De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels.
  • Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 43,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
  • Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drieuur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
  • De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 16 deelnemers. Bij online cursussen is het maximum 15 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.
  • Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste lesvindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnenslagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.
  • De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
  • Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.
  • Lees ook onze voorwaarden.

text:
Inhoud

Deze cursus bestaat uit tien wekelijkse bijeenkomsten van 3 uur. Het afsluitende examen vindt na afloop van de cursus plaats op een vooraf vastgestelde datum (zie onderstaande planning). Aan het einde van de cursus is de stof van één cursusniveau behandeld.

Wat leer je tijdens de cursus Nederlands B1.1?

Deze cursus is een vervolg op de cursus Nederlands A2.2. Tijdens deze cursus bouw je verder op de eerder geleerde onderwerpen van de Nederlandse taal, waarbij de nadruk ligt op de vaardigheden lezen, luisteren, schrijven en spreken in een alledaagse context. Onderwerpen die aan bod komen zijn bijvoorbeeld:

  • werk, studie, onderwijs en vrije tijd;
  • reizen;
  • gevoelens;
  • grammatica;
  • vocabulaire;
  • de Nederlandse cultuur.

In deze cursus wordt je woordenschat aanzienlijk vergroot zodat je op een hoger niveau leert communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is B1.1 volgens het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR).

Leerdoelen In deze cursus wordt je woordenschat aanzienlijk vergroot zodat je op een hoger niveau leert communiceren. Het eindniveau van de cursus is B1.1 volgens het Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR). Belangrijk om te weten

  • Het Language & Training Centre organiseert driemaal per jaar cursussen Nederlands (oktober-december / januari-maart / april-juni).
  • Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
  • De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Nederlands gesproken.
  • Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 45,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
  • Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
  • De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 15 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.
  • Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.
  • De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
  • Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.
  • Lees ook onze voorwaarden.

  • Deze cursus is toegankelijk voor cursisten met een academische achtergrond (hbo/wo).
  • De steuntaal van deze cursus is Engels. In de lessen wordt echter zoveel mogelijk Nederlands gesproken.
  • Het cursusmateriaal kost ± € 45,- en is niet bij de cursusprijs inbegrepen. In de bevestigingsbrief die je ontvangt als de cursus doorgaat, informeren we je over de details.
  • Van de deelnemers wordt verwacht dat zij naast de wekelijkse contacturen ongeveer drie uur per week aan zelfstudie besteden.
  • De groepen zijn klein: minimaal 12 en maximaal 15 deelnemers. Let op! Bij minder dan 12 inschrijvingen behoudt het LTC het recht om de cursus te annuleren.
  • Aanwezigheid bij de lessen is niet verplicht, wel raadzaam. Let op! Tijdens de laatste les vindt er een mondelinge toets en een luistertoets plaats. Om voor de cursus te kunnen slagen, dien je dan aanwezig te zijn.
  • De cursus wordt afgesloten met een schriftelijk examen waarin de lees- en schrijfvaardigheid wordt getoetst. Met dyslexie kun je extra tijd krijgen voor dit examen. Vergeet niet om je dyslexieverklaring met je verzoek naar ltc@eur.nl te sturen.
  • Je ontvangt een certificaat als je de cursus afsluit met een 'pass' voor alle vier de vaardigheden.
  • Lees ook onze voorwaarden.
Data en tijden Dinsdagen 17.30-20.30 uur

course_title: Dutch History in a Globalizing World
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['BC Fici, MA', 'dr. JW Schaap', 'dr. PJBJ van den Heede', 'dr. Y van Hoef']
text:
Inhoud In this course, an overview is given of the Dutch history from the medieval period until the present time. Not just what is the specifically Dutch will be discussed, but also how Dutch history fits in a European and global context. During its history, and especially in the 19th and 20th century, the Netherlands has increasingly become a normal Western country. The early Dutch history – the time of the revolt and the Republic – is relevant because Dutch developments of the era had major cultural, economic and political influence on the rest of Europe and even the world. At the other hand, Dutch history of the nineteenth and twentieth century can be seen as an example for the way in which Western European countries, all with their own variations, developed into rich countries with a good social system and a high degree of individual freedom. At the same time it will become clear that these countries – and certainly a small country like the Netherlands – lost most of their global significance with the decolonization, the rapid economic growth elsewhere in the world, and the shift in the geographic distribution of the population.
Students understand the broad outlines of the Dutch history from the medieval period in a European and global context. They can explain the 16th century Dutch Rebellion as a pluralistic struggle of various groups and interpret the Republic as a civil society. They understand the position of the Netherlands as a colonial power in the perspective of Western imperialism. They can also explain why and how in the 19th and 20th centuries the Netherlands developed into a normal, small western country with characteristic movements such like liberalism, democracy, secularization and multiculturalism.

course_title: Dutch law and Dutch Legal Culture in a Comparative Perspective
college: Erasmus School of Law
text:
Inhoud The course introduces the participating students to the main characteristics of the Dutch legal system and its legal culture.
The focus of the course is twofold. First, the students are provided with an overview of the general principles of the core areas of Dutch law, i.e. constitutional law, administrative law, criminal law and private law. Second, the focus is on the background and context of the Dutch legal system, based on the assumption that a good understanding of a particular legal system includes an understanding of its legal culture.

To achieve this, the course will address typical (legal) institutions and procedures, such as the administration of justice, including the court system, and the legislative procedure. In addition, court annexed mediation will be discussed in the light of the pursuit of more efficient and better performing courts and the European Mediation Directive.
The general approach of the course is comparative by situating the Dutch legal system in its European context and relating it to other legal systems and legal cultures. By comparing a particular legal system, i.e. the Dutch legal system, with other legal systems its typical characteristics will become (more) evident.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. JA Joosse - Bil, MSc', 'dr. PK Marks', 'dr. WAH Spekkink']
text:
Inhoud De huidige bestuurskundige praktijk wordt gekenmerkt door een confrontatie met vraagstukken die systemisch van aard zijn zoals fileproblematiek, klimaatverandering, veiligheid en stedelijke ontwikkeling. Deze issues vragen om interventies in een complex geheel van relaties tussen publieke en private partijen, sociale en fysieke infrastructuren en natuurlijke ecosystemen. In deze module analyseren we verschillende aspecten van systemen, zoals toeval, stabiliteit, en de relatie tussen de individu en het collectief. We maken daarbij gebruik van evolutionaire theorieën, communicatietheorieën, economische theorieën en gedragstheorieën.

De studenten bereiden de colleges voor door voorafgaand een position paper te schrijven over de leerstof van dat college. Tijdens het college wordt van de studenten gevraagd om hun positie te presenteren en te verdedigen. Door middel van discussie tussen studenten en docenten proberen we beter te begrijpen wat de theorie betekent en tegelijkertijd te ontdekken wat onze eigen veronderstellingen zijn. De position papers worden beoordeeld en maken deel uit van het eindcijfer. Leerdoelen Na afloop van deze module kan de student:
  • verschillende theoretische benaderingen van dynamiek in complexe systemen beoordelen
  • dynamiek in complexe systemen vanuit verschillende benaderingen analyseren
  • een onderbouwd en beargumenteerd standpunt innemen
  • reflecteren op de persoonlijke leercurve door een vergelijking te maken tussen de aannames en opvattingen aan het begin van de collegereeks en in de eindsituatie

course_title: ECs waived in the framework of the Double Degree with The University of Economics Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam (UEH)
college: International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud The EFR Involve Consultancy project distinguishes itself from the other EFR's initiatives by its social and research focused approach. In the programme, twenty students apply their academic knowledge to practice and make a sustainable impact on communities that need it the most. This is done in partnership with an NGO or social enterprise and under the supervision of the course coordinator. Both sides will guide and assist the students in setting up their research. This project consists of four months of desk research (April-July), 2 to 3 weeks of field research abroad (August) and a final presentation for the partner (September).
Below are a couple of topics the students worked on the past years:
  • Clean drinking water in Cameroon
  • Sustainable energy in Ghana
  • Youth unemployment in Uganda
  • A sustainable relation between nature and people in Kenya
  • Independent radio in Nepal and Indonesia
  • Female empowerment in Peru
Leerdoelen
  • Work professionally with a partner organization;
  • Manage a research project;
  • Combine information from different sources into a coherent picture of local circumstances in a developing country;
  • Select relevant information about the context (such as socioeconomic circumstances, market access, institutional and financial contexts);
  • Design feasible business plans that takes intro account the local context and skills and needs of the local population;
  • Reflect on strategies to overcome challenges of building business in unfamiliar and poorly developed markets.

  Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Changes in examination. Different partner, so different questions. Extra For extra information, you can visit the EFR website: www.efr.nl/education/involve-consultancy-project; or send an email to involve@efr.nl.
There will be no re-examination.

Inhoud This course involves seminars by EIPE graduate students, as well as external speakers, on state-of-the-art debates in philosophy and economics.

Students are expected to attend all research and PhD seminars. In respect of PhD seminars, they are also expected to chair and comment at least once, in addition to presenting their own work at least once. They will receive a pass/fail grade on that basis. Leerdoelen To educate graduate students in research. Through the seminars, research master students and the EIPE community are acquainted with the most recent research in the field of philosophy and economics.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. M Campo Comba, LLM', 'prof.mr. MH van der Woude']
text:
Inhoud

The course ‘EU Competition law’ looks at anticompetitive behaviour of companies (cartels and abuse of dominant position) and of states (granting exclusive rights or subsidies) as well as at mergers of companies, which affect the EU internal market. The course aims at equipping students with the necessary knowledge in order to identify anticompetitive behaviour and to assess legal consequences attached to this. It will furthermore give insights into how EU Competition law is to be applied in practice. The lecturers of this course are University academics and practitioners that work in big law firms dealing with Competition law cases and as judge at the General Court of the EU.

Leerdoelen This course aims to provide an insight into EU competition law. Students will develop an understanding of EU competition rules and practice that will allow them to identify the EU competition law issues and risks for private parties.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud In het kader van het vak EU-douanerecht en accijnzen wordt op verdiepende wijze ingegaan op een geselecteerd aantal onderwerpen uit het wetgevingspakket van het Douane Wetboek van de Unie. Aan de orde zullen onder andere komen het formele douanerecht, (het ontstaan van) de douaneschuld (classificatie, douanewaarde en oorsprong) en bijzondere regelingen. Ten aanzien van het douaneonderdeel wordt tevens ingegaan op de invloed en doorwerking van het internationale douanerecht zoals vastgesteld door de Wereldhandelsorganisatie, en op de juridische instrumenten zoals ontwikkeld door de Werelddouaneorganisatie. Daarnaast wordt aandacht besteed aan de heffing van accijnzen.
  Leerdoelen Na het volgen van dit vak is de student in staat om:
  • zelfstandig complexe vraagstukken vanuit douane- en accijnsrechtelijk perspectief te analyseren en op te lossen op het gebied van douaneschuld, classificatie, oorsprong, douanewaarde, douaneprocessen, -procedures, -regelingen, -bestemmingen en -formaliteiten, belastbare accijnsgoederen, het Europese accijnssysteem (schorsingsregime, uitslag tot verbruik en heffingsbevoegdheid) en accijnsuitzonderingen en -vrijstellingen;
  • de uitgangspunten en fundamenten van het Europese douanerecht en accijnzen te benoemen, herkennen, begrijpen en onderscheiden;
  • de samenhang en de verschillen tussen de heffing van douanerechten en accijnzen te analyseren;
  • samen te werken met medestudenten op een fiscaal multidisciplinair terrein;
  • een fiscaaltechnisch onderwerp te presenteren ten overstaan van zijn/haar medestudenten en daarbij blijk te geven van beheersing van presentatietechnieken;
  • zelfstandig een aangedragen fiscaaltechnische probleemstelling te analyseren, zich daarover een mening te vormen en deze te beargumenteren op een gedegen wetenschappelijke wijze;
  • de analyse en argumentatie t.a.v. een fiscaal juridisch vraagstuk begrijpelijk en overtuigend weer te geven in een verhandeling.

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud In Northern Europe, the late seventeenth and early eighteenth centuries saw the first proliferation of the Enlightenment – a cultural movement characterized by its pleas in favor of toleration, its opposition to ‘prejudices’, its fascination with the results achieved by the ‘Scientific Revolution’ as well as by its proposals for societal reforms. Philosophers played a crucial role in articulating its program. In this course we start close at home, for it was Pierre Bayle, ‘le philosophe de Rotterdam’, whose attacks on religious prejudices and whose demands for toleration would serve later generations of enlightened authors as a major source of inspiration. Next, we will turn to France, and to Montesquieu and Voltaire in particular. In France a new cultural phenomenon emerges: the philosophe, witty, sociable, and fiercely critical of received tradition. Many French authors start reading British philosophers, and in this course we will deal with both Berkeley and Hume, and we will wrap up this overview of the early stages of the Enlightenment with a discussion of the Scottish Enlightenment, including Adam Smith. In an accompanying (facultative) study group we will read one of Hume’s enduring masterpieces: Dialogues concerning Natural Religion. Leerdoelen

To fulltime students of Philosophy the seminars are compulsory.

The lectures will be recorded.

Having completed this course, students will be familiar with some of the main ideas put forward by Pierre Bayle. They will understand the main characteristics of ‘British empiricism’. They will be able to distinguish some of the main differences between the French and the Scottish Enlightenment. They will develop some awareness of the historical contingency of the history of eighteenth-century philosophy

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud
Politics speaks to us all. Some of us are involved only as citizens; others also as activists, analysts, reporters, or academics. The concepts we use, the positions we defend and the various practices we take part in belong to a tradition of thought that is as rich as it is fundamental to understanding our own society and politics in general. This course offers an overview of the most influential thinkers and themes of political philosophy from the Renaissance to the Enlightenment.

The week-by-week activities of the course will centre around an influential theorist and one of his key contributions. For example, Thomas Hobbes' innovative theory of sovereignty continues to have an enormous influence on work in the fields of international relations, sociology, political theory, history, and philosophy. By introducing such ideas in their historical context we can make them meaningful in terms of the problems the theorist meant to address; conversely, by having a conceptual interest in their theories we can read them in a way that emphasises the relevance of these classic works to our present world. For this reason, the orientation of the course will be both philosophical and historical. The course is a must for
anyone interested in the meaning and history of such concepts as virtue, sovereignty, power and rights.
history of such concepts as virtue, sovereignty, power and rights.
Leerdoelen After completing this course, students are able to:
  • formulate and explain the basic themes of political philosophy from the Early Modern Era, as well as their interrelation;
  • relate thinkers and themes of Early Modern political philosophy to politics in the present day;
  • formulate the difference between institutional approaches to the analysis of society and those focusing on the person of the leader;
  • relate utopianism to its roots in Thomas More, and to explain the relationship between utopianism and interpretations of politics as a moral enterprise;
  • explain the relationship between the classical/humanist concept of ‘virtue’ and Machiavelli’s concept of virtu;
  • define and analyze the ‘turn to nature’ in Machiavelli’s political philosophy and subsequent authors;
  • describe the importance of Hobbes to liberalism, e.g. in terms of consent;
  • explain the nature and necessity of sovereignty in Hobbes’ political philosophy;
  • connect the concept of democracy to Spinoza’s legacy;
  • relate Spinoza’s naturalism to his support for democracy and tolerance;
  • relate Montesquieu’s concept of liberty to his philosophical forebears as well as later political developments;
  • explain Montesquieu’s ideas on adapting laws to contextual factors;
  • describe Rousseau’s views on human nature and the corruption of society;
  • explain Rousseau’s conception of the general will.

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
lecturers: ['dr. HF Tibboel', 'dr. JL Panman', 'IPM Derks, MSc']
text:
Inhoud
In dit blok staan drie groepen psychische stoornissen centraal die te maken hebben met de basisbehoeften van de mens: eten, seks en slapen. Eetstoornissen zijn de afgelopen decennia steeds meer voor het voetlicht gekomen. Zowel in de wetenschap als in de media wordt er relatief veel aandacht aan besteed. Maar wat is er nu eigenlijk precies over bekend?
Seksuele stoornissen zijn veelal een taboe voor de cliënt, maar zijn vaak ook voor de psycholoog niet het makkelijkste onderwerp om over te beginnen. Des te belangrijker dus om er in de opleiding aandacht aan te besteden. Welke seksuele disfuncties kunnen we tegenkomen bij mannen en vrouwen, wat is er bekend over de achterliggende mechanismen, en hoe kunnen deze stoornissen het best behandeld worden?
Aan slaapstoornissen wordt in het psychologisch wetenschappelijk onderzoek nog relatief weinig aandacht besteed. In de praktijk is het echter één van de meest voorkomende stoornissen, die ook vaak als comorbide stoornis optreedt, en nadelige consequenties heeft voor ons psychisch- en sociaal functioneren. Voor een klinisch psycholoog daarom van belang om hier kennis over te hebben.
 
In dit blok komen van alle hierboven genoemde stoornissen de verschijningsvormen en theoretische verklaringsmodellen aan bod. Tevens wordt er aandacht besteed aan de verschillende behandelingsmethoden en de effectiviteit hiervan. Hoewel het zwaartepunt ligt bij dergelijke psychopathologie in volwassenen, wordt deze problematiek in kinderen en adolescenten ook behandeld in dit blok.
 
Blokopdrachten
In dit blok wordt aandacht besteed aan de toepassing van theoretische kennis en richtlijnen in klinische situaties. Studenten werken daarbij in teams aan blokopdrachten, die geevalueerd zullen worden met een voldoende/onvoldoende.
Leerdoelen Doel van dit blok is kennis verwerven over recente wetenschappelijke inzichten met betrekking tot de verschijningsvormen, theoretische verklaringsmodellen en behandelmethoden van eetstoornissen, seksuele stoornissen en slaapstoornissen bij zowel volwassenen als kinderen en adolescenten.

Aan het eind van dit blok, heb je substantiële kennis van …
  • de prevalentie, etiologie en (evidence-based) behandeling van anorexia nervosa;
  • de prevalentie, etiologie en (evidence-based) behandeling van bulimia nervosa;
  • de prevalentie, etiologie en (evidence-based) behandeling van de eetbuistoornis;
  • eetproblematiek bij kinderen;
  • psychologische factoren die een rol spelen bij obesitas;
  • de rol die lichaamsbeeld en zelfwaardering spelen bij eetstoornissen;
  • de belangrijkste (neuro)biologische principes van seksualiteit; 
  • de seksuele responscyclus;
  • de (informatie ver)werking van het seksuele systeem;
  • de prevalentie, etiologie en behandeling van seksuele stoornissen bij de man;
  • de prevalentie, etiologie en behandeling van seksuele stoornissen bij de vrouw;
  • de effecten van (farmacotherapie bij) psychiatrische stoornissen op seksualiteit;
Tevens heb je aan het eind van dit blok basale kennis van …
  1. de prevalentie, etiologie en psychologische behandeling van slaapstoornissen;
  2. de meetpretentie, validiteit en scoring van de Defense Style Questionnaire;
  3. de meetpretentie, betrouwbaarheid, validiteit, testafname en scoring van de Rorschach-test;
  4. de meetpretentie, betrouwbaarheid, validiteit, testafname en scoring van de Thematische Apperceptie Test (TAT).
Belangrijk om te weten De voertaal in de onderwijsgroepen is Engels of Nederlands, afhankelijk van de inschrijving voor de nationale of internationale opleiding.

college: Erasmus MC Academie
International Institute of Social Studies (ISS)
Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

Econometrics is characterized by the combination of economic research questions, use of empirical data, application of statistical and mathematical methods, and the use of software to estimate and evaluate models. All these topics are extensively discussed in the lectures and practised in the tutorials.

  • Lectures and exercise lectures: Introduction to econometrics, research questions, methods. The linear regression model (simple and multiple), method of least squares, testing. Non-linear models, maximum likelihood, some asymptotic theory of estimation and testing. The models and methods are motivated by economic applications and applied in practical examples. The required econometric methods make intensive use of earlier courses in the programme, in particular statistics, matrix algebra and analysis.
  • Tutorials: Exercises on theory and applications. Further, some tutorials consist of computer sessions to apply econometric techniques by means of the software package EViews.
Leerdoelen
  • Learn the mathematical structure and statistical properties of linear and non-linear regression models by means of matrix methods and statistical analysis.
  • Understand the process of econometric modelling as an interplay of economic insights, data properties, and statistical model assumptions.
  • Get experienced in the mathematical analysis and statistical evaluation of econometric models.
  • Get experienced in the practical interpretation of outcomes of econometric analysis and in choosing between alternative models and methods.
  • Get practical experience in analysing economic data by means of econometric software on the PC.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The tutorials and (preferably also) the lectures will be, as much as possible, on campus, and the exercise lectures will mostly be online via zoom. For students who cannot come to campus because of covid restrictions, the lectures are available in the form of videos that were made specifically for self-study at home. For these students there will also be one online tutorial group via zoom online. Take care, this online tutorial group is available only to students with covid restrictions, and attendance in this group will be closely monitored. Extra At the (re-)exam you may only use a simple calculator, not a graphical or programmable one.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
lecturers: ['dr. A Pick', 'prof.dr. M van der Wel']
text:
Inhoud

The lectures are a follow-up on the lectures in Econometrics 1. The following topics will be discussed:

  • Models with heteroskedasticity and/or serial correlation
  • Models with endogenous regressors
  • Models for limited dependent variables (logit, probit, multinomial)

After this course the student will have practical and theoretical knowledge of various extensions of the linear model (among which: heteroskedasticity, serial correlation, endogeneity). The student will also have knowledge of models for limited dependent variables (logit model, probit model, multinomial).
The student will be able to apply the theory in practice, and will also gain experience in the analysis of economic data using Eviews.

Leerdoelen
  • After this course the student will have practical and theoretical knowledge of various extensions of the linear model (among which: heteroskedasticity, serial correlation, endogeneity).
  • The student will also have knowledge of models for binary and multinomial dependent variables (logit and probit models).
  • The student will be able to apply the theory in practice, and will also gain experience in the analysis of economic data using Eviews.
Extra The written examination grade must at least be 4.5 in order to have the assignment grades count for your full grade.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructor: Dr A. Schnucker (EUR)
 
Short subject description:
This course provides knowledge on the quantitative analysis of economic data.
 
Course contents:
In this course we provide an understanding of basic econometric methods. Knowledge of these methods allows one to understand modern empirical economic literature and to perform one's own analysis of economic and business data. The technique of regression is discussed, as well as various extensions that are needed in concrete applications to deal with, for example, heteroskedasticity, autocorrelation, endogeneity, and non-linearities. Furthermore an introduction to discrete choice modeling is given. The main emphasis of the course is on the interpretation of models and outcomes of estimation and testing procedures. The students practice this themselves by analyzing economic and business data by means of the software R and by deriving and interpreting formulas for basic models and concepts.
Leerdoelen After this course students will be able to apply econometric techniques to answer empirical questions and will be able to critically evaluate econometric models.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructors: Prof. B. van der Klaauw (VU) and Dr H.G. Bloemen (VU)
 
Course content:
Many empirical questions in economics require estimating causal parameters. Regression models provide correlations which only have a causal interpretation if the zero conditional mean assumption holds. This assumption is often violated, for example when there are omitted variables, non-random sampling, reversed causality or measurement errors in regressors. In this course we discuss methods dealing with these confounding factors. In particular, we consider limited dependent variable models, instrumental variables estimation, panel data models and sample weighting. In this course, we introduce the potential outcomes model, which is the most general model for defining treatment effects such as average treatment effect, average treatment effect on the treated, quantile treatment effects and local average treatment effects. The emphasis of the course is on identification, estimation and interpretation rather than a thorough treatment of the asymptotic properties of the estimators. During the course applications of the different methods are discussed, mainly in the fields of labor economics, health economics, and the economics of education.
Leerdoelen The key objective of the course is applying microeconometric techniques rather than deriving econometric and statistical properties of estimators. After the course student should be able to decide about the appropriate model, apply the estimation method correctly, and they should be able to interpret the estimation results.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructor: Prof. S.J. Koopman (VU)
 
Short subject description:
This course provides knowledge on the quantitative analysis of economic time series.
 
Course contents:
In this course we provide an understanding of basic econometric methods for the analysis of time series.  Knowledge of these methods allows one to understand modern empirical economic literature and to perform one's own analysis of economic and business time series data. Autoregressive Moving-Average (ARMA) models are considered for stationary time series. Generalized Autoregressive Conditional Heteroskedasticity (GARCH) models are discussed for describing the time-varying volatility of time series. Models (and tests) for deterministic and stochastic trends are addressed. It is discussed how forecasts are computed and assessed. Further, multivariate time series models are considered: the Vector Autoregression (VAR) and cointegration. The main emphasis of the course is on the interpretation of models and outcomes of estimation and testing procedures. The students practice this themselves by analyzing economic and business time series by means of the econometric software package EViews and by interpreting and extending formulae for basic models and concepts.
Leerdoelen After this course students will be able to apply time series models to answer empirical questions and will be able to critically evaluate such models.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

Het vakgebied econometrie wordt gekenmerkt door een combinatie van economische vraagstellingen, gebruik van empirische gegevens, toepassing van statistische en wiskundige methoden, en gebruik van software om modellen te schatten en te evalueren. Al deze onderwerpen komen uitgebreid aan de orde in de hoorcolleges en worden geoefend bij de sommencolleges en in de practica.

  • Hoorcollege en sommencollege: Inleiding econometrie, vraagstellingen, modellen, methoden. Het lineaire regressiemodel (enkelvoudig en meervoudig), methode van kleinste kwadraten, toetsen. Niet-lineaire modellen, maximale aannemelijkheid, enige asymptotische theorie van schatten en toetsen. De modellen en methoden worden gemotiveerd vanuit economische toepassingen en toegepast in praktische voorbeelden. De benodigde econometrische methoden maken intensief gebruik van eerdere vakken uit het programma, met name statistiek, lineaire algebra en analyse.
  • Practicum: Opgaven over theorie en toepassingen. Voorts wordt enige malen een computer-practicum gehouden, waar econometrische technieken worden toegepast met het pakket EViews.
Leerdoelen
  • Leren van de wiskundige structuur en de statistische eigenschappen van lineaire en niet-lineaire regressiemodellen, door middel van matrixmethoden en statistische analyse.
  • Het proces van het econometrisch modelleren als snijvlak van economische inzichten, data eigenschappen en statistische modelaannames begrijpen.
  • Vertrouwd raken met het analyseren van de wiskundige en statistische structuur van econometrische modellen.
  • Vertrouwd raken met de praktische interpretatie van de uitkomsten van econometrische analyse en het kiezen tussen alternatieve modellen en methoden.
  • Opdoen van praktische ervaring met het analyseren van economische data met behulp van econometrische software op een PC.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar De practica en (bij voorkeur ook) de hoorcolleges vinden voor zover mogelijk op de campus plaats, en de meeste sommencolleges zijn online via zoom. Voor studenten die vanwege covid restricties niet naar de campus kunnen of mogen komen, zijn de hoorcolleges beschikbaar in de vorm van videos die speciaal zijn ontwikkeld voor thuisstudie. Ook is er voor deze studenten één online practicumgroep via zoom. Let op, deze online praticumgroep is uitsluitend beschikbaar voor studenten met covid restricties, en deelname aan deze groep zal zorgvuldig worden gemonitord.

  Extra Bij het (her)tentamen mag alleen gebruik worden gemaakt van een eenvoudige rekenmachine, niet van een grafische of programmeerbare.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

Het college is een vervolg op het college Econometrie 1 en bestaat uit de volgende onderwerpen:

  • Modellen met heteroskedasticiteit en seriecorrelatie
  • Modellen met endogene regressoren
  • Modellen voor kwalitatieve data (logit, probit, multinomiaal)

Na dit college heeft de student kennis van de theorie over diverse uitbreidingen van het lineaire model (waaronder: heteroskedasticiteit, seriecorrelatie, endogeniteit). Daarnaast heeft de student kennis van modellen voor keuzegedrag (logit, probit, multinomiale variabelen).
De student kan de theorie ook daadwerkelijk toepassen in de praktijk, en heeft ook ervaring met het zelf analyseren van economische data met behulp van Eviews.

Leerdoelen
  • Na afloop van het vak heeft de student praktische en theoretische kennis van verschillende existensies van het lineaire model (onder andere: heteroskedasticiteit, serie-correlatie, endogeniteit).
  • Studenten hebben ook kennis van modellen voor binaire en multinomiale afhankelijke variabelen (logit en probit modellen).
  • Studenten zijn in staat theorie in de praktijk toe te passen, en zullen ervaring opdoen in het analyseren van economische data met gebruik van Eviews.
Extra Het cijfer voor het schriftelijk tentamen moet minstens 4.5 zijn om de opdrachtcijfers te laten tellen.

college: Erasmus School of Law
Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. AMIB Vandenberghe', 'KM Mikolajczyk, LLM', 'prof.mr.dr. LT Visscher']
text:
Inhoud
<html>
<head>
	<title></title>
	<style type="text/css">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }
	</style>
</head>
<body>This 8-ECTS course aims at giving students an overview of the most important insights from the economic analysis of private law. It combines economic analysis of property law, tort law, and contract law. As far as property law is concerned, the course integrates the legal and the economic approach to ownership and illustrates costs and benefits of different ways to protect entitlements. As far as tort law is concerned, the course offers a comparative analysis of the legal principles from an economic perspective, particularly regarding the structure of liability, the damage compensation, and the insurance. As far as contract law is concerned, the course illustrates its goals and functions from an economic perspective. Moreover, it aims to provide a functional understanding of the spectrum of feasible contracts and of their use in legal practice.</body>
</html>

college: Erasmus School of Law
text: Inhoud This course offers an introduction to the economic analysis of regulation, which is broadly interpreted as government intervention in market processes. The course illustrates the purposes of regulatory intervention from a welfare economics perspective, and it discusses the tension between public and private interest in regulatory choices. A special focus of this course is on issues of European regulation and on cost-benefit analysis.

course_title: Economic Geography of Creativity and Urban Development
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud During the past decade, the concept of creative economy along with that of creative industries have experienced an intensifying academic research and policy attention. The course critically investigates theories and issues linked to culture, creativity, economy and cities. It will provide students with a contrasting set of views on the role of cultural and creative industries in cities through the use of theories, case studies and fieldtrips. Topics discussed include: the role of culture and creativity in   cities across centuries, the emergence of a creative city (e.g. a fashion capital), the economic geography of cultural production, cultural-led urban (re)generation, gentrification, circular economy, cultural intermediaries, (temporary) clusters, the black box of urban growth. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of cultural and creative industries and place, and the issues that arise from them.
 
 
Note
  • The maximum number of participants is 30.
  • This course is only open to Pre-Master students in Cultural Economics and Entrepreneurship, BA students in International Bachelor Arts and Culture Studies (IBACS) and BA Algemene Cultuurwetenschappen
Leerdoelen In this seminar students will acquire knowledge and understanding of the spatial dimension and characteristics of creativity as well as the connections between the development of cultural and creative industries and the growth of cities and regions. Special attention is dedicated the role cultural and creative industries play in supporting the transition to the circular economy.
At the end of the course students should be able:
  • To develop knowledge and understanding of theories applied to the spatial dimensions of creativity;
  • To apply concepts and theories to specific case studies in group presentations, discussions and written assignments;
  • To explain main issues and limitations of theories; critically assess the value and relevance of models, concepts and theories.

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud

This course represents an introduction to the field of Economic History. It looks at the historical record of economic growth and development in different parts of the world since ca. the 18th century, and reflects on the role played in it by several factors, in particular technological progress, human capital, institutions, international trade, and economic policy. By addressing questions such as “Why did the Great Divergence between Western Europe and the rest of the world take place?”, “Why did the Industrial Revolution take place in Britain?”, and “Why could other Western countries easily catch up with Britain, while other parts of the world remained underdeveloped?”, the course provides important insights for understanding why the world we live in nowadays is characterised by wide economic differences among countries.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

This course introduces key topics in Economic History. Among others, the following questions are explored:
• Why did some countries successfully transition from Malthusian stagnation to modern economic growth? What are the “deep roots” of this transition – geography?, institutions?, human capital?, culture?, the scientific revolution?
• How did today’s world economy come into being? What explains the evolution of markets, monetary systems, and exchange rate regimes through previous periods of globalization and de-globalization.
• What were the causes of the Great Depression? What were its consequences? What role did different economic policies play in ending it?

Leerdoelen

1. Familiarize yourself with the most important theories and the empirical evidence surrounding key events in economic history.

2. Develop a better understanding of how today's world economy came into being.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
lecturers: ['dr. AP Markiewicz', 'dr. D Sisak', 'prof.dr. OR Marie']
text:
Inhoud

The minor aims to broaden as well as deepen the knowledge and understanding of economics for individuals trained in econometrics on several dimensions.
Module 1 : "Theoretical Microeconomics"
This module begins with an introduction to/refresher of game theory to lay the methodological foundations. In the rest of the course we consider classical strategic problems of individual interaction such as

  • problems of coordination
  • communication and information exchange
  • contests & tournaments
  • bargaining

After a general analysis of these strategic situations, we apply the framework to questions of economic relevance.
Module 2 (Dr Agnieszka Markiewicz): "Macroeconomics: Theory and Practice"
In this module we will study the long run behaviour of economy and its short-run fluctuations.
In the first part (long-run), we will cover economic growth and unemployment.
In the second part (short-run), the focus will be on the consumption, investment and asset prices’ determination.
The models presented in this course are an introduction to modern macroeconomics and build on the 1st year macroeconomics course. We will study the applications of the models using academic papers.
Module 3 (Prof Olivier Marie): "Applied Micro-Econometrics Methods"
The module is about micro-econometric empirical strategies used to estimate causal relationships that are of interest to economists. These include:

  • Lab & field experiments
  • Randomized control trials
  • Difference-in-differences
  • Propensity score matching
  • Instrumental variables
  • Regression discontinuity

The module will describe the advantages (and disadvantages) of these different empirical strategies to identify the causal effect of a treatment. Students will learn what kind of identifying assumptions different empirical strategies are based on. We will also appraise which data requirements have to be met for the successful application of a particular strategy.
This will be done, for each method in turn, by:
1. reviewing the econometric theory behind the various methods
2. go through empirical papers which have successfully applied these methods

Leerdoelen

The goal of this minor is to introduce students to important macroeconomic and microeconomic problems and theories that modern economic research focuses on. A further key objective is to teach students how they can use empirical methods to systematically think about the relationships between microeconomic and aggregate variables.

Extra This minor is only accessible to ESE students who have a strong econometrics background.
This means that it is open to all bachelor students from one of the econometrics tracks and to those from the economics track who have obtained high grades in statistical and mathematical based courses.

Module 1:          Participation: 10%;                        Course Work: 20%;                       Research Paper: 70%

Module 2:          Participation: 10%;                        Course Work: 20%;                       Written Exam: 70%

Module 3:           Participation: 10%;                        Course Work: 20%;                       Research Paper: 70%

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. L Rosendahl Huber', 'F Mazzola, MSc', 'prof.dr. WB Wagner']
text:
Inhoud The course examines three interrelated questions:

1) How do firms (and individuals) make optimal choices?
2) In what way do these choices interact through markets?
3) How do businesses and managers adjust their decision making process to the characteristics of the markets in which they operate?

The first part of the course focuses on developing a sound understanding of the basic principles of consumer choice and the efficient use of inputs by firms. The second part of the course brings consumers and firms to the market place. Here we study how different market structures (perfect competition, monopoly, oligopoly, monopolistic competition) affect pricing and the allocation of resources. The final part of the course studies how various imperfections (such as asymmetric information and/or non-cooperative behaviour) affect outcomes.

A strong emphasis is placed on the applicability of theories, principles and concepts to actual situations
and concrete management problems. The skills developed during the course enable the students to (1) understand concrete situations and (2) to have an impact on these situations.
 
Leerdoelen
Learning goals

- To understand producer (and consumer) behavior and its impact on markets
- To grasp basic economic theories and principles and their impact on business strategies
- To develop an understanding of the basic market structures and what they imply for a company’s strategic behaviour
- To apply the tools of economics to solve business as well some economic problems

college: Erasmus School of Economics
lecturers: ['D Muslimova', 'dr. CA Rietveld', 'dr. EAW Slob, MSc']
text:
Inhoud

Almost all socio-economic characteristics (e.g., educational attainment, occupation, and income) have been shown to be moderately heritable. This makes it possible to identify specific genes that are related to socio-economic differences among individuals and to investigate how these genes interact with environmental factors. For example, which genetic factors contribute to educational attainment and do specific family environments moderate the genetic susceptibility to perform well in school? The goal of this course is to make students familiar with recent developments in the field of genoeconomics (i.e., the integration of genetics into economics), and to reflect on the ethical aspects of these developments. This course covers topics such as the nature vs. nurture debate, estimation and interpretation of heritability, gene discovery, and genetic prediction. Moreover, the students become familiar with big data analysis by performing basic genetic analyses using specialized statistical software.

Leerdoelen

The goal of this course is to make students familiar with recent developments in the field of genoeconomics (i.e., the integration of genetics into economics), and to reflect on the ethical aspects of these developments. During the course, students are introduced to key concepts and state-of-the-art computer tools in genetics.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Update of course contents (literature list) with most recent developments in the field.
Stronger coherence between lectures and tutorials. Extra Background knowledge about genetics is not needed to follow this course, but basic knowledge about statistics (e.g., regression analysis) will be assumed.

course_title: Economics and Financing of Health Care Systems
college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['D Cattel', 'dr. F Eijkenaar', 'dr. RC van Kleef', 'prof.dr. FT Schut', 'prof.dr. M Varkevisser', 'prof.dr. WPMM van de Ven']
text:
Inhoud Historical developments, political choices, and societal structures strongly influence the organization of health care systems across countries. The main purpose of this course is to provide an introduction to various conceptual frameworks that help you to understand and use economic principles applied to health care systems. The course will deal with theory of supply and demand in health care, the crucial role of (asymmetry in) information, provider payment incentives, private and social health insurance, theory and practice of managed compe­tition, organization and financing of long-term care, and the public/private mix in the financing and provision of care. The course looks at how health care systems, in the Netherlands as well as in other developed countries, deal with important policy issues like competition and regulation, solidarity, and the role of voluntary supplementary health insurance.

The course consists of:
  • Video lectures with explanations of key concepts
  • Live meetings with discussion, Q&A, assignments, etc.
  • 2 peer-reviewed group assignments
 
  Leerdoelen By the end of this course students are able to:
  • Analyze the challenges and economic complexities of healthcare (systems) that are relevant for health policy;
  • Classify different types of healthcare systems and analyze how these systems are organized and financed;
  • Infer and reflect on the implications of the organization and financing of healthcare systems for efficiency and equity;
  • Assess the comparative performance of healthcare systems and infer implications thereof for health policy.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The course illustrates the contribution of cultural economics to the analysis of cultural heritage to guarantee it a sustainable future. Students will learn the main topics characterizing the cultural-economic perspective on cultural heritage. The analysis will consider the issues related to cultural heritage conservation and enhancement emphasizing the role it can have for a sustainable economic, cultural and social development. The course will refer to the main documents issued by UNESCO and the EU related to the role of cultural heritage for society and will use the cultural economic concepts to reflect on the issues at stakes, the values involved and possible interventions to guarantee a sustainable conservation and enhancement of cultural heritage. The main issues considered are:
  • The evolution of the concept of cultural heritage: tangible, intangible.
  • Economic concepts applied to cultural heritage.
  • The values of cultural heritage, evaluation methods and their limits.
  • Cultural heritage policies: actors and tools.
  • Conventions and other protection instruments.
  • The World Heritage List.
  • Cultural heritage and tourism.
  • Conservation and adaptive re-use of cultural heritage.
  • Cultural heritage and sustainability.
  • Cultural heritage and development.
 
Note:  The maximum number of participants is 30. Leerdoelen After completing the course, students should have a wide-ranging knowledge and critical understanding of the cultural economic perspective on cultural heritage. They will be aware of the relevance of economic concepts and management issues related to cultural heritage and sites as well as of the main policy dilemmas arising in this field. The course gives specific attention to the connection between theory and practice referring to several case studies.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The course will introduce the main concepts related to tourism in general: its development, its economic impact, the main definitions and concepts (tourist, visitor, excursionist, carrying capacity of a destination), and the trends characterizing the sector and modifying it. The course will then focus on cultural tourism: a specific branch of tourism that is expanding though it is still difficult to identify and define. The economic approach will highlight the characteristics of the sector, its potential for the economic development of regions but also the risks it can entail (for example in terms of congestion and wear and tear of heritage sites). The course will provide a critical review of the virtuous-vicious relationship between tourism and culture and will focus on the possible strategies that can be applied to avoid or, at least, reduce the risks in order to attain sustainable cultural tourism development.
Every week the lecturer will introduce a theme illustrating the main theoretical notions and some examples. The week after a group of students will lead the class making a presentation that provides a thorough analysis of the same topic using a case study. Leerdoelen The aim of this course is to teach students the main concepts from the economics of tourism, considering the evolution and development of the sector through time, focusing in particularly on the niche of cultural tourism. Based on a critical engagement with the fundamental theories and empirical literature, students are challenged to identify and comment the effects, opportunities and challenges related to cultural tourism. Students will improve their presentation and writing skills by doing presentations in class and writing a final essay.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud The vast increase in digital insecurity - posed by ransomware, DDoS attacks, and data breaches amongst others - requires an intelligent cyber security strategy. However, very little is known regarding the social costs and benefits of investing in cyber security. This is worrisome: cyber security expenditures will rise exponentially in the future as mankind becomes increasingly dependent on the digital world. Cyber security is now a common topic on the agendas of SME’s, large corporations, global enterprises, and governments. 

In this course, we will cover several security related topics from an interdisciplinary perspective. From an economics point we will discuss the economic drivers and effectiveness of security investments, incentive structures and how they affect corporate strategy, and how scammers and cyber criminals make money. From a behavioral perspective we will cover how to achieve a corporate security culture and the role that employees play in cyber security. From a law perspective we will discuss novel legal instruments such as the possibility for insurance against cyber risks, the option to cover these risks by means of pooling, and the EU data breach notification obligation in the GDPR. Together, this course will provide a comprehensive and interdisciplinary overview of the different factors that influence the level of cyber security in government and industry.
   


    


 
  Leerdoelen The course objective is to learn about the role of economical principles and human behavior & decision-making on cyber crime and cyber security.

Upon completion of this course, students in the elective course the economics of cyber security should be able to:

1.    Describe tools that economists and social scientists use to understand and predict investments, costs, threats, and developments in cyber security. The discussed tools include network effects, scalability, risk aversion, prospect theory, and a range of relevant heuristics and biases.
2.    Illustrate how cybercriminals are organised and operate. What types of attacks do they use, how do they approach and persuade their potential victims, and how they are organised. You will also learn the role of Bitcoin and other crypto currencies in cybercrime. 
3.    Illustrate the discussed technological and human-centred cyber attack methods
4.    Explain how the legal aspects of cyber security, including relevant European legislation such as GDPR, affect the decision-making of individuals, industry, and governments.  
5.    Compare characteristics of victims of traditional crimes and cybercrimes. Discussed topics include who is more likely to become a victim, how people are affected by cybercrime victimization, and which factors influence reporting victimization. 
6.    Design an intervention to improve information secure behavior amongst employees.




  Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The course has changed in several ways. These changes are partly based on feedback from students (3, 4,5, 6, 7), partly based on novel findings in the field (1, 2), and partly based on my progressed experience as a lecturer (5, 6, 7).

1) The mandatory literature list is updated and expanded (before 9 papers, now 10).
2) The literature list for the group assignment is updated. 
3) The recommended literature list is updated and expanded with podcasts, blogs, and video lectures
4) 3 out of 4 guest lectures are practically oriented, with people working in industry or for the government.
5) Each lecture will contain a practical element / exercise
6) The final course grade will be comprised of 4 instead of 3 grades. Exam MC questions, exam open questions, ted talk + slides, and 1 page summary. 
7) The group assignment will be reframed to make it more attractive to student: ‘Talk like Ted’ instead of ‘recording an e-lecture’ Extra No computer science or technical background needed to follow this course.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructors: Prof. E.J.S. Plug (UvA), Prof. H. Oosterbeek (UvA) and Prof. T. Buser (UvA)
 
Course description:
Papers on various topics including returns to education, effects of class size, education for gifted students, school assignment models, intergenerational mobility and peer effects.
Leerdoelen After the course students have up-to-date knowledge of important research issues in the economics of education and they are aware of the importance of identifying assumptions.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud The seminar looks at the fashion industry as one of the creative industries. It aims to facilitate students’ knowledge and understanding of how the industry works. The seminar will confront students with the most recent theories linked to the characteristics, the demand, the supply and intermediaries for fashion products as well the sustainability issues in the fashion industry. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of the fashion industry. In doing so, we will discuss relevant literature and specific cases through student presentations, class discussion and field trips. Students will focus on one fashion product/firm/market and carry out research based on scholarly literature, resulting in an individual essay and in a group poster presentation.
 
Note:
 
The maximum number of students is 30.
  • Priority is given to bachelor students from Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication (7 students from BA Geschiedenis or IBHistory, 7 students from BA ACW or IBACS, 7 students from IBCoM, 3 exchange students, 9 students from other faculties or universities).
  • It is not allowed to take this course as an individual course; students are required to take the entire Minor Fashion Industry of 15 ECTs. Minor students should obtain a pass mark for each of the three course; it is not possible to compensate for a score below the pass mark.
  • Admission requirements: Proficiency in spoken and written English is essential [VWO-final examination grade: 7 or higher / TOEFL-test: minimum score 580 (paper-based), 237 (computer- based) or 92 (internet-based) / IELTS-test: minimum of 7(overall band)]
Leerdoelen The seminar aims to facilitate students’ knowledge and understanding of how the fashion industry works. The main objective is to gain insight into the cultural economic dimensions of the fashion industry. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of the fashion industry. In doing so, we will discuss relevant literature and specific cases through student presentation, class discussion and field trips.

course_title: Economics of Fashion, Design and Architecture
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud In academia, business environment and policy-making circles the past decade has given rise to a growing acknowledgment of the design industries as paradigmatic sectors of post-industrial economies, “cognitive-cultural” capitalism, or even better “neo-industrial” economies, in which production increasingly relies on symbolic and aesthetic considerations as well as on local specificities. The seminar provides a forum for discussion of the week's topic, reading material, case studies and fieldtrips. Students are expected to read and discuss the literature, summarize it for discussion in class and apply it to specific cases. A critical approach is encouraged. Topics covered in the course, among others: characteristics of design products; demand for design products; economic and spatial organization of design industries; labour market for designers; intermediaries, temporary clusters and global pipelines; sustainability, circular economy and design industries. Students will focus on design, fashion or architecture industries and carry out research based on scholarly literature, resulting in an individual essay and in a group poster presentation. This course builds further upon the courses in Term 1 and 2, and it is connected to topics that students will encounter in their master thesis.
 
Note
  • The maximum number of participants is 25.
  • It is not allowed to follow the seminar “Economics of Fashion, Design and Architecture” together with the seminar “Heritage and Fashion”
Leerdoelen The seminar wishes to facilitate students’ knowledge and understanding of the economic and spatial characteristics of the design industries - in particular fashion, design and architecture. We emphasize an analytical approach in understanding the dynamic development of the design industries. Special attention is dedicated the role design industries play in supporting the transition to the circular economy. In doing so, we will discuss relevant literature and specific cases through student presentation, class discussion and field trips.

course_title: Economics of Health and Health Care
college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. M Tenand', 'dr. PLH Bakx', 'J Stöckel, MSc', 'JAM Bom', 'M Bar', 'MS Perry-Duxbury, MSc', 'prof.dr. EKA Van Doorslaer']
text:
Inhoud This course builds on Economics and Financing of Health Care, in which the principles of health economics and health care financing are explained. This course uses the tools and concepts discussed in that course to analyse and compare health and health care at the macro or system level. The performance of health care systems may be evaluated by analysing whether the outcomes are efficient and equitable. Therefore, this course consists of three parts.

The first part is about the relationships between health, health care and income. Understanding these relationships is an important goal in its own right, but also provides some of the building blocks that are necessary for the definition and measurement of equity (part 2) and efficiency (part 3). In each of the three parts, the main focus is on applying the analytical framework – and evaluating how other researchers’ applied it – to compare the performance of developed and less developed countries and discuss the aspects of health care systems and their performance in a structured manner. Leerdoelen After taking this course, students are able to:
  • Explain why equity and efficiency are important health system performance indicators
  • Apply the tools that are used to measure equity and efficiency of health systems
  • Judge whether the measures of equity and efficiency are used in a valid and meaningful way in international comparative analyses of health care system functioning
  • Comment on scientific articles on health system performance from top journals in the field of health economics

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

Today both developed and developing countries are searching for ways to foster economic growth. Innovation is considered to be a major force for economic growth. Firms are key actors when it comes to innovation. This course focuses on strategic firm decisions to innovate and to improve (innovation) performance. This course provides students with a comprehensive and advanced understanding of what innovation is. It gives insight into how factors that are external and internal to the firm contribute to innovation and how different types of firms (e.g. start-ups, small firms, large firms) innovate. Students also learn how innovation relates to growth, and what problems and actors are involved in the financing of innovation.

Overall, this course aims to provide understanding of what strategic decisions different types of firms can pursue to improve their innovation and growth performance. These strategic decisions include decisions to compete or collaborate, to export, to hire R&D workers and to contract external consultants.

To help students understand what innovation is, this course makes students familiar with main concepts, models and measures of innovation. Different innovation strategies are considered such as investing in R&D, patenting and introducing new products in the market. Furthermore, different theoretical perspectives are discussed (such as industrial organisation theory, evolutionary theory and the resource-based view) to provide students with insight into how different factors (external and internal) may contribute to innovation. Also, attention is paid to how innovation and entrepreneurship are related and to whether innovations are mainly coming from large or small firms. At industry level, patterns of innovation will be explored across the industry life cycle including first-mover (dis)advantages. Furthermore, different views are discussed on how innovative start-ups emerge and on why innovative firms choose to compete or collaborate. The role of labor mobility across firms for innovation will also be discussed as well as relevance of strategy consulting firms for innovation.

To figure out how innovation relates to growth, different types of growth are considered (sales, productivity, and employment). Attention is also paid to whether innovation and export are complementary firm strategies or rather substitutes for achieving firm growth. Regarding innovation financing, the focus is on understanding why investments in innovation are different from other means of investment; what sources of innovation financing depending on the stage on the innovation development are available; and what typical problems can arise in the process of investing in innovation. Moreover, three sources of finance for start-ups, namely venture capital, crowdfunding, and angel investors, are discussed in more detail.

After this course students will be familiar with concepts, ideas and theories related to the emergence and development of innovation and will be able to apply these to real life examples of innovating firms. Furthermore, students will have learned to understand and interpret empirical articles and to use its findings to develop strategic advice for different types of firms (e.g., small firms or large firms) such as on how to improve their innovation and growth performance.

Leerdoelen
  • Students are able to reproduce and interpret main concepts and characteristics of innovation; economic incentives for innovation; how changes in the external environment and firm-internal changes impact upon innovation; the economic consequences of innovation; and what problems and actors are involved in the financing of innovation.
  • Students apply concepts, theories and paradigms of innovation to analyze complex and current issues of a (business) economics nature such as industry developments and differences, the role of entrepreneurs in fostering innovation and standards races.
  • Students analyze developments related to innovation (such as the emergence of industrial clusters and the increased globalization of specialized production) from several perspectives and then explain these developments based on the tension between those different perspectives.
  • Students present the results of an industry or company analysis.

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud Game theory is the study of strategic interaction. It is a structured approach to analysing situations in which there is room for cooperation and conflict. Such situations are abundant in markets, organisations, and beyond. This course provides an introduction to the use of game theory in a variety of contexts, in particular, bargaining and negotiation, contracting, and auctions. The emphasis of the course is on developing skills to approach problems in a structured and systematic manner. The course aims to promote a careful approach to strategic situations, without undue emphasis on technicalities. The reading material assigned for this course is illustrative of the sort of game-theoretic reasoning this course seeks to promote. Leerdoelen
  • To understand the basic tools of game theory
  • To develop skills for systematic, game theoretic, reasoning in decision making
  • To apply game theoretic reasoning to bargaining and negotiation
  • To understand how the design of contracts affects incentives
  • To understand the mechanics of various types of auctions

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

The economics of markets and organizations combines two fields of research: organizational economics and industrial organization. Industrial organization studies the interaction between firms, consumers, and suppliers on markets. Organizational economics studies the existence, design, and performance of organizations. These fields try to answer questions that include price setting under information asymmetry, incentive pay, how formal and real authority should be divided within the firm, whether an internal capital market is beneficial, and how discrimination on labor markets affects the education choice of different scholars. This course analyzes markets and organizations by studying seminal and contemporary papers in theory and empirics in this field.

The course analyzes papers on the following topics in detail:
1. Financial Markets
2. Labor Markets
3. Markets of Goods and Services
4. Incentives in Organizations
5. Authority in Organisations
6. Decision-Making in Organizations

This course deepens some of the topics from previous micro economics and organizational courses from the Bachelor and gives a preview of the topics discussed in the Economics of Markets and Organizations Master.

Leerdoelen

The goal of the course is to gain knowledge on the application of game theory models within the fields of industrial organization and organizational economics and link this knowledge to empirical papers on the same topic.

Learning goals
* Student is able to analyze models on the discussed topics using game theory
* Student is able to explain the economic intuition of the assumptions and results of these models
* Student is able to explain how empirical papers on the discussed topics corroborate or refute results from the theoretical models
* Student is able to place the models and empirical papers in broader literature

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

How do individuals, firms, and countries get what they want in interactions with other parties? Typically, preferences of different parties are not perfectly aligned. Parties can engage in negotiations to reach mutual agreements. When more than two parties are involved, auctions can be a valuable alternative to negotiations. This course will cover the main principles of negotiations and auctions in theory and practice. The first part of the course covers the game-theoretic basics of negotiations and auctions. The second part deals with putting theory into practice and designing effective mechanisms for negotiations and auctions. Finally, the third part covers behavioral biases in negotiations and auctions. Theory and mechanism design are mostly based on the assumption that parties are fully rational. Yet, how do parties negotiate in practice? Psychological and cultural factors are important to consider. It is crucial to identify the parties at stake in a negotiation and their ability to act rationally in various circumstances. To enhance the students’ insights into negotiations and auctions, guest lecturers will share their experiences in practice.

The course is organized around
• pre-recorded videos;
• guest lectures;
• and interactive plenary sessions involving negotiation games.

Leerdoelen

• Students will learn the core concepts of non-cooperative game theory.
• Students will learn the core concepts of cooperative game theory and negotiations.
• Students will learn the core concepts of auction theory.
• Students will learn to design effective mechanisms for reaching mutual agreements through negotiations and auctions.
