college: Erasmus School of Law
Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud Why do students need to understand the context of Information Systems within enterprises?
  • Information Systems (IS) have enormous strategic value so when they are not working even for a short time, an organization cannot function;
  • The Life Cycle Costs (acquisition, operation, security, and maintenance) of enterprise systems is considerable;
  • It is therefore essential to manage information systems properly. The planning, organizing, implementing, operating, and controlling of the infrastructures and the organization's portfolio of applications must be done with great skill;
  • To obtain awareness of different types of Information Systems and different roles that different systems play in organizations;
  • To gain awareness and knowledge of ERP, CRM, SCM and E-Commerce;
  • To be able to recognize opportunities that are enabled by information technology and to be able to decide to what extent information technology is needed within an organization.
  • To understand critical issues in Information Systems, such as security, project risks and outsourcing of Information Systems. Be able to identify these issues and deal with them.
  • The course also helps students digest why most ERP systems do not live up to its acronym of planning resources for the enterprise. Students should be able to critically evaluate the following questions:
  • What is ERP? What is EIS? How do People and Process come into Technology?
  • What are the similarities and differences between ERP and EIS?
  • How do Enterprise Systems affect Accountants and Economists?
  • How can economic theory help explain the effects of information technology on organizations and value chains?
  • What benefits have been realized by certain companies by implementing Information Technology?
  • How can information technology be an enabler but also be an inhibitor for realizing an organization its strategy?
  • What are advantages and disadvantages from new technologies as Big Data and Blockchain
Leerdoelen
  • Students have knowledge of the use of Enterprise information systems within organisations.
  • Students have knowledge of different applications of Enterprise information systems in organisations.
  • Students have knowledge of different economic theories that enable them to explain and understand the effects of the use of information systems within organisations.
  • Students have knowledge of how research is performed with regard to information systems.
  • Students are able to analyse and identify different situations in which technology is able to help an organization succeed in its goals.
  • Students are able to use different theories to explain how the use of technology may affect organisations.
  • Students are able to critically analyse and report on research findings from a project they perform in a logical and consistent way.
  • Students are able to present their research essay as well as answer critical questions about this essay in a convincing manner.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Within the course there is more emphasis on new developments in technology such as artificial intelligence and cryptocurrency.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud Telling entertaining stories to educate people is as old as mankind. Think of court jesters, fairytales, puppet shows: all examples of entertainment with an added value. Nowadays you find it in all modern media: drama and soap series on television, blogs on the internet, „webisodes‟ on your mobile phone. The difference with the old age is that because of the application of modern technology, the potential impact of an Entertainment-Education intervention is much bigger.
The Entertainment-Education strategy is a communication strategy that has received a lot of scientific attention (both nationally and internationally), and is being put into practice more and more often. To effectively apply this strategy, it is important to gain knowledge and skills both in academic and applied settings and beyond. In this course we discuss and show examples of EE programs, theories for social change, media practice, different EE collaborations, formative and summative research and ethics.  During the course you gain knowledge and experience via (guest) lectures, analyzing video and film fragments, and working in small groups on designing an Entertainment Education media program.

Note: The course will be cancelled if there are less than 10 students. The maximum number of participants is 25. IBCoM students take priority over other students. Leerdoelen This course gives you an in-depth understanding of the Entertainment-Education (EE) strategy and how it works in theory and practice. Entertainment-Education is a scientific communication strategy that systematically interweaves prosocial issues into an entertainment storytelling format in order to create a favorable climate for prosocial change. We will apply participatory working methods to actively engage you on your Entertainment-Education journey and to show how you can use your learning experience in your future professional life.
 
You have gained knowledge and understanding of:
  • The main theoretical approaches and perspectives on the Entertainment-Education for Social Change communication strategy.
  • Examples of how various Entertainment-Education media formats are designed and implemented worldwide (e.g. in soap- and drama series, webisodes, serious games, music, theater cross media and transmedia platforms).
  • How prosocial organizations, communication experts, entertainment media makers and other stakeholders collaborate during the design and implementation of an entertainment education program e.g. in the field of health, sustainability and social tolerance.
  • Different forms of Entertainment-Education research that come into play during the development and implementation of an EE media format.
  • Potential ethical dilemmas and unintended effects that might be faced.
 
You have developed skills to:
  • Analyze the applications of Entertainment-Education (EE) strategies worldwide and EE-formats in different media.
  • Apply theoretical notions of the EE strategy (e.g. social learning theory, elaboration likelihood model, para-social interaction, positive deviance strategy).
  • Identify and understand different roles of various stakeholders in the design and implementation of an Entertainment-Education media format.
  • Apply different forms of EE research.
  • Examine and (pro-actively) reflect on potential ethical dilemmas and unintended effects in Entertainment-Education programs.
  • Design and pitch an Entertainment-Education media intervention plan.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
The course Entrepreneurial Challenge is an intensive module. You will explore and experience what it entails to start a new and ambitious company. You will come to understand that not only existing businesses, but also new businesses require management. As you are enrolled in the Master in Management program, it is important to understand that without businesses there is nothing to manage, and without entrepreneurs there would be (and will be) no businesses. Furthermore, many RSM graduates will – at some stage in their career – consider entrepreneurship as a serious career opportunity. 
In line with RSM’s mission statement we will focus on social entrepreneurship, supporting one of the SDG’s which will be introduced elaborately. The course contains a concise introduction to the domain of social entrepreneurship theory and research. To apply the key concepts and tools in a real-life setting, teams will develop and revise their own start-up opportunities and explore viable business models in the field of social entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship is about turning unmet needs and unsolved problems into viable economic activity. The essence of entrepreneurship has been described as ‘the pursuit of opportunity without regard to the resources currently controlled.’ Entrepreneurship starts with the discovery of promising opportunities. Understanding the origins of such opportunities is key for start-up entrepreneurs and existing companies alike to develop business models that will effectively create and capture value from the identified opportunities. Entrepreneurship is not just a process, but also a mindset. In this module you develop that mindset by exploring the first stages of the process: the identification and evaluation of opportunities and the search for viable business models.
The course requires that all students actively participate in the classes. In addition, we expect the students to spend additional time per day on class preparation by reading the literature and doing project work. This course is a crash course into the (theoretical) foundations of entrepreneurship and a pressure cooker module for developing a business case and presenting it in front of a jury; both of them require your full dedication.

Sessions and attendance
The sessions in this module will differ in nature, ranging from student presentations, to workshops, to feedback sessions. During these meetings, a proactive and constructive atmosphere will be stimulated: a collaborative, open approach is needed to help each other and to learn from each other. The instructor in this course will serve primarily as a coach, rather than as a teacher. His main concern is to guide the group and the teams through the necessary thought and work processes.

Attendance of all university sessions is compulsory

This course is worth 2 EC.

Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
Content-wise: During this course:
  • You will come to understand that new venture creation is a process to systematically turn business model assumptions into knowledge, and that this learning process typically involves business model change.
  • You will come to understand the complexity of the new venture creation process, i.e. you will be able to explain and illustrate that its key steps, activities and challenges are highly interrelated, interdisciplinary, unpredictable, heterogeneous, and iterative.
 
Analytical skills: During this course:
  • You will develop the capability to construct, evaluate, and refine business models for new ventures.
  • You will develop the capability to set-up effective and efficient research designs to turn critical assumptions into knowledge.
 
Social-communicative skills: During this course:
  • You will develop the capability to document your business modelling process concisely, with clarity, logical flow, and coherence. 
  • You will develop the capability to discuss and present your new venture creation process in a variety of contexts, i.e. in your multidisciplinary student team, during the plenary workshops, in a feedback session with startup coaches and entrepreneurs, and in front of an expert panel at the final presentation session.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

This course aims at providing students with an overview of opportunities and challenges faced by entrepreneurs in young, high-growth ventures.
The course is divided into three parts.
In the first part, the course explores valuation methods for entrepreneurial ventures (e.g. DCF analysis and multiples) and how to assess their growth potential.
The second part of the course focuses on obtaining external funding: it studies the advantages and disadvantages of different funding players (e.g. angel financing, Venture Capital, crowdsourcing), furthermore it explores the design of financing instruments (e.g. staging, convertible instruments).
Lastly, the third part of the course describes and investigates exit strategies and their related costs and benefits (e.g. acquisitions, IPOs).

Leerdoelen

Understanding the main challenges faced by entrepreneurs in the early stages of their ventures, especially in uncertain and innovative streams of business.
Understanding the factors considered by investors when selecting which entrepreneurial project to fund.
Analyzing the benefits and costs associated with different sources of funding, both for the entrepreneurs and financiers.
Understanding the various ways investors and entrepreneurs can exit from their ventures and monetize their investments.
By the end of the course, students will gain an overview of the process of starting, funding, growing and exiting an entrepreneurial project. The course will have them equipped with the tools to better understand the financing of innovation and the venture capital industry.

Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The course will incorporate one more guest lecture (so 2 instead of 1). This is to meet students' feedback about the guest lecture.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

The aim of the course is to introduce students to theories of corporate governance. The course will cover the topics on corporate board, ownership structure, IPOs, institutional investor, regulatory reforms, stakeholder involvement and corporate social responsibility. Some of the theory included are: Agency theory; Transaction costs economics; Stakeholder theory; Stewardship theory; Institutional theory; Political theory as well as Network governance and case studies/ examples real life corporate stories. 

The course will include lectures combining theory, cases and live examples including a project, for students to analyze, discuss and present on during seminar sessions and workshops. 

Students will be expected to be active participants in exploring real instances of effect of governance issues on actual entrepreneurial firms of all sizes but with particular attention to smaller and family enterprises. 

Students will be encouraged to make use of provided articles, case studies but also to explore themes and topics by accessing news sites, databases and public informational depositories in a guided but self-proactive environment 

Leerdoelen

After following this course, the student will be able to: Critically reflect on and provide well-grounded analysis of these elements crucial for small, and medium firms, as well as: 

Knowledge and Understanding 

  • Analyse the main elements of good corporate governance 

  • Develop corporate governance frameworks  

  • Evaluate the value and impact of company boards 

  • Critically appraise corporate governance challenges  

Skills 

  • Cognitive/Subject-specific skills 

  • Construct corporate governance frameworks, considering alternatives and assessing these in light of recent academic insights 

  • Evaluate business risks and opportunities for growth, reflecting on the potential for contributing to success as demonstrated by recent academic research. 

  • Practical/subject specific skills 

  • Synthesize information from appropriate sources 

  • Demonstrate effective communication to persuade and influence stakeholders Key/transferable skills 

  • Select and use appropriate investigative and research skills 

  • Demonstrate effective report writing skills

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
Behind each successful venture, there is an investor. No ventures can scale without sufficient funding and mentoring from investors. However, ventures successfully backed by investors are a select group as fewer than 5% of ventures receive funding of which only about 25% ever return their invested capital. Selecting ventures that hit a homerun is an exception rather than a rule. As it is difficult to predict which venture will successfully scale up, we need ‘smart’ investment strategies that help to cope with these uncertainties.

In this course, we will learn that investing in ventures is more than simply making ‘random bets’. Entrepreneurial investments can be understood and managed. The course guides students through the investment process of selecting, monitoring, and exiting ventures. We will get to know the different types of entrepreneurial investors, such as venture capitalists, corporate investors, and governmental investors. We will discuss topics such as the venture capital investment model, combining strategic and financial investment goals, investing under uncertainty, staged decision-making, syndication, venture selection and monitoring techniques, and exit strategies. The knowledge and analytical skills gained in this course will be particularly valuable for students who are seeking a career in high-technology industries, venture capital, new business development, and consulting.

The course consists of 4 lectures, a session for the in-class group assignment, a guest lecture, and an individual assignment. During the lectures we will discuss a set of readings, that students are expected to have read before the start of a lecture. Students are invited to think about a discussion question in advance, and actively participate during the discussion in the classroom. Leerdoelen

Learning Objectives

  • Understand the theoretical assumptions underlying entrepreneurial investment models.
  • Understand how to apply the theoretical concepts related to entrepreneurial investments into real-life examples.
  • Understand the key activities, and challenges in the investment process to select, monitor, and exit ventures.
  • Recognize the options that investors have when making entrepreneurial investment decisions.
  • Understand how to analyze, benchmark, and evaluate different entrepreneurial investment strategies.
  • Present investment plans concisely, with clarity, logical flow, and coherence.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud

Contents, course description
Running a start-up requires operating under high uncertainty and navigating through often chaotic environments, where information may be scarce and unreliable. In this course, we will focus on the customer discovery process and address a set of skills that can help early-stage entrepreneurs with their opportunity pursuit. In particular, we will discuss the process of identifying one’s core business assumptions and engage in actively testing them by soliciting and analyzing potential customers’ feedback.  In doing so, we will also discuss the role of leadership in this context, as well as the characteristics of highly-effective teams and explore how these can impact the performance, motivation and culture of the venture. Using a set of experiential tools, we will also practice how to interview customers for maximum insight, how to effectively revise and update one’s business concept and how to generate commitment and traction for one’s idea. We will also focus on a range of influence tactics and negotiation techniques, which you can apply when testing for a product-market fit.  The overall aim of the course is to provide practical knowledge and skills that future entrepreneurs can apply when developing, testing and validating their hypotheses about a business opportunity.

Leerdoelen

Learning Objectives

At the end of this course, students will be able to:
  • Understand the dynamics of the entrepreneurial process and learn best practices for customer development.
  • Learn and apply a set of interviewing best practices for customer discovery
  • Learn the characteristics of effective team formation and recognize your own team profile, identifying core strengths and areas for improvement.
  • Engage with a set of negotiation techniques and influence tactics and learn how to apply them in order to improve your start-up’s outcomes.
  • Identify the right balance of roles, rewards and relationships in your start-up and learn how to discuss them best when setting up your team.
  • Understand the set of entrepreneurial skills, necessary at different stages of the idea validation process
  • Develop self-awareness as to your own entrepreneurial skillset and its strengths and areas for improvement, based on reflection and action learning tools

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Inhoud
De Entrepreneurial Challenge is een kort en krachtig vak. In teamverband verken en ervaar je wat het is om een nieuw en ambitieus bedrijf te starten. Je leert dat management niet alleen management nodig is in bestaande bedrijven, maar ook geldt in nieuwe, jonge bedrijven. Veel van de lessen blijken bovendien niet alleen van toepassing op nieuwe bedrijven, maar zijn ook relevant voor het management in volwassen bedrijven en organisaties.
 
In lijn met de missie van RSM – A force for positive change – richt de challenge zich meer in het bijzonder op het het starten van een social business met als doel om impact te maken in lijn met een of meer Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). In het vak worden enkele theoretische concepten en theorieen geïntroduceerd, met als doel om deze toe te passen in de praktijk. Deelnemers gaan in teams zelf ideeën verkennen en business modellen ontwikkelen.
  Leerdoelen Leerdoelen
Na afloop van het vak:
  • Begrijp je dat het starten van een bedrijf bestaat uit het systematisch ontwikkelen en testen van kritieke veronderstellingen over het business model, en dat dit leerproces doorgaans gepaard gaat met flinke veranderingen in het business model zelf.
  • Begrijp je de complexiteit van het start-up proces. Je bent in staat om de verschillende hoofdstappen, -activiteiten en -uitdagingen uit te leggen en te illustreren.
  • Ben je in staat om business modellen voor startups te ontwikkelen, te evalueren, en aan te passen
  • Ben je in staat om effectief en efficient onderzoeksmethoden te ontwikkelen en toe te passen om startup-ideeën te valideren.
  • Ben je in staat om het startup proces beknopt en helder te documenteren
  • Ben je in staat om het startup proces te presenteren en te bediscussiëren

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['prof.dr. D Metzger', 'prof.dr. PGJ Roosenboom', 'R Chotiputsilp, MA']
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
The objective of this course is to provide students with a state-of-the-art understanding of the valuation of small and mid-cap public and private firms, and the economics of contracts as it applies to entrepreneurship and new venture finance. Entrepreneurship concerns the undertaking of new business ventures. We will analyse the unique financial issues relating to entrepreneurial firms and to develop a set of skills that has wide applications for such situations. Specific topics will include: start- up ventures; financial management of rapidly growing firms; deal structuring; valuation; initial public offerings; the decision to harvest; and leveraged / management buyouts. We will discuss the various sources of capital for entrepreneurial firms. These sources include venture capital, commercial banks and crowd funding. The decisions of firms at various phases of their life cycle will be examined and the advantages and disadvantages of various sources of financing will be compared. Analytical tools will be introduced and utilized. Financial analysis, various valuation methods, negotiations, and deal structuring are examined in the context of entrepreneurial firms. This course is aimed at students who plan to start, acquire, finance or work for entrepreneurial, fast-growing businesses. It will also be useful for students who plan to join venture capital / private equity firms and investment banks. The course aims at instructing the student in how “real world” professional investors and corporate managers operate to create wealth from entrepreneurial activity.  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
After having followed this course, students are among others able to understand how to value a start-up firm, how contracts used in new venture finance shape incentives, how deals are structured, how to finance young start-up companies, how private equity works in creating value in start-ups, buyouts and growth financing and how to decide when to exit investments. Students are also able to appraise and construct a valuation for a start-up company, compare and select the different sources of financing and connect theory and practice.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
Contents, course description
If you want to know more about developing a business model for a startup and/or setting up your own venture, the Entrepreneurial Lab course is for you. Within an intense and hand-on experiential approach, the Entrepreneurial Lab course allows you exploring a business opportunity with your team and testing its potential value. 
​
This course provides advanced master students with a practical, yet rigorous understanding of the role, the analytics, and the process of business planning that leads to the successful creation of new ventures. Above all, students will be responsible to develop their own professional networks. As it’s a hands-on course, you will learn about business modelling, how to refine opportunities, analyse feasibility, financial planning, and organisational implementation. You will write a weekly blog and a business report and pitch your idea to a jury of experts. In previous years our students launched successful new businesses, including Senz Umbrellas, Symbid and Yoursurprise.com.
Leerdoelen
Learning Objectives
After this course, students will:
  • Define and assess the elements of new business models and recognize how these elements interrelate to each other;
  • Identify major assumptions in their start-up’s business model mainly on their value proposition;
  • Translate assumptions in their start-up’s business model in measurable hypotheses, test them, and change the business model accordingly;
  • Communicate and effectively interact with others to discover and develop a viable start-up business model.
  • Reflect critically on the entire process of the project and evaluate peer and own contribution to the project.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['AM de Greef, MSc', 'dr. FPH Jaspers', 'dr. G Criaco', 'dr. I Verheul', 'J Dresia', 'L Fuligni', 'M Bax']
text:
Inhoud In this Minor, students learn how entrepreneurs create business opportunities and transform them into successful start-ups and sustainable businesses. You experience what it takes to become an entrepreneur by developing your own business idea in a team of students, under the guidance of expert coaches. We believe that entrepreneurship is not only reserved for exceptional visionary people such as Steve Jobs, Richard Branson and Elon Musk, but that everyone can be an entrepreneur, provided they are motivated and know where to start. We provide students with a toolbox that helps them to get started. You will learn and practice an effectual and lean approach to creating new ventures. This approach is based on action-oriented core principles that underlie the decision-making approach and behaviour of expert entrepreneurs. The emphasis is not on writing a business plan but on testing ideas in the market and building real partnerships with relevant stakeholders such as customers, suppliers and investors.
The entrepreneurial adventure in this Minor concludes with a pitch event where student teams present their business idea and achievements to a panel of experts. For this course, there is intense collaboration with the Erasmus Centre for Entrepreneurship (ECE), i.e., the Rotterdam knowledge hub that supports the teaching staff of the Minor with their expertise and network of entrepreneurs within the Rotterdam area. For more information, see: http://ece.nl.
Leerdoelen After following this course, the student is able to:
  •  Understand and apply the principles of effectuation and value proposition design
  • Mobilize resources to build a viable company with a long-term vision
  • Effectively communicate and work together in a team
  • Apply a series of tools and develop entrepreneurial skills. Specifically, you will learn to:
  • Develop a realistic customer profile
  • Evaluate the customer-problem fit
  • Develop a viable value proposition
  • Evaluate the problem-solution fit
  • Set a suitable prize for your value proposition
  • Create a (validated) business model
  • Design and deliver a good pitch

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
lecturers: ['dr. AM Nadolska-den Ouden', 'dr. CA Sabel', 'dr. I Verheul']
text:
Inhoud Course overview
No entry requirements or required background knowledge.

The Entrepreneurship course is spread throughout block 7 and 8.

In block 7, we will use different teaching methods to illustrate entrepreneurship from an academic perspective. Block 7 zooms in on 4 key questions:
 
  1. What is entrepreneurship? (Module 1)
  2. What types of entrepreneurs are there? (Module 2)
  3. What is an "entrepreneurial opportunity"? (Module 3)
  4. What do you need to be successful as an entrepreneur? (Module 4).
Each module addresses the question from different angles and methods. Each module consists of knowledge clips, tutorials, and literature.
The prescribed literature will be discussed in the knowledge clips (available via Canvas). Tutorials offer room to discuss the literature in an interactive way to increase knowledge, understanding and insight gained from the knowledge clips. After tutorial 3 you need to submit an assignment. The assignment concerns a course related film it is meant to apply knowledge gained during tutorials and offer an opportunity to reflect on the literature. As a final assignment in block 7 you will work on a business case, where you will identify an entrepreneurial opportunity for the case company (more details on this assignment can be found below).
Block 8 will be dedicated to the “RSM Entrepreneurship Challenge”. For the Challenge you will be divided into teams of students to develop a value proposition for your company and to validate it in the market. Any form of social and economic value creation is permitted as long as it is (1) legal, (2) does not damage the reputation of Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University and (3) is based on a clear earnings model and business model. To support this Challenge, seminars and feedback sessions will focus on developing a value proposition and creating a business model. In an entrepreneurial way, you will be introduced to important milestones that can ultimately lead to the start of a successful own business. Block 8 will be concluded with a presentation and a group report. In week 22, the course will be concluded during the final of the RSM Entrepreneurship Challenge. Leerdoelen Learning objectives Block 7
After the modules, tutorials and the business case, the student can:
  1. Explain what entrepreneurship is, what the core elements are, and why entrepreneurship is seen as indispensable in our economy and society;
  2. Analyze the process underlying the start of a new business;
  3. Apply literature on topics covered in the course during discussions and assignments;
  4. Prepare well-founded and structured assignments and develop a business case that meets the guidelines of academic writing set in this course.
Learning objectives Block 8
After the lectures, tutorials and the Entrepreneurship Challenge, the student can:
  1. Develop a proposition and business model based on the Lean Startup method;
  2. Explain how an individual can develop into a (successful) entrepreneur; how to set up a business; and how this company can develop successfully;
  3. Present his or her own business idea by means of a "Pecha Kucha" presentation;
  4. Implement a project in a team with random fellow students.

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud
In this course we will introduce entrepreneurship as an academic discipline and we will discuss some important aspects of starting a new venture. This course contains a concise introduction to the domain of entrepreneurship theory and practice. Entrepreneurship is all about identifying opportunities and pursuing them. Understanding the origins of such opportunities is key for entrepreneurs and existing companies alike in order to develop business models that will effectively create and capture value. In this course students will focus on three views of entrepreneurship theory: entrepreneurship, corporate entrepreneurship and social entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship is not just a process but also a mind-set; it is behaviour.  Students will also develop that mind-set by practically exploring the initial stages of entrepreneurial process: the identification and evaluation of opportunities and the search for viable business models by following lean canvas principles. This course is a crash course in the (theoretical) foundations of entrepreneurship and a pressure cooker module for developing a business venture and presenting it in front of a jury from Entrepreneurship Center of Erasmus (ECE).
Leerdoelen After the course, students are able to:
  • Explain what entrepreneurship is, what its central elements are, and why entrepreneurship is crucial for our economy and society;
  • Explain the difference between entrepreneurship and management in general, and between entrepreneurship, intrapreneurship and social entrepreneurship in particular.
  • Develop a business model by applying the principles of the lean startup method.
  • Explain how new ventures emerge and develop.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud During this course we will address the role of entrepreneurship within media markets. We will look at this issue from two angles: entrepreneurship from the perspective of the challenger start-up   company and entrepreneurship within existing media firms. We will discuss literature on entrepreneurship and business model innovation and apply these insights to media related case studies. Furthermore, we will discuss how entrepreneurial principles are applied to media endeavors with not-for-profit social objectives. We will address questions such as: how to identify new market opportunity or social opportunities,  how to find competitive advantage in a media market, how to move from idea to execution and how to scale up and manage growth.
 
In line with the entrepreneurial focus of this course, students are required to write a business plan
for a media-related startup and develop a new value proposition for an existing company. During this process students will experience the valuable contribution of scientific inquiry and insights for the development of new products and services. Students are also required to pitch their business idea and will receive presentation training during the course.
 
As entrepreneurship is the theme of the course, we will invite several professionals from the media industry to discuss their entrepreneurial endeavors. We will also try to arrange having company visits (the dates for these visits might be at a different time than regular classes). Students are also encouraged to organize this themselves.


  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding  of:
  • Current theory and research on entrepreneurship and innovation and entrepreneurship in media.
  • Characteristics of media markets.
  • Business  model innovation.
  • Social  entrepreneurship theory
 
Students have developed skills to:
  • Analyze entrepreneurial activity and entrepreneurship both from the perspective of the challenger and the incumbent companies.
  • Apply models such as the business model canvas and strategy tools to the media industry.
  • Develop a business idea for a media-related start-up.
  • Create a business plan and strategy for an entrepreneurial endeavor for an existing media company.
  • Create a business plan and strategy for a social entrepreneurship initiative

course_title: Epidemic Disease, Famine and Development in Historical Perspective
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud

Entering the 21st century, climate change, globalization, inequality, and rural-to-urban migration have created conditions conducive to emerging infectious diseases and food production challenges. Epidemics and famine are yet to be consigned to the past, and this is worrying given that the World Health Organization has expressed concerns that the social and economic impact of both can be massive. However, measuring their effects is not straightforward. Can history provide new insights by offering a temporal perspective?

By comparing traumatic events such as Great European Famine of 1315-17, the ‘Columbian Exchange’ diseases of American colonization, the worldwide influenza pandemic of 1918-20, and the Great Leap Forward Famine in China of 1958-62, can we understand more about diseases today such as Ebola or famines in East Africa, Syria and Yemen? Although the past may be a ‘foreign country’, we shall see that there are many points of continuity and similarity.

Students will learn the causes and characteristics of epidemics and famines, and their effects on development and welfare, social (dis)order, gender inequalities, public health, and their relationship with climate change. We also consider how epidemics and famines have been represented and remembered by surviving generations, and consider controversies over ‘who is to blame’.

Leerdoelen
  1. Students will explain the causes, characteristics and consequences of epidemic diseases and famines throughout history.
  2. Students will recognize that the outcomes from epidemics and famines could be very different across time, region, and outbreak, and offer explanations.
  3. Students will draw links between the pre-industrial past, the recent past, and contemporary developments, and show the value of a historical approach to epidemics and famines.

college: Erasmus University College
text:
Inhoud This course will teach you the main concepts of Epidemiology and Global Health. Epidemiology is the quantitative study of disease occurrence and distribution in specified populations, the study of consequences of health problems as well as risk and protective factors, and the application of this knowledge to prevent and control health problems. You will learn (i) how to use methodological approaches to measure the incidence and prevalence of diseases in populations, (ii) how to determine causes of diseases, and (iii) how and when interventions may contribute to improvements in population health. Throughout the course you will work on an evidence-based prevention plan for a disease and country of your choice. Leerdoelen After following this course you will be able to:
  • Understand measures of occurrence of disease
  • Understand causes of diseases and relations between exposure and disease
  • Analyse relative importance of causes for the burden of disease
  • Understand the effectiveness of interventions
  • Design effective intervention strategies

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

Een essay over een fiscaal actueel thema ontleend aan recente wetswijzigingen, recente rechtspraak of fiscaalmaatschappelijke ontwikkelingen.

Leerdoelen

Extra De Paper hoeft niet in blok 1 geschreven te worden, maar heeft doorgaans een uiterste inleverdatum die in de eerste helft van Januari ligt.

course_title: Essential Contemporary Challenges: Philosophy and Practice
college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud

What does it mean to be a philosopher today? What can we as philosophers contribute to pressing debates on societal issues? Shall we try to offer solutions or rather ask the right questions? What can we learn from the philosophical tradition in current crisis situations? And what does it mean for philosophers to “create positive societal impact” according to the Erasmian Values of our university?

This course aims to promote philosophical reflection on contemporary challenges through exploring various dilemmas and possible responses, We will examine key contemporary examples in practical philosophy of pressing social, political and cultural issues, or ‘challenges’ such as the climate crisis and the crisis of truth and trust in politics. We will discuss the specific function and value of a philosophical approach to these challenges, the relation between descriptive and normative statements in contemporary debates, the relation between philosophy and politics and the role of the philosopher in society.

Leerdoelen

Lectures will be recorded.

Weekly tutorials, obligatory for full-time philosophy students, optional for double degree students

Ability to discuss case studies philosophically Ability to analyse, reflect and take a position on 4 societal issues discussed during the course and identify philosophical arguments and positions with respect to them

Ability to reflect on the role of philosophy in societal, political, and public debates

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud Ethical Aspects of Economics is a course about topics at the intersection of ethics and economics. You will be introduced to several contemporary topics in this area and given the opportunity to write on issues that you find particularly interesting.

The course will begin with two economic concepts with great importance for contemporary ethics: efficiency and utility. Next, we look at ethical aspects of research in economics. We then turn to debates over distributive justice: how should the resources produced in the economy be distributed? Finally, we dive into the arguments concerning the ethical limits of markets. Leerdoelen By the end of the course, students can:
(1) define and elaborate on core concepts in economics (utility, Pareto improvements, randomised controlled trials etc.) and ethics (moral incentives, rule vs. act utilitarianism, moral corruption, distributive justice, etc.)
(2) understand and critically assess philosophical arguments and theories involving these concepts in terms of their coherence, cogency, and relevance.
(3) argue independently within the debates about these arguments and theories, both in written research and interactive discussions.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud
This course examines the major issues and effects of advertising on society, with a focus on ethical issues and media literacy. Specific concentration is given to examining the responsibility to of the advertising industry to adhere to standards of conduct that reflect the best interest not just of its consumers, but also the interests of the markets and societies it reaches. The course will explore contemporary issues in a context that explores the ethical issues essential to various advertising genres, as well as the economic, political, and social impact of advertising in mass communication.

Hereby, the course deepens the critical lens that students have gained in previous studies or preparatory trainings. While the course covers the basic features and applicability of various ethical issues, the emphasis is on broadening and widening their critical lenses and research skills through media literacy.

The course thus contributes to students’ ability to conduct research independently, in groups and change perspectives.  
 
Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • Conceptual and/or theoretical knowledge of ethics in advertising/marketing
  • The practice of ethics, drives behind agendas in the advertising industry
  • How ethical issues intellectually and emotionally impact the advertising industry, the people that work in it and the people that are served by it (e.g., consumers)

Students have developed the skills to:
  • Examine and challenge advertising practices in terms of ethical issues
  • Dissect ethically charged issues and practices for the purpose of gaining an understanding of foundations on which a perspective is based
  • Creatively solve ethical problems facing the advertising industry
  • Work with peers in the discussion, development, and assessment of ethically charged advertisements

college: Erasmus School of Philosophy
text:
Inhoud This graduate course offers a profound examination of ethics and economics in theory and practice. Firstly, we will study some key concepts and values in economics. What is a market, and what are the virtues and moral limits of markets? What are property rights, and what is their moral relevance? What are the values usually invoked to defend markets? How are markets taken to promote efficiency, freedom and human well-being respectively? Secondly, we will analyze some substantive normative positions on economic questions, such as those held by right-libertarians, left-libertarians or Marxists. This will also allow us to study different ethical foundations that have been offered for different economic systems, such as varieties of capitalism and socialism. In a third step we explore the moral limits of markets and discuss possibly alternative economic systems. Among others, we discuss some specific policy proposals related to debates about ethical problems of our current economic system, such as basic income as a response to increasing material inequality. Leerdoelen The main objective of this course is twofold. Firstly, students acquire an understanding of the relationship between ethics and economics in terms of its historical development, as well as in terms of its role in the contemporary discipline of economics, as well as the economy. Secondly, students learn to critically assess the positions in the field and further develop their oral and written argumentation skills.
  • By the end of this course you should have a good overview of recent work done in the field of economics ethics. You will have studied work by the main contemporary philosophers as well as the most important discussions and issues in this field.
  • You will be equipped to do research (e.g. for a Master’s dissertation) on questions of economic ethics, both theoretical/conceptual as well as applied questions.
  • This course will help you to improve your knowledge of methods and styles of arguments in analytical moral philosophy (esp. ethics/normative political philosophy) – which can also be useful for other streams within analytical moral philosophy.
  • You will be able to practice, refine and further develop your writing and argumentation skills for analytical practical philosophy. This will be a special focus of this course, since you will receive detailed and extensive individual feedback on your written pieces of work.
  • You will be able to practice, refine and further develop your oral argumentation and presentation skills in moral philosophy, through participating in the class discussions.
  • You will be able to learn/practice/rehearse some basic skills related to literature searching and use of libraries and bibliographical search methods.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud

Econometricians use methods and techniques drawn from mathematics and statistics to address economic issues and questions. These questions can concern the macroeconomy, finance, microeconomic issues, labor, and various business economic settings. Typically, econometricians examine economic theories, create forecasts, develop multiple scenarios, propose optimal decisions, or evaluate policies. When the examinations are substantially novel and relevant to share with academics, the research findings can be published in academic literature, where other econometricians judge the merits of the work. In many other settings, however, the studies end up in an advice to an end user who can use the forecasts, who decides on the continuation or a change of the policy, who implements a proposed decision, or who picks one of the scenarios for making further plans.

It is important to recognize that such an end user rarely is an econometrician too. An end user can for example be an employee (top level or middle level) in a government, in a company, or in a bank. This implies that rarely an end user can fully grasp every single step that an econometrician has set when creating the product. At the same time, it is often also not possible to present every single step, and perhaps it is also not instrumental for the end user’s intentions. This means that the end user must trust that the econometrician made the right choices during the analysis.

There are various ethical guidelines around, and these usually concern honesty related to for example data cleaning (from raw data to the data to be analyzed), estimation methods, decisions based on statistical inference, trial and error and the reporting. Basically, these guidelines should establish that the final product can be reproduced when a list of choices and also the programming code is provided.

In this course I will initially discuss these guidelines but after that, in the main content of the book, I will address more specific ethical issues that follow from the fact that there is a knowledge asymmetry between the end user and the econometrician. Loosely said, even when the standard ethical guidelines are obeyed, it is still possible to provide an advice that meets a specific request of an end user. For example, it is not difficult to create a forecast that comes close to a desired target of an end user.

This course provides a range of cases where the knowledge asymmetry can be exploited intentionally, even though reproduction still is possible. There are cases where the result crucially depends on a single observation, cases where the statistical test is performed such that an outcome is manipulated, and for example cases where initial configurations dominate the result, even though it is very difficult to see.

Leerdoelen

Students learn:
General aspects of ethics (lecturer from ESPhil)
General aspects of ethics in econometric academic research and application
Specific aspects of the ethics of econometrics which are caused by knowledge asymmetry between model builder/forecaster (the adviser) and the the advisee.
